text:
97
CHAPTER 6  The Permanent Maxillary Incisors
summary: Chapter 6 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the Permanent Maxillary Incisors.

text:
The incisal ridge may be seen clearly, and a differentiation 
between the incisal edge and the remainder of the incisal ridge, 
with its slope toward the lingual, is easily distinguished.
summary: Description of the incisal ridge and its differentiation from the incisal edge.

text:
The outline of the lingual portion tapers lingually toward the 
cingulum. The cingulum of the crown makes up the cervical por-
tion of the lingual surface.
summary: Description of the lingual portion of a tooth crown tapering towards the cingulum and the cingulum making up the cervical portion of the lingual surface.

text:
The mesiolabial and distolabial line angles are prominent from 
the incisal aspect. The relative positions of these line angles should 
be compared with the mesiolingual and distolingual line angles, 
which are represented by the borders of the mesial and distal mar-
ginal ridges. The mesiodistal calibration of the crown at the labial 
line angles is greater than the same calibration at the lingual line 
angles.
summary: Comparison of mesiolabial and distolabial line angles with mesiolingual and distolingual line angles in dental crown calibration.

text:
The crown of this tooth shows more bulk from the incisal aspect 
than one would expect from viewing it from the mesial or distal 
aspect. Relatively broad surfaces are at the site of contact areas 
mesially and distally. Comparison should also be made between 
the dimensions of the crown labiolingually and mesiodistally. The 
labiolingual calibration of the crown is more than two-thirds as 
great as the mesiodistal calibration. A cursory examination would 
not reveal this detail.
summary: The crown of the tooth has more bulk from the incisal aspect and broad surfaces at the contact areas mesially and distally.

text:
Bilaterally, the outline of the incisal aspect is rather uniform. 
However, the lingual portion shows some variation in that a line 
drawn from the mesioincisal angle to the center of the cingulum 
lingually will be longer than one drawn from the same point on 
the cingulum to the distoincisal angle. The crown conforms to a 
triangular outline reflected by the outline of the root cross section 
at the cervix mentioned earlier.
summary: Description of variations in the lingual portion of the incisal aspect of a tooth compared to the outline of the root cross section at the cervix.

text: Maxillary Lateral Incisor
summary: The maxillary lateral incisor is a specific tooth located in the upper jaw.

text:
Figs. 6.13 through 6.21 illustrate the maxillary lateral incisor in 
various aspects. Because the maxillary lateral incisor supplements 
the central incisor in function, the crowns bear a close resem-
blance. The lateral incisor is smaller in all dimensions except root 
length (Table 6.2). Because it resembles the maxillary central inci-
sor in form, direct comparisons are made with the central incisor 
in its description.
summary: Comparison of maxillary lateral incisor with central incisor in terms of size and function.

text:
This tooth differs from the central incisor in its development, 
which may vary considerably. Maxillary lateral incisors vary in form 
more than any other tooth in the mouth except the third molar. If 
the variation is too great, it is considered a developmental anomaly.
summary: Maxillary lateral incisors vary in form more than any other tooth in the mouth except the third molar, and excessive variation is considered a developmental anomaly.

text:
A common situation is to find maxillary lateral incisors with a non-
descript, pointed form; such teeth are called peg-shaped laterals 
(see Fig. 6.21, 7 and 8). In some individuals the lateral incisors are 
missing entirely;7 in these cases the maxillary central incisor may 
• Fig. 6.13  Maxillary right lateral incisor, labial aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Peg-shaped maxillary lateral incisors and missing lateral incisors are common dental anomalies.

text: • Fig. 6.14  Maxillary right lateral incisor, lingual aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the lingual aspect of a maxillary right lateral incisor with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text: • Fig. 6.15  Maxillary right lateral incisor, mesial aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the mesial aspect of a maxillary right lateral incisor with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text: • Fig. 6.16  Maxillary right lateral incisor, distal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the distal aspect of a maxillary right lateral incisor with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text:
98
CHAPTER 6    The Permanent Maxillary Incisors
summary: Chapter 6 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the Permanent Maxillary Incisors.

text:
be in contact distally with the canine. The presence of a palatogin-
gival groove in maxillary incisors may be a predisposing factor in 
localized periodontal disease (see Fig. 6.21, 3).8 This groove is also 
referred to as the palatoradicular groove.9
summary: The presence of a palatogingival groove in maxillary incisors may be a predisposing factor in localized periodontal disease.

text:
One type of malformed maxillary lateral incisor has a large, 
pointed tubercle as part of the cingulum; some have deep devel-
opmental grooves that extend down on the root lingually with a 
deep fold in the cingulum; and some show twisted roots, distorted 
crowns, and so on (see Fig. 6.21).
summary: Malformed maxillary lateral incisors can exhibit various abnormalities such as large pointed tubercles, deep developmental grooves, twisted roots, and distorted crowns.

text:
Detailed Description of the Maxillary Lateral 
Incisor From All Aspects
summary: This text provides a detailed description of the maxillary lateral incisor from all aspects.

text:
Labial Aspect
Although the labial aspect of the maxillary lateral incisor may 
appear to favor that of the central incisor, usually it has more
summary: The labial aspect of the maxillary lateral incisor differs from that of the central incisor.

text:
curvature, with a rounded incisal ridge and rounded incisal angles 
mesially and distally (see Figs. 6.13 and 6.19). Although the crown 
is smaller in all dimensions, its proportions usually correspond to 
those of the central incisor.
summary: The crown of the tooth has a rounded incisal ridge and incisal angles, with proportions similar to a central incisor.

text:
The mesial outline of the crown from the labial aspect 
resembles that of the central incisor, with a more rounded 
mesioincisal angle. The crest of contour mesially is usually at 
the point of junction of the middle and incisal thirds; occa-
sionally, in the so-called square forms, the mesioincisal angle 
is almost as sharp as that found on most maxillary central 
incisors (see Fig. 6.19, 4 and 5). However, a more rounded 
mesioincisal angle is seen more often. The distal outline of the 
crown from the labial aspect differs somewhat from that of the 
central incisor.
summary: The mesial outline of the crown of maxillary lateral incisors resembles that of central incisors but with a more rounded mesioincisal angle.

text:
The distal outline is always more rounded, and the crest of 
contour is more cervical, usually in the center of the middle
summary: Description of the distal outline and crest contour in dental anatomy.

text: • Fig. 6.17  Maxillary right lateral incisor, incisal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the incisal aspect of the maxillary right lateral incisor with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.
The text block contains a list of numbers in ascending order.

text:
6
7
8
9
10
• Fig. 6.18  Maxillary lateral incisor, incisal aspect. Ten typical specimens are shown.
summary: Illustration showing the incisal aspect of a maxillary lateral incisor with ten typical specimens.

text:
99
CHAPTER 6  The Permanent Maxillary Incisors
summary: Chapter 6 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent maxillary incisors.

text:
third. Some forms describe a semicircular outline distally from 
the cervix to the center of the incisal ridge (see Fig. 6.19, 3 
and 7).
summary: Description of a semicircular outline extending distally from the cervix to the center of the incisal ridge.

text:
The labial surface of the crown is more convex than that of the 
central incisor except in some square and flat-faced forms.
summary: The labial surface of the crown is more convex than that of the central incisor in certain cases.

text:
This tooth is relatively narrow mesiodistally, usually approxi-
mately 2 mm narrower than the central incisor. The crown on the 
average measures from 2 to 3 mm shorter cervicoincisally than 
that of the central incisor, although the root is usually as long, if 
not somewhat longer, than that of the central incisor.
summary: Description of the dimensions of a tooth in comparison to a central incisor.

text:
In general, its root length is greater in proportion to its crown 
length than that of the central incisor. The root is often approxi-
mately 1.5 times the length of the crown.
summary: The root length of the lateral incisor is generally greater in proportion to its crown length compared to the central incisor, with the root being approximately 1.5 times the length of the crown.

text:
The root tapers evenly from the cervical line to a point approxi-
mately two-thirds of its length apically. In most cases, it curves 
sharply from this location in a distal direction and ends in a 
pointed apex. Although the curvature distally is typical, some 
roots are straight (see Fig. 6.19, 4, 7, and 9), and some may be 
found curving mesially. As mentioned previously, this tooth may 
show considerable variance in its crown form; the root form may 
be more characteristic.
summary: The root of a tooth typically tapers evenly from the cervical line to a pointed apex, with variations in curvature and form.

text:
Lingual Aspect
From the lingual aspect, mesial and distal marginal ridges are 
marked, and the cingulum is usually prominent, with a tendency 
toward deep developmental grooves within the lingual fossa, where 
it joins the cingulum (see Fig. 6.14). The linguoincisal ridge is 
well developed, and the lingual fossa is more concave and circum-
scribed than that found on the central incisor. The tooth tapers 
toward the lingual, resembling a central incisor in this respect. It 
is not uncommon to find a deep developmental groove at the side 
of the cingulum, usually on the distal side, which may extend up 
on the root for part or all of its length. Faults in the enamel of the 
crown are often found in the deep portions of these developmen-
tal grooves (see Fig. 6.21, 3 and 4).
summary: The lingual aspect of a tooth features prominent marginal ridges, a well-developed linguoincisal ridge, and deep developmental grooves that may have faults in the enamel.

text:
Mesial Aspect
The mesial aspect of the maxillary lateral incisor is similar to that 
of a small central incisor except that the root appears longer (see 
Figs. 6.15 and 6.20). The crown is shorter, the root is relatively 
longer, and the labiolingual measurement of the crown and root 
is a millimeter or so less than that of the maxillary central incisor 
of the same mouth.
summary: The mesial aspect of the maxillary lateral incisor is similar to a small central incisor but with a longer root and shorter crown.

CHAPTER 6    The Permanent Maxillary Incisors
summary: Chapter 6 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the Permanent Maxillary Incisors.

text:
The curvature of the cervical line is marked in the direction of 
the incisal ridge, although because of the small size of the crown 
the actual extent of curvature is less than that found on the central 
incisor. The heavy development of the incisal ridge accordingly 
makes the incisal portion appear somewhat thicker than that of 
the central incisor.
summary: The curvature of the cervical line is marked in the direction of the incisal ridge, making the incisal portion appear thicker due to the heavy development of the incisal ridge.

text:
The root appears as a tapered cone from this aspect, with a 
bluntly rounded apical end. This varies in individuals, with the 
apical end sometimes being quite blunt, whereas at other times, 
it is pointed. In a good many cases, the labial outline of the root 
from this aspect is straight. As in the central incisor, a line drawn 
through the center of the root tends to bisect the incisal ridge of 
the crown.
summary: Description of the root anatomy of a tooth with a tapered cone shape and varying apical end.

text:
Distal Aspect
Because of the placement of the crown on the root, the width of 
the crown distally appears thicker than it does on the mesial aspect 
from marginal ridge to labial face (see Fig. 6.16). The curvature 
of the cervical line is usually a millimeter or so less in depth than
summary: The distal aspect of a dental crown appears thicker due to its placement on the root compared to the mesial aspect.

text:
on the mesial side. It is not uncommon to find a developmental 
groove distally on this crown extending on the root for part or all 
of its length.
summary: Developmental groove may extend distally on the crown and root of a tooth.

text:
Incisal Aspect
The incisal aspect of this tooth sometimes resembles that of the 
central incisor, or it may resemble that of a small canine (see Figs. 
6.17 and 6.18). If the tooth conforms in development to its cen-
tral incisor neighbor in other respects, it will, from the incisal 
aspect, resemble a central incisor except in size (see Fig. 6.18, 5 
and 9). However, the cingulum may be large, as is the incisal ridge. 
In addition, the labiolingual dimension may be greater than usual 
in comparison with the mesiodistal dimension. If these variations 
are present, the tooth has a marked resemblance to a small canine 
(see Fig. 6.18, 3 and 10). (To view Animations 3 and 4, please go 
to Expert Consult.)
summary: The incisal aspect of a tooth can resemble either a central incisor or a small canine depending on its development and characteristics.

text:
All maxillary lateral incisors exhibit more convexity labially 
and lingually from the incisal aspect than do the maxillary central 
incisors.
summary: Maxillary lateral incisors have more convexity labially and lingually compared to maxillary central incisors.

summary: The text block is a question asking about the proximity of the mandibular lateral incisor to a specific measurement.

text:
The mandibular incisors are four in number. The mandibular cen-
tral incisors are centered in the mandible, one on either side of the 
median line, with the mesial surface of each in contact with the 
mesial surface of the other. The right and left mandibular lateral or 
second incisors are distal to the central incisors. They are in contact 
with the central incisors mesially and with the canines distally.
summary: Description of the arrangement of mandibular incisors in the dental arch.

text:
The mandibular incisors have smaller mesiodistal dimen-
sions than any of the other teeth. The central incisor is somewhat 
smaller than the lateral incisor, which is the reverse of the situation 
in the maxilla.
summary: Mandibular incisors have smaller mesiodistal dimensions compared to other teeth, with the central incisor being smaller than the lateral incisor, opposite to the maxilla.

text:
These teeth are similar in form and have smooth crown surfaces 
that show few traces of developmental lines. Mamelons on the 
incisal ridges are worn off soon after eruption if the occlusion is 
normal, which leaves the incisal ridges smooth and straight (com-
pare Fig. 7.9, 7 and 8). The contact areas are near the incisal ridges 
mesially and distally, and lines drawn through the contact areas 
are near the same level on both central and lateral incisors; here 
also the situation is unlike that of the maxillary incisors. The man-
dibular incisors show uniform development, with few instances of 
malformations or anomalies (see Fig. 7.12).1,2
summary: Mandibular incisors have smooth crown surfaces with few developmental lines, worn mamelons, and uniform development.

text:
The anatomic form of these teeth differs entirely from that 
of the maxillary incisors. The inclination of the crowns differs 
from the mesial and distal aspects; the labial faces are inclined 
lingually so that the incisal ridges are lingual to a line bisect-
ing the root. After normal wear has taken place, obliterating 
the mamelons, the incisal surfaces show a labial inclination 
when the occlusion has been normal. Note that the incisal sur-
faces of maxillary incisors have a lingual inclination. With this 
arrangement, the incisal planes of the mandibular and maxil-
lary incisors are parallel with each other, fitting together during 
incising action.
summary: The anatomic form of mandibular incisors differs from maxillary incisors, with labial inclination after normal wear.

text: Mandibular Central Incisor
summary: The mandibular central incisor is a specific tooth located in the lower jaw.

text:
Figs. 7.1 through 7.12 illustrate the mandibular central incisor 
in various aspects. Generally the mandibular central incisor is the 
smallest tooth in the dental arches (Table 7.1). The crown has little 
more than half the mesiodistal diameter of the maxillary central 
incisor; however, the labiolingual diameter is only about 1 mm 
less. The lines of greatest masticatory stress are brought to bear on 
the mandibular incisors in a labiolingual direction, which makes 
this reinforcement necessary.
summary: Description of the mandibular central incisor anatomy and its size compared to the maxillary central incisor.

dibular central and lateral incisors.
	3.	 Discuss the grid diagrams of the permanent mandibular
summary: Discussion on the grid diagrams of the permanent mandibular central and lateral incisors.

central and lateral incisors and be able to correctly draw the 
graph outlines of each tooth from all views. Note: Being able 
to model correct tooth contours is fundamental to learning. 
Drawing, waxing, and/or carving the teeth are good ways to 
practice this.
	4.	 Discuss common anatomic variations seen in each tooth type.
	5.	 List similarities and differences between permanent man-
summary: Discussion on modeling correct tooth contours and practicing tooth drawing, waxing, and carving as fundamental learning methods in dentistry.

text:
The single root is very narrow mesiodistally and corre-
sponds to the narrowness of the crown, although the root 
and crown are wide labiolingually. The length of the root is 
as great as, if not greater than, that of the maxillary central  
incisor.
summary: Description of the narrow single root of a tooth corresponding to the crown's narrowness but wide labiolingually, with root length comparable to or greater than a maxillary central incisor.

text:
Detailed Description of the Mandibular Central 
Incisor From All Aspects
summary: This text provides a detailed description of the mandibular central incisor from all aspects.

text:
Labial Aspect
The labial aspect of the mandibular central incisor is regular, 
tapering evenly from the relatively sharp mesial and distal incisal 
angles to the apical portion of the root (see Figs. 7.7 through 7.9). 
The incisal ridge of the crown is straight and is at approximately 
a right angle to the long axis of the tooth. Usually the mesial and 
distal outlines of the crown make a straight drop downward from 
the incisal angles to the contact areas, which are incisal to the 
junction of the incisal and middle thirds of the crown. The mesial
summary: The labial aspect of the mandibular central incisor has a regular shape with straight incisal ridge and outlines tapering evenly towards the root.

text:
and distal sides of the crown taper evenly from the contact areas 
to the narrow cervix.
summary: The mesial and distal sides of the crown taper evenly from the contact areas to the narrow cervix.

text:
The outlines of the mesial and distal roots are straight with the 
mesial and distal outlines of the crown down to the apical portion. 
The apical third of the root terminates in a small pointed taper, in 
most cases curving distally. Sometimes the roots are straight (see 
Fig. 7.9, 2 and 10).
summary: Description of the straight outlines of the mesial and distal roots with a small pointed taper at the apical third.

text:
The labial face of the mandibular central incisor’s crown is ordi-
narily smooth, with a flattened surface at the incisal third; the 
middle third is more convex, narrowing down to the convexity of 
the root at the cervical portion.
summary: Description of the labial face of the mandibular central incisor's crown.

text:
Except in newly erupted teeth, central incisors show few traces 
of developmental lines. The labial surface of the root of the man-
dibular central incisor is regular and convex.
summary: Central incisors typically show few developmental lines, with a regular and convex labial surface on the root of the mandibular central incisor.

text:
Lingual Aspect
The lingual surface of the crown is smooth, with a very slight 
concavity at the incisal third between the inconspicuous marginal
summary: Description of the lingual aspect of a dental crown with a slight concavity at the incisal third.

Labial
Lingual
summary: The text mentions labial and lingual aspects of dental anatomy.

text: Distal
summary: Distal refers to the direction away from the midline or center of the body.

text: Incisal
summary: The term 'Incisal' refers to the cutting edge of anterior teeth.

text:
Mesial
• Fig. 7.7  Mandibular right central incisor. Graph outlines of five aspects are shown. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)

CHAPTER 7    The Permanent Mandibular Incisors
summary: Chapter 7 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent mandibular incisors.

text:
ridges (see Figs. 7.1, 7.3, 7.7, and 7.8). In some instances, the 
marginal ridges are more prominent near the incisal edges (see Fig. 
7.11, 2 and 8). In these cases the concavity between the marginal 
ridges is more distinct.
summary: The text describes how marginal ridges can be more prominent near incisal edges and have a distinct concavity between them.

text:
The lingual surface becomes flat and then convex as progres-
sion is made from the incisal third to the cervical third.
summary: The lingual surface of a tooth changes from flat to convex as you move from the incisal third to the cervical third.

text:
No developmental lines mark the development of the cingulum 
on this tooth at the cervical third. No other tooth in the mouth 
except the mandibular lateral incisor shows so few developmental 
lines and grooves. The outlines and surfaces of the mandibular 
incisors are regular and symmetric.
summary: The mandibular lateral incisor shows few developmental lines and grooves, with regular and symmetric outlines and surfaces.

text:
Mesial Aspect
The curvature labially and lingually above the cervical line is less 
than that found on maxillary incisors (see Figs. 7.4, 7.7, 7.8, and 
7.10).
summary: The mesial aspect of teeth has less curvature labially and lingually above the cervical line compared to maxillary incisors.

text:
The outline of the labial face of the crown is straight above 
the cervical curvature, sloping rapidly from the crest of curvature 
to the incisal ridge. The lingual outline of the crown is a straight 
line inclined labially for a short distance above the smooth con-
vexity of the cingulum; the straight outline joins a concave line 
at the middle third of the crown, which extends upward to join 
the rounded outline of a narrow incisal ridge. The incisal ridge is 
rounded or worn flat, and its center is usually lingual to the center 
of the root.
summary: Description of the labial and lingual outlines of the crown of a tooth, including the incisal ridge and its position relative to the root center.

text:
The curvature of the cervical line representing the cementoe-
namel junction (CEJ) on the mesial surface is marked, curving 
incisally approximately one-third the length of the crown.
summary: The curvature of the cervical line representing the cementoenamel junction (CEJ) on the mesial surface is marked, curving incisally approximately one-third the length of the crown.

text:
The root outlines from the mesial aspect are straight with the 
crown outline from the cervical line, so that the root diameter is 
uniform through the cervical third and part of the middle third; 
the outline of the root begins to taper in the middle third area,
summary: Description of root outlines and tapering in dental anatomy.

Lingual

• Fig. 7.12  Mandibular central incisor. Ten specimens with uncommon variations are shown. (1) Crown and 
root very broad mesiodistally; malformed enamel at incisal third of crown. (2) Crown wide at incisal third, 
with short crown; root length extreme. (3) Unusual contours at middle third of crown; cervix narrow. (4) 
Well-formed crown; short root. (5) No curvature labially at cervical third; extreme labial curvature at root 
end. (6) Specimen well formed but undersized. (7) Contact areas pointed at incisal edge; crown and root 
very long. (8) Crown long and narrow; root short. (9) Crown measurement at cervical third same as root; 
crown and root of extreme length. (10) Crown and root very wide labiolingually; greater curvature than 
average above cervical line at the cervical third of the crown.

CHAPTER 7  The Permanent Mandibular Incisors
summary: Chapter 7 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent mandibular incisors.

text:
tapering rapidly in the apical third to either a bluntly rounded or 
a pointed root end.
summary: Description of root morphology tapering rapidly in the apical third to either a bluntly rounded or a pointed root end.

text:
The mesial surface of the crown is convex and smooth at the 
incisal third and becomes broader and flatter at the middle third 
cervical to the contact area; it then becomes quite flat, with a ten-
dency toward concavity immediately below the middle third of 
the crown and above the cervical line (see Fig. 7.10, 5, 8, and 10).
summary: Description of the mesial surface of the crown in dental anatomy.

text:
The mesial surface of the root is flat just below the cervical line. 
Most of these roots have a broad developmental depression for 
most of the root length. The depressions are usually deeper at the 
junction of the middle and apical thirds (see Fig. 7.10, 3 and 9).
summary: The mesial surface of the root has a flat area below the cervical line with developmental depressions, deeper at the middle and apical thirds.

text:
Distal Aspect
The cervical line representing the CEJ curves incisally about 1 mm 
less on the distal aspect than on the mesial aspect (see Figs. 7.5, 
7.7, and 7.8).
summary: The cervical line curves incisally about 1 mm less on the distal aspect than on the mesial aspect.

text:
The distal surface of the crown and root of the mandibular 
central incisor is similar to that of the mesial surface. The devel-
opmental depression on the distal surface of the root may be more 
marked, with a deeper, better-defined developmental groove at its 
center.
summary: The distal surface of the crown and root of the mandibular central incisor is similar to the mesial surface, with a more marked developmental depression on the distal surface of the root.

text:
Incisal Aspect
The incisal aspect illustrates the bilateral symmetry of the man-
dibular central incisor (see Figs. 7.1, 7.6, 7.7, 7.8, and 7.11). The 
mesial half of the crown is almost identical with the distal half.
summary: The incisal aspect of the mandibular central incisor demonstrates bilateral symmetry.

text:
The incisal edge is almost at right angles to a line bisecting the 
crown labiolingually. This feature is characteristic of the tooth and 
serves as a mark of identification in differentiation between man-
dibular central and lateral incisors (see Mandibular Lateral Incisor, 
later). Note the comparison between the diameter of these crowns 
labiolingually and their diameters mesiodistally. The labiolingual 
diameter is always greater.
summary: The incisal edge of mandibular central and lateral incisors is almost at right angles to a line bisecting the crown labiolingually, with the labiolingual diameter always being greater.

text:
The labial surface of the crown is wider mesiodistally than the 
lingual surface. The crown is usually wider labially than lingually 
at the cervical third, which latter area is represented by a smooth 
cingulum.
summary: The labial surface of the crown is wider mesiodistally than the lingual surface, with the crown usually wider labially than lingually at the cervical third.

text:
The labial surface of the crown at the incisal third, although 
rather broad and flat in comparison with the cervical third, 
has a tendency toward convexity, whereas the lingual surface 
of the crown at the incisal third has an inclination toward 
concavity.
summary: The labial surface of the crown at the incisal third is convex while the lingual surface is concave.

text:
When this tooth is posed from the incisal aspect so that the line 
of vision is on a line with the long axis of the tooth, more of the 
labial surface may be seen than of the lingual surface.
summary: Visibility of labial surface is greater than lingual surface when viewing tooth from incisal aspect.

text: Mandibular Lateral Incisor
summary: The mandibular lateral incisor is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Figs. 7.13 through 7.21 illustrate the mandibular lateral incisor in 
various aspects. The mandibular lateral incisor is the second man-
dibular tooth from the median line, right or left. It resembles the 
mandibular central incisor so closely that only a brief description 
of each aspect of the lateral incisor is necessary. Direct comparison 
is made with the mandibular central incisor, and the variations 
are mentioned. The two incisors operate in the dental arch as a 
team; therefore their functional form is related. As with the man-
dibular central incisor, the shape of the lateral incisor is uniform 
compared with that of other teeth. Rarely, it will have a labial and 
lingual root division in the cervical third. Somewhat more com-
monly it has two canals in the single root.3
summary: The text describes the mandibular lateral incisor in comparison to the mandibular central incisor, highlighting their functional relationship and variations in root structure.

text:
The mandibular lateral incisor is somewhat larger than the 
mandibular central incisor (compare measurements), but gener-
ally speaking its form closely resembles that of the mandibular 
central incisor (Table 7.2). Ten specimens with uncommon varia-
tions are shown in Fig. 7.21.
summary: The mandibular lateral incisor is larger than the central incisor and closely resembles its form.

text:
Brief Description of the Mandibular Lateral 
Incisor From All Aspects
summary: Overview of the anatomy and characteristics of the mandibular lateral incisor.

text:
Labial and Lingual Aspects
The labial and lingual aspects show the added fraction of 
approximately 1 mm of crown diameter mesiodistally added to 
the distal half (see Figs. 7.13 and 7.14). This, however, is not 
always true (see Fig. 7.19, 3 and 6). The lingual aspect of the
summary: The labial and lingual aspects of dental crowns may have an added fraction of approximately 1 mm mesiodistally, but this is not always the case.

text:
Mesial and Distal Aspects
The mesial side of the crown is often longer than the distal side; 
this causes the incisal ridge, which is straight, to slope downward 
in a distal direction (see Fig. 7.19, 1). The distal contact area is 
more toward the cervical than the mesial contact area to contact 
properly the mesial contact area of the mandibular canine.
summary: The mesial side of the crown is longer than the distal side, causing the incisal ridge to slope downward in a distal direction.

text:
Except for size, no marked difference is evident between 
the mesial and distal surfaces of central and lateral incisors (see 
Figs. 7.15, 7.16, and 7.20). Even the curvatures of the cervical 
line mesially and distally are similar in extent. A tendency exists 
toward a deeper concavity immediately above the cervical line on 
the distal surface of the mandibular lateral incisor.
summary: Mesial and distal surfaces of central and lateral incisors show no marked difference except in size, with similar curvatures of the cervical line, but a deeper concavity above the cervical line on the distal surface of the mandibular lateral incisor.

text:
Although the crown of the mandibular lateral incisor is some-
what longer than that of the central incisor (usually a fraction of 
a millimeter), the root may be considerably longer. Therefore, in 
most instances, the tooth is a little larger in all dimensions. The 
root form is similar to that of the central incisor, including the 
presence of developmental depressions mesially and distally.
summary: The mandibular lateral incisor has a longer root compared to the central incisor, making the tooth slightly larger in all dimensions.

text:
Incisal Aspect
The incisal aspect of the mandibular lateral incisor provides a fea-
ture that can usually serve to identify this tooth. The incisal edge 
is not at approximate right angles to a line bisecting the crown
summary: The incisal aspect of the mandibular lateral incisor provides a unique feature for identification.

text:
The maxillary and mandibular canines bear a close resemblance to 
each other, and their functions are closely related. The four canines 
are placed at the “corners” of the mouth; each one is the third tooth 
from the median line, right and left, in the maxilla and mandible. 
They are commonly referred to as the cornerstones of the dental 
arches.1 They are the longest teeth in the mouth; the crowns are usu-
ally as long as those of the maxillary central incisors, and the single 
roots are longer than those of any of the other teeth. The middle labial 
lobes have been highly developed incisally into strong, well-formed 
cusps. Crowns and roots are markedly convex on most surfaces. The 
shapes and positions of the canines contribute to the guidance of the 
teeth into the intercuspal position by “canine guidance.”2
summary: The maxillary and mandibular canines are the longest teeth in the mouth, positioned at the corners and play a key role in guiding teeth into intercuspal position.

text:
The shape of the crowns—with their single pointed cusps, their 
locations in the mouth, and the extra anchorage furnished by the 
long, strongly developed roots—makes these canines resemble 
those of the carnivore. This resemblance to the prehensile teeth of 
the carnivore gives rise to the term canine.
summary: Canine teeth in humans resemble those of carnivores due to their shape, single pointed cusps, and strong roots.

text:
Because of the labiolingual thickness of crown and root and 
the anchorage in the alveolar process of the jaws, these teeth are 
perhaps the most stable in the mouth. The crown portions of the 
canines are shaped in a manner that promotes cleanliness. This 
self-cleansing quality, along with the efficient anchorage in the 
jaws, tends to preserve these teeth throughout life. When teeth 
are lost, the canines are usually the last to go. They are very valu-
able teeth considered either as units of the natural dental arches 
or as possible assistants in stabilizing replacements of lost teeth in 
prosthetic procedures.
summary: Canines are stable teeth in the mouth due to their thickness, self-cleansing quality, and efficient anchorage, making them valuable for dental arch stability and prosthetic procedures.

text:
Both maxillary and mandibular canines have another qual-
ity that must not be overlooked: the positions and forms 
of these teeth and their anchorage in the bone, along with 
the bone ridge over the labial portions of the roots, called 
the canine eminence, have a cosmetic value. They help 
form a foundation that ensures normal facial expression at 
the corners of the mouth. Loss of all of these teeth makes it 
extremely difficult or impossible to make replacements that 
restore the natural appearance of the face for any length of
summary: Maxillary and mandibular canines play a crucial role in maintaining normal facial expression and cosmetic value.

text:
115
CHAPTER 8  The Permanent Canines: Maxillary and Mandibular
summary: Chapter 8 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent canines in both the maxillary and mandibular arches.

text:
time. It would therefore be difficult to place a value on the 
canines, and their importance is manifested by their efficiency 
in function, stability, and aid in maintaining natural facial 
expression.
summary: Canines play a crucial role in function, stability, and maintaining natural facial expression.

text:
In function, the canines support the incisors and premolars, 
since they are located between these groups. The canine crowns 
have some characteristics of functional form, which bears a resem-
blance to incisor form and also to the premolar form.
summary: Canines support incisors and premolars due to their location between these groups, with crown characteristics resembling both incisors and premolars.

text: Maxillary Canine
summary: The maxillary canine is an important tooth in the dental arch, known for its prominent position and function.

text:
Figs. 8.1 through 8.12 illustrate the maxillary canine in various 
aspects. The outline of the labial or lingual aspect of the maxillary 
canine is a series of curves or arcs except for the angle made by the 
tip of the cusp. This cusp has a mesial incisal ridge and a distal 
incisal ridge.
summary: Illustrations of the maxillary canine show curved outlines with incisal ridges.

text:
The mesial half of the crown makes contact with the lateral 
incisor, and the distal half contacts the first premolar. Therefore 
the contact areas of the maxillary canine are at different levels 
cervicoincisally.
summary: The maxillary canine's contact areas are at different levels cervicoincisally due to its contact with the lateral incisor and first premolar.

text:
From a labial view, the mesial half of the crown resembles 
a portion of an incisor, whereas the distal half resembles a
summary: Description of the labial view of a dental crown comparing the mesial and distal halves to different teeth.

text:
It is apparent that the construction of this tooth has reinforce-

against it when in use. The incisional (incising) portion is thicker

any root with the possible exception of that of the mandibular

text:
canine, which may be as long at times. The root is thick labio-

summary: Description of the anatomy of the canine tooth, including its root structure and secure anchorage in the maxilla.

text:
Detailed Description of the Maxillary Canine 
From All Aspects
summary: This text provides a detailed description of the maxillary canine from all aspects.

text:
Labial Aspect
From the labial aspect, the crown and root are narrower mesio-
distally than the crown and root of the maxillary central incisor. 
The difference is about 1 mm in most mouths. The cervical line 
labially is convex, with the convexity toward the root portion (see 
Figs. 8.2 and 8.7 through 8.9).
summary: The labial aspect of the tooth shows differences in width between the crown and root compared to the maxillary central incisor.

text:
Mesially, the outline of the crown may be convex from the cer-
vix to the center of the mesial contact area, or the crown may 
exhibit a slight concavity above the contact area from the labial 
aspect. The center of the contact area mesially is approximately at 
the junction of middle and incisal thirds of the crown.
summary: Description of the mesial outline of a dental crown and the location of the contact area.

text:
Distally, the outline of the crown is usually concave between 
the cervical line and the distal contact area. The distal contact area 
is usually at the center of the middle third of the crown. The two 
levels of contact areas mesially and distally should be noted (see 
Fig. 5.7B and C).
summary: The crown outline is concave distally between the cervical line and distal contact area, with the distal contact area typically in the middle third of the crown.

text:
Unless the crown has been worn unevenly, the cusp tip is on a 
line with the center of the root. The cusp has a mesial slope and 
a distal slope, the mesial slope being the shorter of the two. Both 
slopes show a tendency toward concavity before wear has taken 
place (see Fig. 8.9, 5 and 6). These depressions are developmental 
in character.
summary: The cusp tip of a tooth is typically aligned with the center of the root, with mesial and distal slopes showing concavity before wear, indicating developmental depressions.

text:
The labial surface of the crown is smooth, with no devel-
opmental lines of note except shallow depressions mesially 
and distally dividing the three labial lobes. The middle labial 
lobe shows much greater development than the other lobes. 
This produces a ridge on the labial surface of the crown. A 
line drawn over the crest of this ridge, from the cervical line 
to the tip of the cusp, is a curved one inclined mesially at its 
center. All areas mesial to the crest of this ridge exhibit convex-
ity except for insignificant developmental lines in the enamel.
summary: Description of the labial surface of the crown with a prominent middle labial lobe and a curved ridge extending from the cervical line to the cusp tip.

text:
120
CHAPTER 8    The Permanent Canines: Maxillary and Mandibular
summary: Chapter 8 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent canines in both the maxillary and mandibular arches.

text:
Distally to the labial ridge (see incisal aspect), a tendency exists 
toward concavity at the cervical third of the crown, although 
convexity is noted elsewhere in all areas approaching the labial 
ridge (see Fig. 8.11, 7 to 9).
summary: The text describes the anatomical features of the crown of a tooth, noting concavity at the cervical third and convexity in other areas.

text:
The root of the maxillary canine appears slender from the labial 
aspect when compared with the bulk of the crown; it is conical 
in form with a bluntly pointed apex. It is not uncommon for 
this root to have a sharp curve in the vicinity of the apical third. 
This curvature may be in a mesial or distal direction, but in most 
instances is the latter (see Fig. 8.9, 1 and 6). The labial surface of 
the root is smooth and convex at all points.
summary: The root of the maxillary canine is slender and conical with a pointed apex, often having a sharp curve near the apical third.

text:
Lingual Aspect
The crown and root are narrower lingually than labially. The cer-
vical line from the lingual aspect differs somewhat from the cur-
vature found labially and shows a more even curvature. The line 
may be straight for a short interval at this point (see Figs. 8.3, 8.7, 
and 8.8).
summary: The lingual aspect of teeth shows narrower crown and root compared to labial aspect, with a more even curvature of the cervical line.

text:
The cingulum is large and, in some instances is pointed, like 
a small cusp (see Fig. 8.10, 7). In this type, definite ridges are 
found on the lingual surface of the crown below the cingulum and 
between strongly developed marginal ridges. Although depres-
sions are to be found between these ridge forms, deep develop-
mental grooves are rarely present.
summary: Description of the cingulum on a tooth, with ridges and marginal ridges present but deep developmental grooves are rare.

text:
Occasionally a well-developed lingual ridge is seen that is con-
fluent with the cusp tip; this extends to a point near the cingulum. 
Shallow concavities are evident between this ridge and the mar-
ginal ridges. When these concavities are present, they are called 
mesial and distal lingual fossae (see Figs. 8.1 and 8.8).
summary: Description of lingual ridge extending to cingulum with mesial and distal lingual fossae.

text:
Sometimes the lingual surface of the canine crown is so smooth 
that fossae or minor ridges are difficult to distinguish. However, 
there is a tendency to see concavities where the fossae are usually 
found, and heavy marginal ridges with a well-formed cingulum 
are to be expected. The smooth cingulum, marginal ridges, and 
lingual portion of the incisal ridges are usually confluent, with 
little evidence of developmental grooves.
summary: Description of the lingual surface of the canine crown with smooth cingulum, marginal ridges, and confluent lingual portion of incisal ridges.

text:
The lingual portion of the root of the maxillary canine is nar-
rower than the labial portion. Because of this formation, much of 
the mesial and distal surface of the root is visible from the lingual 
aspect. Developmental depressions mesially and distally may be 
seen on most of these roots, extending most of the root length. The 
lingual ridge of the root is rather narrow, but it is smooth and con-
vex at all points from the cervical line to the apical end (see Fig. 8.3).
summary: The lingual portion of the root of the maxillary canine is narrower than the labial portion, with visible mesial and distal surfaces and developmental depressions.

text:
Mesial Aspect
The mesial aspect of the maxillary canine presents the outline of 
the functional form of an anterior tooth. However, it generally 
shows greater bulk and a greater labiolingual measurement than 
any of the other anterior teeth (see Figs. 8.4, 8.7, 8.8, and 8.10).
summary: The mesial aspect of the maxillary canine resembles an anterior tooth but has greater bulk and labiolingual measurement.

text:
The outline of the crown is wedge-shaped, the greatest mea-
surement being at the cervical third and the wedge point being 
represented by the tip of the cusp.
summary: The outline of the crown is wedge-shaped with the greatest measurement at the cervical third and the wedge point at the tip of the cusp.

text:
The curvature of the crown below the cervical line labially and 
lingually corresponds in extent to the curvature of the maxillary 
central and lateral incisors. Nevertheless, the crest of that curva-
ture is found at a level more incisal, because the middle labial and 
the lingual lobes are more highly developed (see Fig. 8.10, 5 and 
10). Many canines show a flattened area labially at the cervical 
third of the crown, which appears as a straight outline from the 
mesial aspect. It is questionable just how much wear has to do 
with this effect (see Fig. 8.10, 1 and 2).
summary: The curvature of the canine crown corresponds to the maxillary central and lateral incisors, with some showing a flattened area labially at the cervical third.

text:
Below the cervical third of the crown, the labial face may be 
presented by a line only slightly convex from the crest of curva-
ture at the cervical third to the tip of the cusp. The line usually 
becomes straighter as it approaches the cusp.
summary: Description of the labial face of a tooth below the cervical third, transitioning from slightly convex to straighter as it approaches the cusp.

text:
The entire labial outline from the mesial aspect exhibits more 
convexity from the cervical line to the cusp tip than the maxillary 
central incisor does from cervix to incisal edge.
summary: The labial outline of the tooth exhibits more convexity from the cervical line to the cusp tip compared to the maxillary central incisor.

text:
The lingual outline of the crown from the mesial aspect may 
be represented by a convex line describing the cingulum, which 
convexity straightens out as the middle third is reached, becoming 
convex again in the incisal third (see Fig. 8.10, 10).
summary: Description of the lingual outline of the crown from the mesial aspect with convexity at the cingulum and incisal third.

text: Maxillary Canine
summary: The maxillary canine is an important tooth in the dental arch.

text:
First evidence of calcification
4–5 months
summary: Calcification of teeth begins around 4-5 months of age.

text:
Enamel completed
6–7 years
summary: Enamel formation is completed around the age of 6-7 years.

text:
Eruption
11–12 years
summary: Eruption of permanent teeth typically occurs around 11-12 years of age.

text:
Root completed
13–15 years
summary: Root formation is completed between the ages of 13-15 years.

text:

text:

summary: Dimensions in dentistry refer to the measurements and proportions of various structures.

text:
121
CHAPTER 8  The Permanent Canines: Maxillary and Mandibular
summary: Chapter 8 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent canines in both the maxillary and mandibular arches.

text:
The cervical line that outlines the base of the crown from 
this aspect curves toward the cusp on average by approximately 
2.5 mm at the cementoenamel junction. The outline of the root 
from this aspect is conical, with a tapered or bluntly pointed 
apex. The root may curve labially toward the apical third. The 
labial outline of the root may be almost perpendicular, with 
most of the taper appearing on the lingual side (see Fig. 8.10, 
4 and 9).
summary: Description of the cervical line, root outline, and curvature of the root in dental anatomy.

text:
The position of the tip of the cusp in relation to the long axis of 
the root is different from that of the maxillary central and lateral 
incisors. Although the specimen illustrations in Figs 8.4 and 8.5 
do not show this difference, most specimens in Fig. 8.10 show it 
conclusively. A line bisecting the cusp is labial to a line bisecting 
the root. Lines bisecting the roots of central and lateral incisors 
also bisect the incisal ridges.
summary: The position of the cusp tip in relation to the root axis differs in maxillary central and lateral incisors, as shown in specimen illustrations.

text:
The mesial surface of the canine crown presents convexities at 
all points except for a small circumscribed area above the contact 
area, where the surface is concave and flat between that area and 
the cervical line.
summary: The mesial surface of the canine crown has convexities except for a concave area above the contact area.

text:
The mesial surface of the root appears broad, with a shallow 
developmental depression for part of the root length. Develop-
mental depressions on the heavy roots help anchor the teeth in the 
alveoli and help prevent rotation and displacement.
summary: The mesial surface of the root has a broad appearance with a shallow developmental depression, aiding in anchoring teeth in the alveoli and preventing rotation and displacement.

text:
Distal Aspect
The distal aspect of the maxillary canine shows somewhat the 
same form as the mesial aspect, with the following variations: the 
cervical line exhibits less curvature toward the cusp ridge; the dis-
tal marginal ridge is heavier and more irregular in outline; the 
surface displays more concavity, usually above the contact area; 
and the developmental depression on the distal side of the root is 
more pronounced (see Figs. 8.5, 8.7, and 8.8).
summary: The distal aspect of the maxillary canine differs from the mesial aspect in terms of curvature, marginal ridge, concavity, and developmental depression.

text:
Incisal Aspect
The incisal aspect of the maxillary canine emphasizes the propor-
tions of this tooth mesiodistally and labiolingually (see Figs. 8.6 
through 8.8 and 8.11). In general, the labiolingual dimension is 
greater than the mesiodistal. Occasionally, the two measurements 
are about equal (see Fig. 8.11, 8). Other instances appear in which 
the crown is larger than usual in a labiolingual direction (see Fig. 
8.11, 10).
summary: The incisal aspect of the maxillary canine emphasizes its proportions mesiodistally and labiolingually, with variations in size observed.

text:
From the incisal aspect, if the tooth is correctly posed so that 
the long axis of the root is directly in the line of vision, the tip 
of the cusp is labial to the center of the crown labiolingually and 
mesial to the center mesiodistally.
summary: Proper tooth positioning involves aligning the long axis of the root with the line of vision, with the cusp tip positioned labially and mesially to the center of the crown.

text:
If the tooth were to be sectioned labiolingually beginning at 
the center of the cusp of the crown, the two sections would show 
the root rather evenly bisected, with the mesial portion carrying 
a narrower portion of the crown mesiodistally than that carried 
by the distal section of the tooth. (Note the proportions demon-
strated by the fracture line in the enamel in Fig. 8.11, 9.) Nev-
ertheless the mesial section shows a crown portion with greater 
labiolingual bulk. The crown of this tooth gives the impression of 
having the entire distal portion stretched to make contact with the 
first premolar.
summary: Sectioning a tooth labiolingually reveals differences in crown proportions between mesial and distal sections.

text:
The ridge of the middle labial lobe is very noticeable labially 
from the incisal aspect. It attains its greatest convexity at the cervi-
cal third of the crown, becoming broader and flatter at the middle 
and incisal thirds.
summary: The ridge of the middle labial lobe is most prominent at the cervical third of the crown and becomes broader and flatter towards the middle and incisal thirds.

text:
The cingulum development makes up the cervical third of 
the crown lingually. A shorter arc than the one labially from this
summary: The cingulum development is located on the cervical third of the lingual crown.

text:
aspect may describe the outline of the cingulum. This comparison 
coincides with the relative mesiodistal dimensions of the root lin-
gually and labially.
summary: The text discusses how the aspect may describe the outline of the cingulum based on the relative mesiodistal dimensions of the root lingually and labially.

text:
A line bisecting the cusp and cusp ridges drawn in the mesio-
distal direction is almost always straight and bisects the short arcs 
representative of the mesial and distal contact areas. This fact 
emphasizes the close relation between maxillary canines and some 
lateral incisors, since they resemble each other in this characteristic 
(compare Fig. 8.11, 7 with Fig. 6.18, 1). As mentioned in Chapter 
6, two types of maxillary lateral incisors include ones resembling 
canines from the incisal aspect and others resembling central inci-
sors. The latter are supposed to be in the majority. Naturally the 
lateral incisors that resemble canines are relatively wide labiolin-
gually, and those resembling central incisors are narrow in that 
direction.
summary: The relationship between maxillary canines and some lateral incisors is emphasized by the straight line bisecting the cusp and cusp ridges in the mesio-distal direction.

text:
The incisal aspect of most canines, maxillary or mandibular, 
may be outlined in many cases by a series of arcs. Fig. 8.11, 6, for 
example, could be drawn almost perfectly with the aid of a French 
curve, a drawing instrument used in drafting to draw arcs of vary-
ing degrees.
summary: Canine teeth can be outlined by a series of arcs, which can be drawn using a French curve.

text: Mandibular Canine
summary: The mandibular canine is a vital tooth in the lower jaw responsible for cutting and tearing food.

text:
Figs. 8.13 through 8.24 illustrate the mandibular canine in vari-
ous aspects. Because maxillary and mandibular canines bear a 
close resemblance to each other, direct comparisons are made with 
the maxillary canine in describing the mandibular canine.
summary: Illustrations comparing the mandibular canine to the maxillary canine.

text:
The mandibular canine’s crown is narrower mesiodistally than 
that of the maxillary canine, although it is just as long in most 
instances and in many instances is longer by 0.5 to 1 mm (Table 
8.2). The root may be as long as that of the maxillary canine, but 
usually it is somewhat shorter. The labiolingual diameter of crown 
and root is usually a fraction of a millimeter less.
summary: Comparison of mandibular and maxillary canines in terms of crown and root dimensions.

text:
The lingual surface of the crown is smoother, with less cingu-
lum development and less bulk to the marginal ridges. The lingual 
portion of this crown resembles the form of the lingual surfaces of 
the mandibular lateral incisors.
summary: Description of the lingual surface of a dental crown resembling mandibular lateral incisors.

text:
The cusp of the mandibular canine is not as well developed as 
that of the maxillary canine, and the cusp ridges are thinner labio-
lingually. Usually the cusp tip is on a line with the center of the 
root, from the mesial or distal aspect, but sometimes it lies lingual 
to the line, as with the mandibular incisors.
summary: Comparison of the cusp development between mandibular and maxillary canines.

text: MCR
summary: MCR is a dental abbreviation that stands for Maximum Contact Record.

text:
LR
MMR
summary: LR and MMR are abbreviations commonly used in dentistry to refer to specific teeth.

text: MLF
summary: MLF stands for Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus, a bundle of nerve fibers in the brainstem responsible for coordinating eye movements.

text: C
summary: The letter C is commonly used to represent the speed of light in dental materials.

text: CL
summary: CL

text: DCR
summary: DCR stands for dacryocystorhinostomy, a surgical procedure to treat a blocked tear duct.

text: DMR
summary: DMR stands for Dental Materials Research.

text:
DLF
DCR
C
summary: DLF, DCR, and C are abbreviations likely related to dental materials or orthodontics.

text: MCR
summary: MCR is a dental abbreviation that stands for Maximum Contour of Restoration.
Description of anatomical features of the mandibular right canine from lingual and incisal aspects.

text:
122
CHAPTER 8    The Permanent Canines: Maxillary and Mandibular
summary: Chapter 8 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent canines in both the maxillary and mandibular arches.

text:
A variation in the form of the mandibular canine is bifurcated 
roots. This variation is not rare (see Fig. 8.24, 1, 2, 5, and 6 and 
Fig. 8.25).
summary: Mandibular canines can have bifurcated roots, a common variation.

text:
Detailed Description of the Mandibular Canine 
From All Aspects
summary: This text provides a detailed description of the mandibular canine from all aspects.

text:
Labial Aspect
From the labial aspect, the mesiodistal dimensions of the man-
dibular canine are less than those of the maxillary canine. The dif-
ference is usually about 1 mm. The mandibular canine is broader 
mesiodistally than either of the mandibular incisors, for example, 
about 1 mm wider than the mandibular lateral incisor (see Figs. 
8.14 and 8.19 through 8.21).
summary: The mesiodistal dimensions of the mandibular canine are less than those of the maxillary canine, with a difference of about 1 mm, and it is broader mesiodistally than the mandibular incisors.

text:
The essential differences between mandibular and maxil-
lary canines viewed from the labial aspect may be described as  
follows:
 • The crowns of the mandibular canines appear longer.
summary: Mandibular canines have longer crowns compared to maxillary canines when viewed from the labial aspect.

text:
Sometimes they are longer, but the effect of greater length 
is emphasized by the narrowness of the crown mesio-
distally and the height of the contact areas above the  
cervix.
 • The mesial outline of the crown of the mandibular canine is
summary: The text discusses the impact of crown length, narrowness, and contact areas on the mandibular canine.

text:
almost straight with the mesial outline of the root, with the 
mesial contact area being near the mesioincisal angle.
 • When the cusp ridges have not been affected by wear, the cusp
summary: Description of the alignment of the root and contact area in relation to cusp ridges.

text:
angle is on a line with the center of the root, as on the maxillary 
canine. The mesial cusp ridge is shorter.
summary: The angle of the maxillary canine is on a line with the center of the root, and the mesial cusp ridge is shorter.

text: • Fig. 8.14  Mandibular left canine, labial aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the labial aspect of the mandibular left canine with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text: • Fig. 8.15  Mandibular left canine, lingual aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the lingual aspect of the mandibular left canine with grid measurement of 1 sq. mm.

text: • Fig. 8.16  Mandibular left canine, mesial aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the mesial aspect of the mandibular left canine with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text: • Fig. 8.17  Mandibular left canine, distal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the distal aspect of the mandibular left canine with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text: • Fig. 8.18  Mandibular left canine, incisal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the mandibular left canine from the incisal aspect with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text:
123
CHAPTER 8  The Permanent Canines: Maxillary and Mandibular
summary: Chapter 8 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent canines in both the maxillary and mandibular arches.

text: • The distal contact area of the mandibular canine is more toward
summary: The distal contact area of the mandibular canine is more toward

text:
the incisal aspect than that of the maxillary canine but is not up 
to the level of the mesial area.
 • The cervical line labially has a semicircular curvature apically.
 • Many mandibular canines give the impression from this aspect
summary: Comparison of the incisal aspect of mandibular canines to maxillary canines, noting differences in curvature and level.

text:
of being bent distally on the root base. The maxillary canine 
crowns are more likely to be in line with the root.
 • The mandibular canine root is shorter by l or 2 mm on average
summary: The mandibular canine root is shorter by 1 or 2 mm on average compared to the maxillary canine roots.

text:
than that of the maxillary canine, and its apical end is more 
sharply pointed. Root curvatures are infrequent. When curva-
ture of root ends is present, it is often in a mesial direction (see 
Fig. 8.21, 1 to 4 ).
summary: The mandibular canine has a shorter root compared to the maxillary canine, with a more sharply pointed apical end and infrequent root curvatures, often in a mesial direction.

text:
Lingual Aspect
In comparing the lingual aspect of the mandibular canine with 
that of the maxillary canine, the following differences are noted.
summary: Differences between lingual aspect of mandibular and maxillary canines.

text:
The lingual surface of the crown of the mandibular canine is 
flatter, simulating the lingual surfaces of mandibular incisors (see 
Figs. 8.13, 8.15, 8.19, and 8.20). The cingulum is smooth and 
poorly developed. The marginal ridges are less distinct. This is true 
of the lingual ridge except toward the cusp tip, where it is raised. 
Generally speaking the lingual surface of the crown is smooth and 
regular.
summary: Description of the lingual surface of the crown of the mandibular canine, resembling mandibular incisors with a smooth and regular surface.

text:
The lingual portion of the root is relatively narrower than that 
of the maxillary canine. It narrows down to little more than half 
the width of the labial portion.
summary: The lingual portion of the root of the maxillary canine is relatively narrower than the labial portion.

text:
Mesial Aspect
From the mesial aspect, characteristic differences are evident 
between the two teeth in question. The mandibular canine has less 
curvature labially on the crown, with very little curvature directly 
above the cervical line. The curvature at the cervical portion as a
summary: Differences in curvature between mandibular canine and another tooth from the mesial aspect.

text:
Labial
Lingual
summary: The terms 'Labial' and 'Lingual' refer to the surfaces of teeth facing the lips and tongue, respectively.

text: Incisal
summary: The term 'Incisal' refers to the biting edge of anterior teeth.

text:
Mesial
Distal
• Fig. 8.19  Mandibular right canine. Graph outlines of five aspects are shown. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: The text block describes the mesial and distal aspects of the mandibular right canine with a graph outline.

text:
124
CHAPTER 8    The Permanent Canines: Maxillary and Mandibular
summary: Chapter 8 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent canines in both the maxillary and mandibular arches.

text:
rule is less than 0.5 mm. The lingual outline of the crown is curved 
in the same manner as that of the maxillary canine, but it differs in 
degree (see Figs. 8.16, 8.19, 8.20, and 8.22).
summary: The lingual outline of the crown is curved similar to the maxillary canine but with differences in degree.

text:
The cingulum is not as pronounced, and the incisal portion 
of the crown is thinner labiolingually, which allows the cusp to 
appear more pointed and the cusp ridge to appear more slender. 
The tip of the cusp is more nearly centered over the root, with a 
lingual placement in some cases comparable to the placement of 
incisal ridges on mandibular incisors.
summary: Description of the anatomical features of maxillary incisors compared to mandibular incisors.

text:
The cervical line curves more toward the incisal portion than 
does the cervical line on the maxillary canine.
summary: The cervical line on the mandibular canine curves more toward the incisal portion compared to the maxillary canine.

text:
The roots of the two teeth are quite similar from the mesial 
aspect with the possible exception of a more pointed root tip on 
the mandibular canine. The developmental depression mesially on 
the root of the mandibular canine is more pronounced and some-
times quite deep.
summary: Comparison of root morphology between two teeth, noting differences in root tip and developmental depression.

text:
Distal Aspect
Little difference from the distal aspect can be seen between man-
dibular and maxillary canines except for those features mentioned 
earlier, under “Mesial Aspect,” that are common to both (see Figs. 
8.17, 8.19, and 8.20).
summary: The distal aspect of mandibular and maxillary canines share similar features, with differences mentioned in the mesial aspect.

text:
Incisal Aspect
The outlines of the crowns of mandibular and maxillary canines 
from the incisal aspect are often similar (see Figs. 8.13, 8.18 
through 8.20, and 8.23). The main differences to be noted are as 
follows:
 • The mesiodistal dimension of the mandibular canine is less
summary: Comparison of mandibular and maxillary canines from the incisal aspect reveals similarities and differences.

text:
than the labiolingual dimension. A similarity is evident in this, 
but the outlines of the mesial surface are less curved.
summary: The mesial surface of a tooth has less curved outlines compared to the labiolingual dimension.

text:

text:
The maxillary premolars number four: two in the right maxilla 
and two in the left maxilla. They are posterior to the canines and 
immediately anterior to the molars.
summary: The maxillary premolars consist of four teeth, two in each maxilla, positioned between the canines and molars.

text:
The premolars are so named because they are anterior to the 
molars in the permanent dentition. In zoology, the premolars are 
those teeth that succeed the deciduous molars regardless of the 
number to be succeeded. The term bicuspid, which is widely used 
to describe human teeth, presupposes two cusps, a supposition 
that makes the term misleading, because mandibular premolars in 
the human may show a variation in the number of cusps from one 
to three. Among carnivores, in the study of comparative dental 
anatomy, premolar forms differ so greatly that a more descriptive 
single term than premolar is out of the question. The term pre-
molar is used widely in dental anatomy, human and comparative; 
therefore, it will be used here. However, its use here does not sug-
gest that the term bicuspid should not be used when appropriate.
summary: Premolars in dental anatomy can vary in the number of cusps, with the term 'bicuspid' being commonly used but potentially misleading due to variations in cusps.

text:
The maxillary premolars are developed from the same number of 
lobes as anterior teeth—four. The primary difference in development 
is the well-formed lingual cusp, developed from the lingual lobe, which 
is represented by the cingulum development on incisors and canines. 
The middle buccal lobe on the premolars, corresponding to the middle 
labial lobe of the canines, remains highly developed, with the maxillary 
premolars resembling the canines when viewed from the buccal aspect. 
The buccal cusp of the maxillary first premolar, especially, is long and 
sharp, assisting the canine as a prehensile or tearing tooth. The mandib-
ular first premolar assists the mandibular canine in the same manner.
summary: Maxillary premolars have well-formed lingual cusps and resemble canines when viewed from the buccal aspect.

text:
The second premolars, both maxillary and mandibular, have 
cusps less sharp than the others, and their cusps articulate with 
opposing teeth when the jaws are brought together; this makes 
them more efficient as grinding teeth, and they function much 
like the molars, but to a lesser degree.
summary: Second premolars have less sharp cusps, articulate with opposing teeth, and function as grinding teeth similar to molars.

text:
The maxillary premolar crowns are shorter than those of the 
maxillary canines, and the roots are also shorter. The root lengths 
equal those of the molars. The crowns are a little longer than those 
of the molars.
summary: Comparison of maxillary premolar crowns and roots with canines and molars.

text:
Because of the cusp development buccally and lingually, the 
marginal ridges are in a more horizontal plane and are considered 
part of the occlusal surface of the crown rather than part of the 
lingual surface, as in the case of incisors and canines.
summary: Marginal ridges are considered part of the occlusal surface of the crown due to cusp development buccally and lingually.

text:
When premolars have two roots, one is placed buccally and 
one lingually.
summary: Premolars with two roots have one buccal and one lingual root.

ing, waxing, and/or carving the teeth are good ways to practice 
this.
	4.	 Discuss common anatomic variations seen in each tooth type.
	5.	 List similarities and differences between permanent maxillary
summary: Discussion on the importance of correctly drawing tooth contours and practicing through drawing, waxing, and carving teeth.

summary: The text block mentions the first and second premolars.

text:
129
CHAPTER 9  The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the Permanent Maxillary Premolars.

text: Maxillary First Premolar
summary: The maxillary first premolar is a specific tooth in the upper jaw.

text:
Figs. 9.1 through 9.16 illustrate the maxillary first premolar from 
all aspects. The maxillary first premolar has two cusps, a buccal 
and a lingual, each being sharply defined. The buccal cusp is usu-
ally about 1 mm longer than the lingual cusp. The crown is angu-
lar, and the buccal line angles are prominent.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the maxillary first premolar including the number of cusps, their lengths, and the angular crown shape.

text:
The crown is shorter than that of the canine by 1.5 to 2 mm on 
the average (Table 9.1). Although this tooth resembles the canine 
from the buccal aspect, it differs in that the contact areas mesially 
and distally are at about the same level. The root is shorter. If the 
buccal cusp form has not been changed by wear, the mesial slope 
of the cusp is longer than the distal slope. The opposite arrange-
ment is true of the maxillary canine. In general, the first premolar 
is not as wide in a mesiodistal direction as the canine.
summary: Comparison of the crown and root characteristics of the maxillary first premolar with the canine.

text:
Most maxillary first premolars have two roots (see Fig. 9.10) 
and two pulp canals. When only one root is present, two pulp 
canals are usually found anyway.
summary: Most maxillary first premolars have two roots and two pulp canals, but when only one root is present, two pulp canals are usually found anyway.

text:
The maxillary first premolar has some characteristics common 
to all posterior teeth. Briefly, those characteristics that differentiate 
posterior teeth from anterior teeth are as follows:
summary: Characteristics that differentiate posterior teeth from anterior teeth.

text: 1.	 Greater relative faciolingual measurement compared with the
summary: Discussion on the greater relative faciolingual measurement compared with the

text:
mesiodistal measurement
	2.	 Broader contact areas
	3.	 Contact areas more nearly at the same level
	4.	 Less curvature of the cervical line mesially and distally
	5.	 Shorter crown cervico-occlusally than that of anterior teeth
summary: The mesiodistal measurement of posterior teeth includes broader contact areas, contact areas at the same level, less curvature of the cervical line, and shorter crown cervico-occlusally compared to anterior teeth.
