text:
130
CHAPTER 9    The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent maxillary premolars.

text:
Detailed Description of the Maxillary First 
Premolar From All Aspects
Buccal Aspect
From the buccal aspect, the crown is roughly trapezoidal (see Fig. 
4.16C). The crown exhibits little curvature at the cervical line. The
summary: Description of the buccal aspect of the maxillary first premolar crown with little curvature at the cervical line.

text:
crest of curvature of the cervical line buccally is near the center of 
the root buccally (see Figs. 9.2 and 9.7 through 9.9).
summary: The crest of curvature of the cervical line buccally is near the center of the root buccally.

text:
The mesial outline of the crown is slightly concave from the 
cervical line to the mesial contact area. The contact area is rep-
resented by a relatively broad curvature, the crest of which lies 
immediately occlusal to the halfway point from the cervical line to 
the tip of the buccal cusp.
summary: Description of the mesial outline of the crown in relation to the cervical line and contact area.

text:
The mesial slope of the buccal cusp is rather straight and lon-
ger than the distal slope, which is shorter and more curved. This 
arrangement places the tip of the buccal cusp distal to a line bisect-
ing the buccal surface of the crown. The mesial slope of the buccal 
cusp is sometimes notched; in other instances, a concave outline is 
noted at this point (see Fig. 9.9, 7, 9, and 10).
summary: Description of the mesial and distal slopes of the buccal cusp in dental anatomy.

text:
The distal outline of the crown below the cervical line is 
straighter than that of the mesial, although it may be somewhat 
concave as well. The distal contact area is represented by a broader 
curvature than is found mesially, and the crest of curvature of the 
contact area tends to be a little more occlusal when the tooth is 
• Fig. 9.6  Maxillary left first premolar, occlusal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Description of the distal outline of the crown of a maxillary left first premolar.

text:
Buccal
Lingual
summary: The text block mentions the terms 'Buccal' and 'Lingual'.

text:
Distal
Mesial
summary: Distal and mesial are terms used to describe the sides of teeth in relation to their position in the mouth.

text: Occlusal
summary: The term 'Occlusal' refers to the surface of a tooth that comes into contact with the opposing tooth during chewing or biting.

text: • Fig. 9.7  Maxillary right first premolar. Graph outlines of five aspects are shown. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Graph outlines of five aspects of a maxillary right first premolar are shown with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text:
131
CHAPTER 9  The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the Permanent Maxillary Premolars.

text:
posed with its long axis vertical. Even so, the contact areas are 
more nearly level with each other than those found on anterior 
teeth.
summary: The contact areas on posterior teeth are more nearly level with each other compared to those found on anterior teeth.

text:
The width of the crown of the maxillary first premolar mesio-
distally is about 2 mm less at the cervix than at its width at the 
points of its greatest mesiodistal measurement.
summary: The width of the crown of the maxillary first premolar decreases by 2 mm from the cervix to its greatest mesiodistal measurement.

text:
The buccal cusp is long, coming to a pointed tip and resem-
bling the canine in this respect, although contact areas in this 
tooth are near the same level.
summary: Description of the buccal cusp resembling a canine tooth.

text:
The buccal surface of the crown is convex, showing strong 
development of the middle buccal lobe. The continuous ridge 
from cusp tip to cervical margin on the buccal surface of the 
crown is called the buccal ridge.
summary: Description of the buccal surface of the crown and the buccal ridge.

text:
Mesial and distal to the buccal ridge, at or occlusal to the mid-
dle third, developmental depressions are usually seen that serve as 
demarcations between the middle buccal lobe and the mesiobuccal 
and distobuccal lobes. Although the latter lobes show less devel-
opment, they are nevertheless prominent and serve to emphasize 
strong mesiobuccal and distobuccal line angles on the crown.
summary: Developmental depressions serve as demarcations between buccal lobes and emphasize line angles on the crown.

text:
The roots are 3 or 4 mm shorter than those of the maxillary 
canine, although the outline of the buccal portion of the root form 
bears a close resemblance.
summary: The roots of the mandibular canine are shorter than those of the maxillary canine with a similar buccal root outline.

text:
Lingual Aspect
From the lingual aspect, the gross outline of the maxillary first 
premolar is the reverse of the gross outline from the buccal aspect 
(see Figs. 9.3, 9.7, and 9.8).
summary: The lingual aspect of the maxillary first premolar has a reverse gross outline compared to the buccal aspect.

text:
The crown tapers toward the lingual because the lingual cusp 
is narrower mesiodistally than the buccal cusp. The lingual cusp is 
smooth and spheroidal from the cervical portion to the area near 
the cusp tip. The cusp tip is pointed, with mesial and distal slopes 
meeting at an angle of about 90 degrees.
summary: Description of the morphology of the lingual cusp of a tooth, including its tapering, shape, and pointed tip.

text:
Naturally, the spheroidal form of the lingual portion of the 
crown is convex at all points. Sometimes the crest of the smooth 
lingual portion that terminates at the point of the lingual cusp is 
called the lingual ridge.
summary: The lingual portion of the crown is spheroidal and convex, with the lingual ridge terminating at the lingual cusp.

text:
The mesial and distal outlines of the lingual portion of the 
crown are convex; these outlines are continuous with the mesial
summary: The lingual portion of the crown has convex mesial and distal outlines.

text: Buccal
summary: The term 'buccal' refers to the cheek area in dentistry.

text: Occlusal
summary: The term 'Occlusal' refers to the relationship between the upper and lower teeth when they come together during chewing or biting.

text: Lingual
summary: The lingual surface of a tooth refers to the side that faces the tongue.

text:
Mesial
Distal
• Fig. 9.8  Maxillary right first premolar.
summary: The text block describes the mesial and distal aspects of a maxillary right first premolar.

text:
132
CHAPTER 9    The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the Permanent Maxillary Premolars.

text:
and distal slopes of the lingual cusp and straighten out as they join 
the mesial and distal sides of the lingual root at the cervical line.
summary: Description of the joining of lingual cusps with lingual root at the cervical line.

text:
The cervical line lingually is regular, with slight curvature 
toward the root and the crest of curvature centered on the root. 
Because the lingual portion of the crown is narrower than the buc-
cal portion, it is possible to see part of the mesial and distal sur-
faces of crown and root from the lingual aspect, depending on the 
posing of the tooth and the line of vision.
summary: The cervical line lingually is regular, with slight curvature toward the root and the crest of curvature centered on the root.

text:
Because the lingual cusp is not as long as the buccal cusp, the 
tips of both cusps, with their mesial and distal slopes, may be seen 
from the lingual aspect.
summary: The lingual cusp is shorter than the buccal cusp, allowing both cusps to be visible from the lingual aspect.

text:
The lingual portion of the root, or the lingual portion of the 
lingual root if two roots are present, is smooth and convex at all 
points. The apex of the lingual root of a two-root specimen tends 
to be blunter than the buccal root apex.
summary: The lingual portion of the root is smooth and convex, with the lingual root apex being blunter in two-root specimens.

text:
Mesial Aspect
The mesial aspect of the crown of the maxillary first premolar is 
also roughly trapezoidal (see Figs. 9.1, 9.4, 9.7, 9.8, and 9.10). 
However, the longest of the uneven sides is toward the cervical 
portion, and the shortest is toward the occlusal portion (see Fig. 
4.16E).
summary: The mesial aspect of the crown of the maxillary first premolar is roughly trapezoidal with uneven sides.

text:
Another characteristic that is representative of all posterior 
maxillary teeth is that the tips of the cusps are well within the 
confines of the root trunk. (For a definition of root trunk, see 
Figs. 11.3 and 11.8.) In other words, the measurement from 
the tip of the buccal cusp to the tip of the lingual cusp is less 
than the buccolingual measurement of the root at its cervical 
portion.
summary: Posterior maxillary teeth have cusps that are well within the confines of the root trunk, with the buccolingual measurement of the root at its cervical portion being greater than the distance between the cusps.

text:
Most maxillary first premolars have two roots, one buccal and 
one lingual; these are clearly outlined from the mesial aspect.
summary: Maxillary first premolars typically have two roots, one buccal and one lingual, which can be easily distinguished from the mesial aspect.

text:
The cervical line may be regular in outline (see Fig. 9.10, 1) or 
irregular (see Fig. 9.10, 4). In either case, the curvature occlusally 
is less (about 1 mm on the average) than the cervical curvature on 
the mesial of any of the anterior teeth. The extent of the curvature 
of the cervical line mesially on these teeth is constant within a 
fraction of a millimeter and is similar to the average curvature of 
the mesial of all posterior teeth.
summary: The cervical line of anterior teeth may have a regular or irregular outline with less curvature occlusally compared to the mesial curvature.

text:
From the mesial aspect, the buccal outline of the crown curves 
outward below the cervical line. The crest of curvature is often 
located approximately at the junction of cervical and middle 
thirds; however, the crest of curvature may be located within the 
cervical third (see Fig. 9.10, 1 and 10). From the crest of curva-
ture, the buccal outline continues as a line of less convexity to the
summary: Description of the buccal outline of a dental crown from the mesial aspect.
The text block consists of numbered points.

text:
6
7
8
9
10
• Fig. 9.9  Maxillary first premolar, buccal aspect. Ten typical specimens are shown. (To view Animations 3 
and 4 for tooth #5, please go to Expert Consult.)
summary: Illustration of ten typical specimens of maxillary first premolar on the buccal aspect.

text:
133
CHAPTER 9  The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent maxillary premolars.

text:
tip of the buccal cusp, which is directly below the center of the 
buccal root (when two roots are present).
summary: Description of the location of the tip of the buccal cusp in relation to the buccal root.

text:
The lingual outline of the crown may be described as a smoothly 
curved line starting at the cervical line and ending at the tip of the 
lingual cusp. The crest of this curvature is most often near the 
center of the middle third. Some specimens show a more abrupt 
curvature at the cervical third (see Fig. 9.10, 2 and 9).
summary: Description of the lingual outline of the dental crown with variations in curvature.

text:
The tip of the lingual cusp is on a line, in most cases, with 
the lingual border of the lingual root. The lingual cusp is always 
shorter than the buccal cusp, the average difference being about 1 
mm. This difference, however, may be greater (see Fig. 9.10, 1, 4, 
and 10). From this aspect, it is noted that the cusps of the maxil-
lary first premolar are long and sharp, with the mesial marginal 
ridge at about the level of the junction of the middle and occlusal 
thirds.
summary: The lingual cusp of the maxillary first premolar is shorter than the buccal cusp, with long and sharp cusps and mesial marginal ridge at a specific level.

text:
A distinguishing feature of this tooth is found on the mesial 
surface of the crown. Immediately cervical to the mesial con-
tact area, centered on the mesial surface and bordered buc-
cally and lingually by the mesiobuccal and mesiolingual line 
angles, is a marked depression called the mesial developmen-
tal depression (see Fig. 9.1). This mesial concavity continues 
apically beyond the cervical line, joins a deep developmental 
depression between the roots, and ends at the root bifurcation.
summary: The mesial surface of a tooth features a marked depression known as the mesial developmental depression, extending apically and joining a deep developmental depression between the roots.

text:
On single-root specimens, the concavity on the crown and root 
is also plainly seen, although it may not be as deeply marked. 
Maxillary second premolars do not have this feature (see Fig. 
9.11A and B).
summary: Single-root specimens exhibit concavities on the crown and root, with exceptions in maxillary second premolars.

text:
Another distinguishing feature of the maxillary first premolar 
is a well-defined developmental groove in the enamel of the mesial 
marginal ridge. This groove is in alignment with the developmen-
tal depression on the mesial surface of the root but is not usually 
connected with it. This marginal groove is continuous with the 
central groove of the occlusal surface of the crown, crossing the 
marginal ridge immediately lingual to the mesial contact area and 
terminating a short distance cervical to the mesial marginal ridge 
on the mesial surface (see Fig. 9.10, 10).
summary: The maxillary first premolar has a distinct developmental groove in the enamel of the mesial marginal ridge, connected to the central groove of the occlusal surface.

text:
The buccal outline of the buccal root, above the cervical line, 
is straight, with a tendency toward a lingual inclination. On those 
buccal roots having a buccal inclination above the root bifurca-
tion, the outline may be relatively straight up to the apical portion 
of the buccal root or it may curve buccally at the middle third. 
Buccal roots may take a buccal or lingual inclination, apical to 
middle thirds.
summary: Description of the buccal outline of buccal roots in relation to their inclination and curvature.

text:
The lingual outline of the lingual root is rather straight above the 
cervical line. It may not exhibit much curvature between the cervix 
and the apex. Many cases, however, show considerable curvature to
summary: Description of the lingual outline of the lingual root in dental anatomy.
The text block contains numbered points.

summary: Illustration of the mesial aspect of a maxillary first premolar with ten typical specimens shown.

text:
134
CHAPTER 9    The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent maxillary premolars.

text:
lingual roots apical to the middle thirds. The lingual root may take 
a buccal or lingual inclination (see Fig. 9.10, 1, 2, and 9).
summary: The lingual roots of teeth may have apical positions in relation to the middle thirds, with possible buccal or lingual inclinations.

text:
The root trunk is long on this tooth, making up about half 
of the root length. The bifurcation on those teeth with two roots 
begins at a more occlusal point mesially than distally. Generally 
speaking, when bifurcated, the root is bifurcated for half its total 
length.
summary: Description of root trunk length and bifurcation in teeth with two roots.

text:
Except for the deep developmental groove and depression at or 
below the bifurcation, the mesial surface of the root portion of this 
tooth is smoothly convex buccally and lingually. Even when only 
one root is present, the developmental depression is very notice-
able for most of the root length. In such cases, roots with buccal 
and lingual outlines ending in a blunt apex above the center of the 
crown are seen (see Fig. 9.10, 4 and 5).
summary: The mesial surface of the root portion of a tooth is smoothly convex buccally and lingually, with a noticeable developmental depression and a blunt apex above the center of the crown.

text:
136
CHAPTER 9    The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the Permanent Maxillary Premolars.

text:
Distal Aspect
From the distal aspect (see Figs. 9.5, 9.7, and 9.8), the anatomy of 
the crown and root of the maxillary first premolar differs from that 
from the mesial aspect as follows:
 • The crown surface is convex at all points except for a small,
summary: The anatomy of the crown and root of the maxillary first premolar differs when viewed from the distal aspect.

text:
flattened arc just cervical to the contact area and buccal to the 
center of the distal surface.
 • The curvature of the cervical line is less on the distal than on
summary: Description of the flattened arc just cervical to the contact area and buccal to the center of the distal surface.

text:
the mesial surface, often showing a line straight across from 
buccal to lingual.
summary: Description of the mesial surface with a line straight across from buccal to lingual.

text: • A deep developmental groove crossing the distal marginal ridge
summary: Description of a deep developmental groove crossing the distal marginal ridge.

text:
of the crown is not evident. If a developmental groove should 
be noticeable, it is shallow and insignificant.
 • The root trunk is flattened on the distal surface above the cervi-
summary: Description of the crown and root trunk anatomy with emphasis on developmental groove and shape.

text:
cal line with no outstanding developmental signs.
 • The bifurcation of the roots is abrupt near the apical third, with
summary: Description of the root bifurcation near the apical third with no outstanding developmental signs.

text:
no developmental groove leading to it, such as that found mesi-
ally.
summary: The text discusses the absence of a developmental groove leading mesially.

text:
Occlusal Aspect
The occlusal aspect of the maxillary first premolar resembles 
roughly a six-sided or hexagonal figure (see Figs. 9.7, 9.8, 9.12, 
and 9.14). The six sides are made up of the mesiobuccal, which is 
mesial to the buccal ridge; mesial; mesiolingual, which is mesial 
to the lingual ridge; distolingual; distal; and distobuccal. This hex-
agonal figure, however, is not equilateral. The two buccal sides are 
nearly equal, the mesial side is shorter than the distal side, and 
the mesiolingual side is shorter than the distolingual side (see Fig. 
9.14).
summary: The occlusal aspect of the maxillary first premolar resembles a hexagonal figure with unequal sides.

text:
The relation and position of various anatomical points are to 
be considered from the occlusal aspect. A drawing of the outline 
of this occlusal aspect, when placed within a rectangle, the dimen-
sions of which represent the mesiodistal and buccolingual width 
of the crown, demonstrates the relative positions of the mesial and 
distal contact areas and also those of the buccal and lingual ridges 
(see Figs. 9.6 and 9.15).
summary: Anatomical points and their positions are important from the occlusal aspect, demonstrated through drawings within a rectangle representing crown dimensions.

text:
The crest of the distal contact area is somewhat buccal to that 
of the mesial contact area, and the crest of the buccal ridge is 
somewhat distal to that of the lingual ridge. The crests of curva-
ture represent the highest points on the buccal and lingual ridges 
and the mesial and distal contact areas.
summary: The crests of curvature in dental anatomy represent the highest points on the buccal and lingual ridges and the mesial and distal contact areas.

text:
Close observation of the crown from this aspect reveals the fol-
lowing characteristics (see Fig. 9.15):
summary: Close observation of the crown reveals specific characteristics as shown in Figure 9.15.

text:
137
CHAPTER 9  The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent maxillary premolars.

text: 1.	 The distance from the buccal crest (A in Fig. 9.15) to the mesial
summary: The text discusses the distance from the buccal crest to the mesial aspect.

text:
crest (C) is slightly longer than the distance from the buccal 
crest to the distal crest (D).
	2.	 The distance from the mesial crest to the lingual crest is much
summary: Description of the distances between different dental crests.

text:
shorter than the distance from the distal crest to the lingual 
crest.
	3.	 The crown is wider on the buccal than on the lingual.
	4.	 The buccolingual dimension of the crown is much greater than
summary: Description of crown dimensions in relation to buccal and lingual sides.

text:
the mesiodistal dimension.
The occlusal surface of the maxillary first premolar is cir-
cumscribed by the cusp ridges and marginal ridges. The mesio-
buccal and distobuccal cusp ridges are in line with each other, 
and their alignment is in a distobuccal direction. In other 
words, even though they are in the same alignment, the disto-
buccal cusp ridge is buccal to the mesiobuccal cusp ridge (see 
Fig. 9.16).
summary: The occlusal surface of the maxillary first premolar is defined by cusp ridges and marginal ridges, with the mesiobuccal and distobuccal cusp ridges aligned in a distobuccal direction.

text:
The angle formed by the convergence of the mesiobuccal cusp 
ridge and the mesial marginal ridge approaches a right angle. The 
angle formed by the convergence of the distobuccal cusp ridge and 
the distal marginal ridge is acute. The mesiolingual and distolin-
gual cusp ridges are confluent with the mesial and distal marginal 
ridges; these cusp ridges are curved, following a semicircular out-
line from the marginal ridges to their convergence at the tip of the 
lingual cusp.
summary: Description of the angles and ridges in the occlusal surface of a tooth.

text:
When one looks at the occlusal aspect of the maxillary first 
premolar, posing the tooth so that the line of vision is in line with 
the long axis, more of the buccal surface of the crown is seen than 
of the lingual surface. When the tooth is viewed from the mesial 
aspect, the tip of the buccal cusp is nearer the center of the root 
trunk than is the lingual cusp.
summary: Description of the occlusal aspect of the maxillary first premolar and the positioning of the tooth for better visibility of the buccal surface.

text:
The occlusal surface of this tooth has no supplemental 
grooves in most cases, a fact that makes the surface relatively 
smooth. A well-defined central developmental groove divides 
the surface evenly buccolingually. It is located at the bottom 
of the central sulcus of the occlusal surface, extending from 
a point just mesial to the distal marginal ridge to the mesial 
marginal ridge, where it joins the mesial marginal devel-
opment groove. This latter groove crosses the mesial mar-
ginal ridge and ends on the mesial surface of the crown (see  
Figs. 9.1 and 9.4).
summary: The occlusal surface of a tooth typically lacks supplemental grooves, with a central developmental groove dividing the surface buccolingually.

text:
Two collateral developmental grooves join the central groove 
just inside the mesial and distal marginal ridges. These grooves 
are called the mesiobuccal developmental groove and the disto-
buccal developmental groove. The junctions of the grooves are 
deeply pointed and are named the mesial and distal developmen-
tal pits.
summary: Description of mesiobuccal and distobuccal developmental grooves and pits in dental anatomy.

text:
Just distal to the mesial marginal ridge, the triangular depres-
sion that harbors the mesiobuccal developmental groove is called 
the mesial triangular fossa. The depression in the occlusal sur-
face, just mesial to the distal marginal ridge, is called the distal 
triangular fossa.
summary: Description of mesial triangular fossa and distal triangular fossa on the occlusal surface of teeth.

text:
Although no supplemental grooves are present in most 
instances, smooth developmental depressions may be visible radi-
ating from the central groove and giving the occlusal surface an 
uneven appearance.
summary: Smooth developmental depressions may be visible radiating from the central groove on the occlusal surface.

text:
The buccal triangular ridge of the buccal cusp is prom-
inent, arising near the center of the central groove and 
converging with the tip of the buccal cusp. The lingual tri-
angular ridge is less prominent; it also arises near the center 
of the central groove and converges with the tip of the lingual  
cusp.
summary: Description of the buccal and lingual triangular ridges in relation to the buccal and lingual cusps.

text: The lingual cusp is pointed more sharply than the buccal cusp.
summary: The lingual cusp is sharper than the buccal cusp.

text: Maxillary Second Premolar
summary: The maxillary second premolar is a specific tooth in the upper jaw.

text:
Figs. 9.17 through 9.25 illustrate the maxillary second premolar 
from all aspects. The maxillary second premolar supplements the 
maxillary first premolar in function. The two teeth resemble each 
other so closely that only a brief description of each aspect of the 
second premolar is necessary. Direct comparison is made between 
it and the first premolar, and variations are mentioned.
summary: Illustrations and comparison of the maxillary second premolar to the first premolar.

text: • Fig. 9.17  Maxillary left second premolar, buccal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the buccal aspect of a maxillary left second premolar with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text: • Fig. 9.18  Maxillary left second premolar, lingual aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the lingual aspect of a maxillary left second premolar with a grid size of 1 square millimeter.

text: • Fig. 9.19  Maxillary left second premolar, mesial aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the mesial aspect of a maxillary left second premolar with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text:
138
CHAPTER 9    The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 focuses on the anatomy and characteristics of the Permanent Maxillary Premolars.

text:
The maxillary second premolar is less angular, giving a more 
rounded effect to the crown from all aspects. It has a single root.
summary: The maxillary second premolar has a rounded crown and a single root.

text:
Considerable variations in the relative sizes of the two teeth 
may be seen, because the second premolar does not appear true to 
form as often as does the first premolar (Table 9.2). The maxillary
summary: Variations in the relative sizes of premolars may be seen, with the second premolar less true to form than the first premolar.

text:
second premolar may have a crown that is noticeably smaller 
cervico-occlusally and also mesiodistally; however, it may also be 
larger in those dimensions. Usually, the root of the second pre-
molar is as long as, if not a millimeter or so longer than, that of 
the first premolar. The two teeth have about the same dimensions 
on average, except for a tendency toward a greater length of the 
second premolar root. Ten specimens with uncommon variations 
are shown in Fig. 9.25.
summary: The second premolar can vary in size compared to the first premolar, with the root of the second premolar typically being longer.

text:
• Fig. 9.20  Maxillary left second premolar, distal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
• Fig. 9.21  Maxillary left second premolar, occlusal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Illustrations of maxillary left second premolar from distal and occlusal aspects with grid measurements of 1 sq. mm.
The text block contains numbered points.

text:
6
7
8
9
10
• Fig. 9.22  Maxillary second premolar, buccal aspect. Ten typical specimens are shown. (To view Anima-
tions 3 and 4 for tooth #4, please go to Expert Consult.)
summary: Illustration of ten typical specimens of maxillary second premolar on the buccal aspect.

text:
139
CHAPTER 9  The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the Permanent Maxillary Premolars.

text:
Detailed Description of the Maxillary Second 
Premolar From All Aspects
summary: This text provides a detailed description of the maxillary second premolar from all aspects.

text:
Buccal Aspect
From the buccal aspect, it may be noticed that the buccal cusp of 
the second premolar is not as long as that of the first premolar and 
it appears less pointed (see Fig. 9.17). Also, the mesial slope of 
the buccal cusp ridge is usually shorter than the distal slope. The 
opposite is true of the first premolar.
summary: Comparison of buccal cusps between first and second premolars.

text:
In many instances, the crown and root of the second premolar 
are thicker at their cervical portions. This is not the rule, however 
(see Fig. 9.22, 5, 6, 7, and 9). The buccal ridge of the crown may 
not be as prominent as that of the first premolar.
summary: Variability in thickness of crown and root of second premolar, with buccal ridge differences compared to first premolar.

text:
Lingual Aspect
From the lingual aspect, little variation may be seen except that 
the lingual cusp is longer, which makes the crown longer on the 
lingual side (see Fig. 9.18).
summary: The lingual aspect of a tooth typically shows little variation, with the lingual cusp being longer and resulting in a longer crown on that side.

text:
Mesial Aspect
The mesial aspect shows the difference in cusp length between the 
first and second premolars (see Figs. 9.4 and 9.19). The cusps of
summary: The mesial aspect of premolars shows differences in cusp length between first and second premolars.

text:
the second premolar are shorter, with the buccal and lingual cusps 
more nearly the same length. Greater distance between cusp tips 
widens the occlusal surface buccolingually.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the second premolar emphasizing the shorter length and alignment of the buccal and lingual cusps.

text:
No developmental depression is evident on the mesial surface 
of the crown as on the first premolar; the crown surface is convex 
instead. A shallow developmental groove appears on the single 
tapered root.
summary: The mesial surface of the crown lacks developmental depression seen in the first premolar, with a convex surface and a shallow developmental groove on the tapered root.

text:
No deep developmental groove crossing the mesial marginal 
ridge is evident, and except for the variation in root form, no out-
standing variation is noted when viewed from the distal aspect.
summary: Absence of deep developmental groove crossing the mesial marginal ridge, with no significant variation noted in root form when viewed from the distal aspect.

text:
Distal Aspect
The distal root depression is deeper than the mesial depression 
on the maxillary second premolar. This characteristic of the distal 
root surface is the opposite of that of the maxillary first premolar, 
in which the depression is on the mesial surface of the root. A 
knowledge of where these depressions are facilitates periodontal 
instrumentation—that is, scaling and root planing.
summary: The distal root depression on the maxillary second premolar is deeper than the mesial depression, aiding in periodontal instrumentation.

text:
Occlusal Aspect
From the occlusal aspect, some differences are to be noted between 
the two premolars. On the second premolar, the outline of the
summary: Differences between two premolars from the occlusal aspect are noted.
The text block contains a numbered list.

Crown very broad mesiodistally; root dwarfed. 5, Root extremely long. 6, Root dwarfed and very pointed at

text:
141
CHAPTER 9  The Permanent Maxillary Premolars
summary: Chapter 9 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent maxillary premolars.

text:
crown is more rounded or oval, rather than angular (see Figs. 9.21 
and 9.24). There are, of course, exceptions. The central develop-
mental groove is shorter and more irregular, and there is a ten-
dency toward multiple supplementary grooves radiating from the 
central groove. These supplementary grooves terminate in shallow 
depressions in the enamel that may extend out to the cusp ridges. 
(To view Animations 3 and 4, please go to Expert Consult.)
summary: Description of the crown anatomy with rounded or oval shape, exceptions, central developmental groove, and supplementary grooves terminating in shallow depressions.

text:
This arrangement makes for an irregular occlusal surface and 
gives the surface a very wrinkled appearance.
summary: The irregular occlusal surface of teeth gives them a wrinkled appearance.

summary: Pretest questions to assess knowledge before studying dental topics.

text:
1.	 Which of the following teeth is most likely to have three cusps?
	
A.	 Maxillary second premolar
	
B.	 Mandibular second premolar
	
C.	 Mandibular first premolar
	
D.	Maxillary first premolar
	2.	 What is the length of the root of the mandibular first premolar?
	
A.	 14 mm
	
B.	 15 mm
	
C.	 16 mm
	
D.	17 mm
	3.	 Which of the following is a characteristic often seen from the
summary: Multiple choice questions about tooth cusps, root length, and tooth characteristics.

text:

A.	 A well-developed lingual lobe
	
B.	 A tall lingual cusp
	
C.	 A wide root surface
	
D.	Mesiolingual developmental groove
	4.	 When comparing the mandibular first and second premolar
summary: The text block discusses the lingual aspect of the mandibular first premolar and its characteristics.

text:
from a mesial view, which of the following is false regarding the 
second premolar?
	
A.	 The crown and root are wider buccolingually.
	
B.	 Less of the occlusal surface may be seen.
	
C.	 There is a longer root.
	
D.	The buccal cusp is longer and centered over the root trunk.
	5.	 In a three-cusped mandibular premolar, which of the following
summary: The false statement regarding the second premolar from a mesial view is that the buccal cusp is longer and centered over the root trunk.

A.	 Buccal, mesiolingual, distolingual

D.	All are about the same size
For additional study resources, please visit Expert Consult.

text:
The mandibular premolars number four: two are situated in the 
right side of the mandible and two in the left side. They are immedi-
ately posterior to the mandibular canines and anterior to the molars.
summary: The text describes the location and number of mandibular premolars in relation to other teeth.

text:
The mandibular first premolars are developed from four lobes, 
as were the maxillary premolars. The mandibular second premo-
lars are, in most instances, developed from five lobes—three buc-
cal and two lingual lobes.
summary: Mandibular first premolars are developed from four lobes, while mandibular second premolars are developed from five lobes.

text:
The first premolar has a large buccal cusp, which is long and 
well formed, with a small, nonfunctioning lingual cusp that in 
some specimens is no longer than the cingulum found on some 
maxillary canines (see Fig. 10.10, 3 and 8, and Fig. 10.12, 4 
and 7). The second premolar has three well-formed cusps in 
most cases, one large buccal cusp and two smaller lingual cusps. 
The form of both mandibular premolars fails to conform to the 
implications of the term bicuspid, a term that implies two func-
tioning cusps.
summary: Mandibular premolars have large buccal cusps and small lingual cusps, not conforming to the term bicuspid.

text:
The mandibular first premolar has many of the characteristics 
of a small canine, because its sharp buccal cusp is the only part 
of it occluding with maxillary teeth. It functions along with the 
mandibular canine. The mandibular second premolar has more 
of the characteristics of a small molar, because its lingual cusps 
are well developed, a fact that places both marginal ridges high 
and produces a more efficient occlusion with antagonists in the 
opposite jaw. The mandibular second molar functions by being 
supplementary to the mandibular first molar.
summary: Description of the characteristics and functions of mandibular premolars and molars in relation to occlusion with maxillary teeth and antagonists in the opposite jaw.

text:
The first premolar is always the smaller of the two mandibular 
premolars, whereas the opposite is true, in many cases, of the max-
illary premolars.
summary: The first premolar is smaller in the mandible, while in many cases, the maxillary premolars are larger.

text: Mandibular First Premolar
summary: The mandibular first premolar is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Figs. 10.1 through 10.12 illustrate the mandibular first premolar 
from all aspects. The mandibular first premolar is the fourth tooth 
from the median line and the first posterior tooth in the mandible. 
This tooth is situated between the canine and second premolar 
and has some characteristics common to each of them.
summary: Illustrations of the mandibular first premolar from various angles and its position in the dental arch.

text:
The characteristics that resemble those of the mandibular 
canine are as follows:
	1.	 The buccal cusp is long and sharp and is the only occluding
summary: Comparison of characteristics between mandibular canine and other teeth.

text:
cusp.
	2.	 The buccolingual measurement is similar to that of the canine.
	3.	 The occlusal surface slopes sharply lingually in a cervical direc-
summary: The text describes the buccolingual measurement and occlusal surface slope of a cusp.

text:
tion.
	4.	 The mesiobuccal cusp ridge is shorter than the distobuccal cusp
summary: The mesiobuccal cusp ridge is shorter than the distobuccal cusp.

text: ridge.
summary: The term 'ridge' refers to the bony ridge in the mouth, often used in dental anatomy.

dibular first and second premolars.
	3.	 Discuss the grid diagrams of the permanent mandibular

• Fig. 10.2  Mandibular right first premolar, buccal aspect. The speci-

the roots of these teeth will curve, if at all, in a distal direction. (Grid =

text:
144
CHAPTER 10    The Permanent Mandibular Premolars
summary: Chapter 10 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent mandibular premolars.

text:
Although the root of the mandibular first premolar is shorter 
generally than that of the mandibular second premolar, it is closer 
to the length of the second premolar root than it is to that of the 
mandibular canine (Table 10.1).
summary: Comparison of root length in mandibular first premolar, second premolar, and canine.

text:
Detailed Description of the Mandibular First 
Premolar From All Aspects
summary: This text provides a detailed description of the mandibular first premolar from all aspects.

text:
Buccal Aspect
From the buccal aspect, the form of the mandibular first 
premolar crown is nearly symmetrical bilaterally (see Figs. 
10.2 and 10.7 through 10.9). The middle buccal lobe is 
well developed, which results in a large, pointed buccal 
cusp. The mesial cusp ridge is shorter than the distal cusp  
ridge.
summary: The buccal aspect of the mandibular first premolar crown is nearly symmetrical bilaterally with a well-developed middle buccal lobe and a large, pointed buccal cusp.

text:
The contact areas are broad from this aspect; they are almost 
at the same level mesially and distally, this level being a little 
more than half the distance from cervical line to cusp tip. The
summary: The contact areas in teeth are broad and almost at the same level mesially and distally, located slightly more than half the distance from the cervical line to the cusp tip.

text:
measurement mesiodistally at the cervical line is small compared 
with the measurement at the contact areas.
summary: The mesiodistal measurement at the cervical line is smaller than at the contact areas.

text:
From the buccal aspect, the crown is roughly trapezoidal (see 
Fig. 4.16C). The cervical margin is represented by the shortest of 
the uneven sides.
summary: The crown of the tooth is roughly trapezoidal with the cervical margin represented by the shortest side.

text:
The crown exhibits little curvature at the cervical line buccally, 
because of the slight curvature of the cervical line on the mesial 
and distal surfaces of the tooth. The crest of curvature of the cervi-
cal line buccally approaches the center of the root buccally.
summary: The crown exhibits little curvature at the cervical line buccally due to slight curvature on the mesial and distal surfaces of the tooth.

text:
The mesial outline of the crown is straight or slightly concave 
above the cervical line to a point where it joins the curvature of 
the mesial contact area. The center of the contact area mesially is 
occlusal to the cervical line, a distance equal to a little more than 
half the crown length. The outline of the mesial slope of the buc-
cal cusp usually shows some concavity unless wear has obliterated 
the original form.
summary: Description of the mesial outline of the dental crown and contact area.

text:
The tip of the buccal cusp is pointed and, in most cases, is 
located a little mesial to the center of the crown buccally (see
summary: Description of the location and shape of the buccal cusp tip on a tooth crown.

text:
Buccal
Lingual
summary: The text block mentions the terms 'Buccal' and 'Lingual'.

text:
Distal
Mesial
summary: Distal and mesial are terms used to describe the location of teeth in relation to each other.

text: Occlusal
summary: The term 'occlusal' refers to the surface of a tooth that comes into contact with the opposing teeth during chewing or biting.

text: • Fig. 10.7  Mandibular right first premolar. Graph outlines of five aspects are shown. (Grid = 1 sq. mm.)
summary: Graph outlines of five aspects of a mandibular right first premolar are shown with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text:
145
CHAPTER 10  The Permanent Mandibular Premolars
summary: Chapter 10 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent mandibular premolars.

text:
Fig. 10.9, 3, 7, 8, and 9). The mandibular canine has the same 
characteristic to a greater degree.
summary: The mandibular canine shares similar characteristics with other teeth.

text:
The distal outline of the crown is slightly concave above the 
cervical line to a point where it is confluent with the curvature 
describing the distal contact area. This curvature is broader than 
that describing the curvature of the mesial contact area. The distal 
slope of the buccal cusp usually exhibits some concavity.
summary: Description of the distal outline of the crown and buccal cusp in dental anatomy.

text:
The cervix of the mandibular first premolar crown is narrow 
mesiodistally when compared with the crown width at the contact 
areas.
summary: The cervix of the mandibular first premolar crown is narrow mesiodistally compared to the crown width at the contact areas.

text:
The root of this tooth is 3 or 4 mm shorter than that of the 
mandibular canine, although the outline of the buccal portion of 
the root bears a close resemblance to that of the canine.
summary: The root of the tooth discussed is shorter than the mandibular canine, with a similar outline in the buccal portion.

text:
The buccal surface of the crown is more convex than in the 
maxillary premolars, especially at the cervical and middle thirds.
summary: The buccal surface of the crown in maxillary premolars is more convex at the cervical and middle thirds.

text:
The development of the middle buccal lobe is outstanding, 
ending in a pointed buccal cusp. Developmental depressions are 
often seen between the three lobes (see Fig. 10.9, 2, 3, 8, and 10).
summary: The text discusses the development of the middle buccal lobe in dental anatomy.

text:
The continuous ridge from the cervical margin to the cusp tip 
is called the buccal ridge.
summary: The continuous ridge from the cervical margin to the cusp tip is called the buccal ridge.

text:
In general, the enamel of the buccal surface of the crown is 
smooth and shows no developmental grooves and few develop-
mental lines. If the latter are present, they are seen as very fine 
horizontal cross lines at the cervical portion.
summary: Description of the enamel on the buccal surface of the crown with few developmental lines.

text:
Lingual Aspect
The crown of the mandibular first premolar tapers toward the lin-
gual, since the lingual measurement mesiodistally is less than that 
buccally. The lingual cusp is always small (see Figs. 10.3, 10.7, and 
10.8). The major portion of the crown is made up of the middle 
buccal lobe (see Fig. 10.11). This makes it resemble the canine.
summary: The lingual aspect of the mandibular first premolar shows a smaller lingual measurement compared to the buccal side, with a small lingual cusp and a crown resembling a canine.

text:
The crown and the root taper markedly toward the lingual so 
that most of the mesial and distal surfaces of both may be seen 
from the lingual aspect.
summary: The crown and root of teeth taper towards the lingual aspect allowing visibility of mesial and distal surfaces.

text:
The occlusal surface slopes greatly toward the lingual in a cervi-
cal direction down to the short lingual cusp. Most of the occlusal 
surface of this tooth can therefore be seen from this aspect.
summary: The occlusal surface of the tooth slopes towards the lingual in a cervical direction down to the short lingual cusp, allowing most of it to be visible from this aspect.

text:
The cervical portion of the crown lingually is narrow and con-
vex, with concavities in evidence between the cervical line and the 
contact areas on the lingual portion of mesial and distal surfaces.
summary: Description of the narrow and convex cervical portion of the crown with concavities between the cervical line and contact areas on lingual surfaces.

text:
Buccal
Lingual
summary: The terms 'buccal' and 'lingual' refer to the sides of teeth facing the cheek and tongue, respectively.

text: Mesial
summary: Mesial refers to the side of a tooth that is closest to the midline of the dental arch.

text: Occlusal
summary: The term 'Occlusal' refers to the relationship between the upper and lower teeth when they come together during chewing or biting.

text:
Distal
• Fig. 10.8  Mandibular right first premolar.
summary: The text block describes the distal aspect of the mandibular right first premolar.

text:
6
7
8
9
10
• Fig. 10.12  Mandibular first premolar. Ten specimens with uncommon variations are shown. 1, Crown 
oversized. 2, Crown and root diminutive. 3, Mesial and distal sides of crown straight; cervix wide mesio-
distally; root extra long. 4, Unusual formation of lingual portion of crown; root with deep developmental 
groove mesially. 5, Bifurcated root. 6, Lingual cusp long; little lingual curvature; root of extra length. 7, No 
lingual cusp; root bifurcated. 8, Dwarfed root. 9, Crown poorly formed; root unusually long. 10, Very long 
curved root for crown so small.
summary: Variations in mandibular first premolar anatomy including oversized crown, diminutive crown and root, straight sides with wide cervix, lingual portion abnormalities, bifurcated root, and long curved roots.

text:
148
CHAPTER 10    The Permanent Mandibular Premolars
summary: Chapter 10 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent mandibular premolars.

text:
The contact areas and marginal ridges are pronounced and extend 
out above the narrow cervical portion of the crown.
summary: The contact areas and marginal ridges are pronounced and extend above the narrow cervical portion of the crown.

text:
Although the lingual cusp is short and less developed (resem-
bling a strongly developed cingulum at times), it usually shows a 
pointed tip. This cusp tip is in alignment with the buccal triangu-
lar ridge of the occlusal surface, which is in plain view. The mesial 
and distal occlusal fossae are on each side of the triangular ridge 
(see Fig. 10.1).
summary: Description of the lingual cusp alignment with the buccal triangular ridge on the occlusal surface.

text:
A characteristic of the lingual surface of the mandibular first 
premolar is the mesiolingual developmental groove. This groove 
acts as a line of demarcation between the mesiobuccal lobe and 
the lingual lobe and extends into the mesial fossa of the occlusal 
surface.
summary: The lingual surface of the mandibular first premolar has a mesiolingual developmental groove that separates lobes and extends into the mesial fossa.

text:
The root of this tooth is much narrower on the lingual side, 
and there is a narrow ridge, smooth and convex, the full length 
of the root. This formation allows most of the mesial and distal 
surfaces of the root to be seen. Often, developmental depressions 
in the root may be seen with developmental grooves mesially. 
The root of this tooth tapers evenly from the cervix to a pointed 
apex.
summary: Description of the root anatomy of a tooth, including its narrowness on the lingual side, smooth convex ridge, developmental depressions, and even tapering to a pointed apex.

text:
Mesial Aspect
From the mesial aspect (see Figs. 10.4, 10.7, 10.8, and 10.10), the 
mandibular first premolar shows an outline that is fundamental 
and characteristic of all mandibular posterior teeth when viewed 
from the mesial or distal aspect. The crown outline is roughly 
rhomboidal (see Fig. 4.16E), and the tip of the buccal cusp is 
nearly centered over the root. The convexity of the outline of the 
lingual lobe is lingual to the outline of the root. The surface of 
the crown presents an overhang above the root trunk in a lingual 
direction. The tip of the cusp is on a line approximately with the 
lingual border of the root. This differs from the situation found in 
maxillary posterior teeth, where both buccal and lingual cusp tips 
are well within the confines of the root trunks.
summary: The mesial aspect of the mandibular first premolar shows a rhomboidal crown outline with the buccal cusp tip centered over the root and lingual lobe convexity lingual to the root outline.

text:
The mandibular first premolar, when viewed from the mesial aspect, 
often shows the buccal cusp centered over the root (see Fig. 10.4). In 
other instances, the buccal cusp tip is a little buccal to the center, cor-
responding to the typical placement of buccal cusps on all mandibular 
posterior teeth.
summary: The mandibular first premolar may have the buccal cusp centered over the root or slightly buccal to the center.

text:
The buccal outline of the crown from this aspect is promi-
nently curved from the cervical line to the tip of the buccal cusp; 
the crest of the curvature is near the middle third of the crown. 
This accented convexity and the location of the crest of contour 
are characteristic of all mandibular posterior teeth on the buccal 
surfaces.
summary: The buccal outline of mandibular posterior teeth is prominently curved from the cervical line to the tip of the buccal cusp, with the crest of the curvature near the middle third of the crown.

text:
The lingual outline of the crown, representative of the lingual 
outline of the lingual cusp, is a curved outline of less convexity 
than that of the buccal surface. The crest of curvature lingually 
approaches the middle third of the crown, with the curvature end-
ing at the tip of the lingual cusp, which is in line with the lingual 
border of the root.
summary: Description of the lingual outline of the crown and lingual cusp in relation to the buccal surface and root border.

text:
The distance from the cervical line lingually to the tip of the 
lingual cusp is about two thirds of that from the cervical line buc-
cally to the tip of the buccal cusp.
summary: The distance from the cervical line to the lingual cusp is about two thirds of the distance to the buccal cusp.

text:
The mesiobuccal lobe development is prominent from this 
aspect; it creates by its form the mesial contact area and the mesial 
marginal ridge, which in turn has a sharp inclination lingually 
in a cervical direction. The lingual border of the mesial marginal 
ridge merges with the developmental depression mesiolingually; 
this harbors the mesiolingual developmental groove.
summary: The mesiobuccal lobe development contributes to the formation of the mesial contact area and mesial marginal ridge, with a lingual inclination and merging with the mesiolingual developmental groove.

text:
Some of the occlusal surface of the crown mesially may be seen 
with the mesial portion of the buccal triangular ridge. The slope 
of this ridge parallels that of the mesial marginal ridge, although 
the crest of the triangular ridge is above it. The sulcus formed by 
the convergence of buccal and lingual triangular ridges is directly 
above the mesiolingual groove from this aspect.
summary: Description of the occlusal surface of the crown and triangular ridges.

text:
The cervical line on the mesial surface is rather regular, curving 
occlusally. The crest of the curvature is centered buccolingually,
summary: Description of the regular curving cervical line on the mesial surface with a centered buccolingual crest.

text: Mandibular First Premolar
summary: The mandibular first premolar is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
First evidence of calcification
1¾–2 years
summary: The first evidence of calcification in teeth typically occurs between 1¾ to 2 years of age.

text:
Enamel completed
5–6 years
summary: Enamel formation is completed around 5-6 years of age.

text:
Eruption
10–12 years
summary: Eruption of permanent teeth typically occurs around 10-12 years of age.

text:
Root completed
12–13 years
summary: Root development in teeth is typically completed around 12-13 years of age.

text:
149
CHAPTER 10  The Permanent Mandibular Premolars
summary: Chapter 10 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent mandibular premolars.

text:
the average curvature being about 1 mm in extent. It may, how-
ever, be a fraction of a millimeter, or the line may be straight across 
buccolingually.
summary: The average curvature of the line in dental anatomy is about 1 mm, but it can vary in extent or be straight across buccolingually.

text:
The surface of the crown mesially is smooth except for the 
mesiolingual groove. The surface is plainly convex at the mesial 
contact area, which is centered on a line with the tip of the buccal 
cusp. Immediately below the convexity of the contact area, the 
surface is sharply concave between that area and the cervical line. 
The distance between the contact area and the cervical line is very 
short.
summary: Description of the surface features of the mesial aspect of a dental crown.

text:
The root outline from the mesial aspect is tapered from the 
cervix, ending in a relatively pointed apex in line with the tip of 
the buccal cusp. The lingual outline may be straight and the buc-
cal outline more curved.
summary: Description of the root outline of a tooth from the mesial aspect.

text:
The mesial surface of the root is smooth and flat from the buc-
cal margin to the center. From this point, it too converges sharply 
toward the root center lingually, often displaying a deep develop-
mental groove in this area. Shallow grooves are nearly always in 
evidence, and occasionally a deep developmental groove will end 
in a bifurcation at the apical third (see Fig. 10.12, 5 and 7).
summary: The mesial surface of the root of a tooth is smooth and flat initially, then converges sharply towards the root center lingually, often displaying deep developmental grooves.

text:
Distal Aspect
The distal aspect of the mandibular first premolar differs from 
the mesial aspect in some respects (see Figs. 10.5, 10.7, and 
10.8). The distal marginal ridge is higher above the cervix, and 
it does not have the extreme lingual slope of the mesial mar-
ginal ridge, being more nearly at right angles to the axis of 
the crown and root. The marginal ridge is confluent with the 
lingual cusp ridge; it has no developmental groove on the dis-
tal marginal ridge. The major portion of the distal surface of 
the crown is smoothly convex, the spheroidal form having an 
unbroken curved surface.
summary: The distal aspect of the mandibular first premolar differs from the mesial aspect in terms of ridge height, slope, and surface curvature.

text:
Below this curvature and just above the cervical line, a concav-
ity is to be noted that is linear in form and that extends buccolin-
gually. The distal contact area is broader than the mesial, although 
it is centered in the same relation to the crown outlines. The center 
of the distal contact area is at a point midway between buccal and 
lingual crests of curvature and midway between the cervical line 
and the tip of the buccal cusp.
summary: Description of the concavity just above the cervical line with details on the distal contact area.

text:
The curvature of the cervical line distally may be the same as 
that found mesially, although less curvature distally is the general 
rule when one is describing all posterior teeth.
summary: The curvature of the cervical line distally is generally less pronounced in posterior teeth compared to mesial curvature.

text:
The surface of the root distally exhibits more convexity than 
was found mesially. A shallow developmental depression is cen-
tered on the root, but rarely does it contain a deep developmental 
groove.
summary: The root surface distally is more convex than mesially, with a shallow developmental depression but rarely a deep groove.

text:
The distal surface slopes from the buccal margin toward the 
center of the root lingually, but the slope is more gradual than that 
found mesially.
summary: The distal surface of the root slopes gradually from the buccal margin towards the center lingually.

text:
Occlusal Aspect
The occlusal aspects of many specimens show considerable varia-
tion in the gross outlines of this tooth. Both mandibular premolars 
exhibit more variations in form occlusally than do the maxillary 
premolars (see Figs. 10.6, 10.7, 10.8, and 10.11).
summary: The occlusal aspects of mandibular premolars exhibit more variations in form than maxillary premolars.

text:
The usual outline form of the mandibular first premolar from 
the occlusal aspect is roughly diamond-shaped and similar to the 
incisal aspect of mandibular canines (see Fig. 10.11, 1, 3, 4, and 
7 through 10). Some of these teeth have a circular form similar 
to that of some mandibular second premolars (see Fig. 10.11, 2); 
others conform to the gross outlines of the more common second 
premolars (see Fig. 10.11, 5 and 6).
summary: The mandibular first premolar has a diamond-shaped outline from the occlusal aspect, similar to mandibular canines and some mandibular second premolars.

text:
The characteristics common to all mandibular first premolars, 
regardless of type, when viewed from the occlusal aspect are as 
follows:
	1.	 The middle buccal lobe makes up the major bulk of the tooth
summary: Mandibular first premolars share common characteristics in terms of the middle buccal lobe being the major bulk of the tooth when viewed from the occlusal aspect.

text:
crown.
	2.	 The buccal ridge is prominent.
	3.	 The mesiobuccal and distobuccal line angles are prominent,
summary: Description of prominent buccal ridge and line angles on a dental crown.

text:
although rounded.
	4.	 The curvatures representing the contact areas, immediately lin-
summary: Discussion on the curvatures representing contact areas in dental anatomy.

text:
gual to the buccal line angles, are relatively broad, with the 
distal area being the broader of the two.
	5.	 The crown converges sharply to the center of the lingual sur-
summary: Description of the broadness of teeth near the buccal line angles with the distal area being broader.

text:
face, starting from points approximating the mesial and dis-
tal contact areas. This formation makes that part of the crown 
represented by buccal cusp ridges, marginal ridges, and lingual 
lobe triangular in form, with the base of the triangle at the buc-
cal cusp ridges and the point of the triangle at the lingual cusp.
	6.	 The marginal ridges are well developed.
	7.	 The lingual cusp is small.
	8.	 The occlusal surface shows a heavy buccal triangular ridge and
summary: Description of the formation of the crown in a triangular form with well-developed marginal ridges and a small lingual cusp.

text:
a small lingual triangular ridge.
The occlusal surface harbors two depressions. These are called 
the mesial and distal fossae because of their irregular form, even 
though they correspond in location to the mesial and distal trian-
gular fossae of other posterior teeth.
summary: Description of a small lingual triangular ridge with mesial and distal fossae on the occlusal surface.

text:
The most common type of mandibular first premolar shows 
a mesiolingual developmental depression and groove. These con-
strict the mesial surface of the crown and create a smaller mesial 
contact area that is in contact with the mandibular canine. The 
distal portion of the crown is described by a larger arc that creates 
a broader contact area in contact with the second mandibular pre-
molar, which has a broader proximal surface than the canine (see 
Figs. 5.7D, 5.10B, and 5.17D).
summary: Description of the anatomy of the most common type of mandibular first premolar including developmental depressions and contact areas.

text:
The mesial fossa is more linear in form, being more sulcate 
and containing the mesial developmental groove, which extends 
buccolingually. This groove is confluent with its extension, which 
becomes the mesiolingual developmental groove as it passes over 
the mesiolingual surface. The distal fossa is more circular in most 
cases and is circumscribed by the distobuccal cusp ridge, the distal 
marginal ridge, the buccal triangular ridge, and the distolingual 
cusp ridge.
summary: Description of the mesial and distal fossa in dental anatomy.

text:
The distal fossa may contain a distal developmental groove that 
is crescent shaped (see Fig. 10.11, 2). It may harbor a distal devel-
opmental pit with accessory supplemental grooves radiating from 
it (see Fig. 10.11, 10), or it may contain a linear groove running 
mesiodistally with an arrangement resembling the typical triangu-
lar fossa (see Fig. 10.11, 4, 5, and 6).
summary: The distal fossa in dental anatomy may have various features including a crescent-shaped groove, a pit with supplemental grooves, or a linear groove resembling a triangular fossa.

text:
Because of the position of this crown over the root, most of the 
buccal surface may be seen from the occlusal aspect, whereas very 
little of the lingual surface is in view.
summary: The crown's position allows for better visibility of the buccal surface compared to the lingual surface.

text: Mandibular Second Premolar
summary: The mandibular second premolar is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Figs. 10.13 through 10.21 illustrate the mandibular second pre-
molar from all aspects. The mandibular second premolar resem-
bles the mandibular first premolar from the buccal aspect only. 
Although the buccal cusp is not as pronounced, the mesiodistal 
measurement of the crown and its general outline are similar 
(Table 10.2). The tooth is larger and has better development 
in other respects. This tooth assumes two common forms. The 
first form, which probably occurs most often, is the three-cusp 
type, which appears more angular from the occlusal aspect
summary: Illustration and comparison of mandibular second premolar with mandibular first premolar.

text:
150
CHAPTER 10    The Permanent Mandibular Premolars
summary: Chapter 10 discusses the anatomy and characteristics of the permanent mandibular premolars.

text:
(see Fig. 10.17). The second form is the two-cusp type, which 
appears more rounded from the occlusal aspect (see Fig. 10.20, 
1, 2, 7, and 10).
summary: Describes two types of forms in dental anatomy, including the two-cusp type.

text:
The two types differ mainly in the occlusal design. The outlines 
and general appearance from all other aspects are similar.
summary: The two types of dental materials differ mainly in the occlusal design, while being similar in outlines and general appearance.

text:
The single root of the second premolar is larger and longer than 
that of the first premolar. The root is seldom, if ever, bifurcated, 
although some specimens show a deep developmental groove 
buccally (see Fig. 10.18, 3 and 6). Often a flattened area appears 
in this location. Ten specimens with uncommon variations are 
shown in Fig. 10.21.
summary: The second premolar typically has a larger and longer single root compared to the first premolar, with rare instances of bifurcation and developmental grooves.

text:
Detailed Description of the Mandibular Second 
Premolar From All Aspects
summary: This text provides a detailed description of the mandibular second premolar from all aspects.

text:
To describe the separate aspects of this tooth, direct comparisons 
are made with the mandibular first premolar except for the occlu-
sal aspect.
summary: Comparison of aspects of a tooth with the mandibular first premolar, excluding the occlusal aspect.

text:
Buccal Aspect
From the buccal aspect, the mandibular second premolar presents 
a shorter buccal cusp than the first premolar, with mesiobuccal 
and distobuccal cusp ridges showing angulation of less degree (see 
Figs. 10.13 and 10.18). The contact areas, both mesial and distal, 
are broad. The contact areas appear to be higher because of the 
short buccal cusp.
summary: The mandibular second premolar has a shorter buccal cusp than the first premolar, with broad contact areas and angulation of cusp ridges.

text:
The root is broader mesiodistally than that of the first premo-
lar, the extra breadth appearing for most of its length, and the root
summary: Comparison of root width between second premolar and first premolar.

text:
• Fig. 10.13  Mandibular left second premolar, buccal aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. 
mm.)
summary: Illustration of the buccal aspect of a mandibular left second premolar with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text:
• Fig. 10.14  Mandibular left second premolar, lingual aspect. (Grid = 1 sq. 
mm.)
summary: Illustration of mandibular left second premolar from lingual aspect with grid measurement of 1 sq. mm.

text:

mm.)
summary: Illustration of the mesial aspect of a mandibular left second premolar with a grid size of 1 sq. mm.

text:

mm.)
summary: Illustration of the distal aspect of the mandibular left second premolar with grid measurement of 1 sq. mm.

text:

sq. mm.)
summary: Illustration of the occlusal aspect of the mandibular left second premolar with a grid size of 1 square millimeter.
