text:
however, the cuspid has a much longer root. The pulp cavity gen-
tly tapers from the incisal aspect to the apical foramen. A mesial or 
distal curve of the apical root may be present (see Fig. 13.10B, 1, 
4, 6, and 8; E, 14, 17, and 18). The apical foramen may appear to 
exit at the tip of the root (see Fig. 13.10B, 1, 3 to 5, 7, and 9; E, 
10, 11, 13, 14, 17, and 18) or slightly to its mesial or distal aspect 
(see Fig. 13.10B, 2, 6, and 8; E, 12, 15, and 16).
summary: The root of the cuspid has a longer length with a tapering pulp cavity that may have a mesial or distal curve at the apical foramen.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.10C)
In a cervical cross section, the shape of the root and pulp cavity is oval 
(see Fig. 13.10C, 6, 7, and 9), triangular (see Fig. 13.10C, 8), or ellip-
tical (see Fig. 13.10C, 1 to 5). The pulp chamber and canal are often 
centered within the crown and root (see Fig. 13.10C, 1, 3, 4, and 9).
summary: The cervical cross section of teeth shows oval, triangular, or elliptical shapes of the root and pulp cavity, with the pulp chamber and canal typically centered within the crown and root.

text: Maxillary First Premolar
summary: The maxillary first premolar is a specific tooth in the upper jaw.

text:
Buccolingual Section (Fig. 13.11A and D)
The maxillary first premolar may have two well-developed roots 
(see Fig. 13.11A, 1, 2, and 9; D, 10 and 14), two root projections 
that are not fully separated (see Fig. 13.11A, 3, 5, 7, and 8; D, 11
summary: The buccolingual section of the maxillary first premolar shows two well-developed roots and root projections that are not fully separated.

text:
to 13 and 15 to 17), or one broad root (see Fig. 13.11A, 4 and 6; 
D, 18). The majority of maxillary first premolars have two root 
canals (see Fig. 13.11A and D). A small percentage of maxillary 
first premolar teeth may have three roots that may be almost unde-
tectable radiographically.
summary: Maxillary first premolars typically have two root canals, but a small percentage may have three roots.

text:
The pulp horn usually extends further incisally under the buccal 
cusp, because this cusp is usually better developed than the lingual 
cusp. The pulp horns may be blunted (see Fig. 13.11A, 1, 5, and 
6; D, 11) in teeth possessing cusps that demonstrate a fair amount 
of attrition. The pulp chamber’s floor is below the cervical level of 
all the variations found in the maxillary first premolar. The pulp 
chamber of teeth having the least root separation usually shows the 
largest incisal-apical dimension (see Fig. 13.11A, 4; D, 18). Those 
teeth possessing a partial root separation may also have this large 
dimension (see Fig. 13.11A, 8; D, 10). Teeth having two separate 
canals usually demonstrate a rather small pulp chamber in the inci-
sal-apical direction (see Fig. 13.11A, 1, 2, and 9; D, 11 and 14). 
The shape of the pulp chamber (excluding the pulp horns) tends to 
be square (see Fig. 13.11A, 1 and 8; D, 10, 12, 13, 14, and 18) or 
rectangular (see Fig. 13.11A, 2 to 7; D, 11, 15, 16, and 17).
summary: Description of the pulp chamber variations in teeth based on cusp development, attrition, and root separation.

text:
• Fig. 13.11  Maxillary first premolar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the 
pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing 
the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Cervical cross section at the cementoenamel junction, 
exposing the pulp chamber. These are the openings to root canals that will be seen in the floor of the pulp 
chamber. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) Mesiodistal 
section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the maxillary first premolar tooth and its pulp cavity.

text:
198
CHAPTER 13    Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
The root canal often appears to exit at the tip of the root (see 
Fig. 13.11A, 1, 4, 6, 7, and 8; B, 12, 13, and 15 to 18), slightly to 
the labial or lingual (see Fig. 13.11A, 2), or a combination of the 
two locations (see Fig. 13.11A, 3, 5, and 9; B, 10, 11, and 14).
summary: The root canal can exit at the tip of the root in various locations.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.11B and E)
The pulp horns appear blunted from the mesial or distal aspect, 
and the pulp chamber cannot be differentiated from the root 
canal. The pulp cavity tapers slightly from the occlusal aspect to 
the apical foramen. If two canals are present, the radiopacity will 
increase in the apical half of the tooth because of an increased 
amount of dentin and bone and a decrease in the volume of the 
pulp cavity.
summary: Description of the mesiodistal section of a tooth showing blunted pulp horns and radiopacity changes if two canals are present.

text:
The apical foramen appears to exit at the tip of the root most 
of the time (see Fig. 13.11B, 1, 2, 3, and 6 through 9; E, 10 and 
12 through 18), but some appear to exit on the mesial or distal 
aspects of the root (see Fig. 13.11B, 4 and 5; E, 11).
summary: The apical foramen typically exits at the tip of the root, but can also exit on the mesial or distal aspects.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.11C)
The cross section at the cervical level shows the kidney-shaped 
outline form characteristic of the maxillary first premolar (see Fig. 
13.11C). A mesial developmental groove is usually present, giving
summary: The cervical cross section of the maxillary first premolar shows a kidney-shaped outline with a mesial developmental groove.

text:
this tooth its classic indentation. The pulp cavity may demon-
strate a constriction adjacent to the developmental groove (see Fig. 
13.11C, 2, 3, 5, 6, and 9), or it may follow the general outline 
of the root surface (see Fig. 13.11C, 1, 4, 7, and 8). Some roots 
demonstrate two separate root canals (see Fig. 13.11C, 7), whereas 
a cross section of a three-rooted maxillary first premolar will show 
three separate canals (see Fig. 13.11C, 3).
summary: The text discusses variations in the pulp cavity shape and number of root canals in teeth.

text: Maxillary Second Premolar
summary: The maxillary second premolar is a specific tooth located in the upper jaw.

text:
Buccolingual Section (Fig. 13.12A and D)
Most maxillary second premolars have only one root and one 
canal. Two roots are possible, although two canals within a single 
root may also be found.
summary: Maxillary second premolars typically have one root and one canal, but variations with two roots or two canals in a single root are possible.

text:
The pulp cavity may demonstrate well-developed pulp horns 
(see Fig. 13.12A, 1, 2, 6, 7, and 8; D, 10, 11, 12, 14, 16, and 
17); others may have blunted or nonexistent pulp horns (see Fig. 
13.12A, 3, 4, 5, and 9; D, 13, 15, and 18). The pulp chamber and 
root canal are very broad in the buccolingual aspect of teeth with 
single canals. The pulp cavity does not show a well-defined demar-
cation between the root cavity and the pulp cavity because of the 
large buccolingual extent of the pulp cavity in the upper half of
summary: Variations in pulp horn development and size of pulp chamber and root canal in teeth with single canals.

text:
• Fig. 13.12  Maxillary second premolar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of 
the pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing 
the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Cervical cross section at the cementoenamel junction, 
exposing the pulp chamber. These are the openings to root canals that will be seen in the floor of the pulp 
chamber. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) Mesiodistal 
section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the maxillary second premolar and their relation to the pulp cavity.

text:
199
CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and physiology of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
the tooth. In the apical half or third of the tooth, the pulp cavity 
often narrows abruptly (see Fig. 13.12A, 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8; D, 11, 
12, 13, and 18) and then tapers gently toward the apex. Some 
teeth possess dentinal islands in the apical third of the root; this 
situation essentially forces the clinician to treat these as teeth with 
two canals (see Fig. 13.22A, 5; D, 15 and 17). Other maxillary 
second premolars have a canal that bifurcates at the apical third of 
the root (see Fig. 13.12D, 10, 15, and 16). It should also be noted 
that buccal and lingual pulpal projections or fins are present at the 
level of the CEJ (see Fig. 13.12A, 2; D, 12 and 18). Some teeth 
show a constriction at this same level (see Fig. 13.12D, 10).
summary: The anatomy of the tooth in the apical half or third includes variations such as narrowing of the pulp cavity, dentinal islands, bifurcated canals, and pulpal projections.

text:
The apical foramen often appears to exit at the tip of the root 
(see Fig. 13.12A, 1, 2, 5, 6, and 8; D, 11, 12, and 14 to 18). Some 
apical foramina appear to exit on the buccal aspect of the root (see 
Fig. 13.12A, 4; D, 13), on the lingual aspect of the root (see Fig. 
13.12A, 7 and 9), or on both sides of the root tip (see Fig. 13.12A, 
3; D, 10 and 15).
summary: The apical foramen can exit at the tip, buccal aspect, lingual aspect, or both sides of the root tip.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.12B and E)
The view of the pulp cavity in the mesiodistal section of the second 
maxillary premolar does not vary from that found in the maxil-
lary first premolar. The pulp horns are blunted, and the pulp cavity
summary: Comparison of pulp cavity in mesiodistal section of second maxillary premolar with first maxillary premolar.

text:
tapers slightly from the occlusal aspect to the apex. The apical fora-
men may appear to be located off center of the root tip (see Fig. 
13.12A, 2, 6, and 9; D, 10 and 13) or appear to exit at the root tip 
(see Fig. 13.12B, 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, and 8; E, 11, 12, and 14 to 18).
summary: The root canal tapers slightly from the occlusal aspect to the apex, with variations in the location of the apical foramen.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.12C)
The cervical cross section of the maxillary second premolar is usu-
ally oval (see Fig. 13.12C, 2 and 4 to 9), with some teeth having a 
kidney-shaped cross section (see Fig. 13.12C, 1 and 3). The pulp 
cavity is centered in the root and may have a constriction in the 
middle of the canal space (see Fig. 13.12C, 1, 4, 6, and 9), an 
entire separation (see Fig. 13.12C, 2), or an elliptical pulp cavity 
(see Fig 13.12C, 3, 5, 7, and 8).
summary: The cervical cross section of the maxillary second premolar can be oval or kidney-shaped, with variations in the pulp cavity structure.

text: Maxillary First Molar
summary: The maxillary first molar is a specific tooth in the upper jaw.

text:
Buccolingual Section (Fig. 13.13A and D)
The buccolingual section of the maxillary first molar in Fig. 13.13 
shows the pulp cavities of the mesiobuccal and palatal root. These 
roots were chosen to demonstrate the pulp cavity’s anatomy 
because of the complexity of the mesiobuccal root. The distobuc-
cal root is straighter and smaller and presents fewer variations in
summary: Illustration of the buccolingual section of the maxillary first molar showing pulp cavities of mesiobuccal and palatal roots.

summary: The text block is incomplete and does not provide any information.

summary: The letter B

text:
• Fig. 13.13  Maxillary first molar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp 
cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing the buc-
cal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Five cross sections at the cervical line and four cross sections 
at the midroot. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) Mesio-
distal section, exposing the buccal aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the maxillary first molar and its pulp cavity.

text:
200
CHAPTER 13    Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and physiology of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
shape. Entire removal of the pulp is impossible in many maxillary 
first molar teeth because of the complexities of the root canal sys-
tem (see Fig. 13.7).
summary: The complexities of the root canal system in maxillary first molar teeth make complete removal of the pulp impossible.

text:
The maxillary first molar usually has three roots and three 
canals. The palatal root usually has the largest dimensions, fol-
lowed by the mesiobuccal and distobuccal roots, respectively. The 
mesiobuccal root is often very wide buccolingually and usually 
possesses an accessory canal, commonly called MB2, which is usu-
ally the smallest of all the canals in this tooth.
summary: The maxillary first molar typically has three roots and three canals, with the palatal root being the largest, followed by the mesiobuccal and distobuccal roots.

text:
The pulp horns are usually prominent in this tooth (see Fig. 
13.13A, 1, and 4 to 8; D, 10 to 13, and 15 to 18). The pulp 
chamber is somewhat rectangular (excluding the pulp horns) 
when viewed from the mesial aspect of the tooth. The palatal root 
usually has the largest canal (see Fig. 13.13A, 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6; D, 
10, 15, 17, and 18). The mesiobuccal canal is often very small (see 
Fig. 13.13A, 2 and 6; D, 10, 14, and 17), but some mesiobuccal 
canals may be very wide within a very wide root (see Fig. 13.13A, 
9; D, 12 and 13).
summary: Description of the pulp chamber and canals in a specific tooth with variations in size and shape.

text:
The presence of an unmarked MB2 is strongly suggested when 
the root canal appears to be off to one side (see Fig. 13.13A, 2, 6, 
and 8; D, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, and 18).
summary: Identification of an unmarked MB2 in root canals is indicated by its off-center appearance.

text:
The root canals of the wide mesiobuccal roots are widest at 
the midroot level and taper to a very fine diameter at the apical 
foramen. The palatal root canal and the mesiobuccal root canal of 
most teeth taper gently to the apical region, where they terminate 
at or near the apex. The apical foramen of the palatal canal may 
appear to exit at the apex (see Fig. 13.13A, 1, and 4 to 9; D, 11 to 
17), slightly lingually (see Fig. 13.13A, 2; D, 10) or buccally to the 
root tip (see Fig. 13.13A, 3; D, 18).
summary: Description of the root canal morphology in mesiobuccal and palatal roots of teeth.

text:
The apical foramen of the mesiobuccal canal may appear to exit 
on the tip of the root (see Fig. 13.13A, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9; D, 10, 
12, 13, 17, and 18) or on the buccal (see Fig. 13.13A, 1 and 6; 
D, 14 and 15) or lingual (see Fig. 13.13D, 16) aspect of the root.
summary: The location of the apical foramen of the mesiobuccal canal can vary on the root.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.13B and E)
The mesiodistal section of the maxillary first molar includes the 
distobuccal root, which was not visible on the previously men-
tioned buccolingual section. The mesiobuccal root has a great 
tendency to possess a more curved root and canal than the disto-
buccal root (see Fig. 13.13B, 1 to 8; E, 12, 14, and 15). Some of 
the buccal canals are relatively straight (see Fig. 13.13E, 10, 11, 
and 13).
summary: The mesiodistal section of the maxillary first molar shows differences in root and canal curvature between the mesiobuccal and distobuccal roots.

text:
The pulp horns are very distinct from this view, with the mesio-
buccal pulp horn usually appearing a little larger than the disto-
buccal pulp horn (see Fig. 13.13B, 1 and 3 to 9; E, 10 to 13 and 
15 to 18). In some teeth, the pulp horns are of equal size (see Fig. 
13.13B, 2; E, 14). The pulp chamber is somewhat square (if the 
pulp horns are excluded) when viewed from the buccal aspect. The 
demarcation of the root canal is much more distinct in the mesio-
distal section. The root canals appear much smaller when viewed 
from the buccal or lingual aspect. The canals taper slightly as they 
approach the apical foramen. The apical foramen often appears 
to be located at the tip of the root (see Fig. 13.13B, 1 to 7 and 
9; E, 11, 14, 16, and 18), but the apical foramen may appear to 
be located on the mesial (see Fig. 13.13E, 10 and 17, mesial root 
only) or on the distal aspect of the root (see Fig. 13.13B, 8; E, 12 
and 13, distal root only).
summary: Description of the pulp horns, pulp chamber, and root canals in teeth from different aspects.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.13C)
The cervical outline form of the maxillary first molar is rhomboi-
dal with rounded corners (see Fig. 13.13C, 1 to 5). The mesiobuc-
cal angle has an acute angle, the distobuccal angle is obtuse, and
summary: Description of the cervical outline form of the maxillary first molar with specific angles.

text:
the lingual angles are essentially right angles. The orifices of the 
root canals have the following relation to the floor of the pulp 
chamber.
summary: The lingual angles are essentially right angles and the orifices of the root canals have a specific relation to the floor of the pulp chamber.

text:
The palatal canal is centered lingually; the distobuccal canal is 
near the obtuse angle of the pulp chamber; the mesiobuccal root 
canal is buccal and mesial to the distobuccal canal, in what seems 
to be the extreme corner, positioned within the acute angle of the 
pulp chamber. If an accessory mesiobuccal canal (MB2) is present, 
it will be located lingual to the mesiobuccal canal. The canals of 
this tooth form a triangular pattern; a line drawn between the 
mesiobuccal canal and the palatal canal makes the base of the tri-
angle; the distobuccal canal, which is slightly closer to the palatal 
canal, makes the third point of the triangle. If a mesiobuccal acces-
sory canal is present, it will be between the mesiobuccal and pala-
tal canal just off an imaginary line between the two canals (see Fig. 
13.13C, 7 to 9). The MB2 may even be mesial to a line connecting 
the mesiobuccal and the palatal canals (see Fig. 13.13C, 8).
summary: Description of the root canal anatomy of maxillary molars with details on the position of the palatal, distobuccal, and mesiobuccal canals, including the presence of accessory canals.

text:
Midroot Cross Section (see Fig. 13.13C)
The midroot sections were added to the molar descriptions because 
some molars possess more than one canal within the root (see Fig. 
13.13C, 6 to 9). The palatal root is usually the largest root, having 
a round outline form. The distobuccal canal is oval to round but 
much smaller than the palatal root. The mesiobuccal root is an 
elongated oval to kidney-shaped root with the indentation located 
toward the furcation. The root canals of the palatal and distobuc-
cal root are oval to round, whereas the mesiobuccal canals are 
elongated (see Fig. 13.13C, 6 and 9), elliptical (see Fig. 13.13C, 
7), or round (see Fig. 13.13C, 8 and 9). The pulp canals may be 
extremely difficult to locate and instrument if secondary or irrita-
tion-induced dentin is abundant (see Fig. 13.13C, 9). A thorough 
knowledge of the anatomy of the pulp chambers and canals is 
necessary if endodontic procedures are to be accomplished.
summary: Description of midroot cross sections in molars, highlighting the different shapes and sizes of root canals.

text: Maxillary Second Molar
summary: The maxillary second molar is a specific tooth in the upper jaw.

text:
Buccolingual Section (Fig. 13.14A and D)
The buccal roots of the maxillary second molar are straighter and 
closer together than those of the maxillary first molar. The ten-
dency for root fusion is greater in the second maxillary molar than 
in the first maxillary molar, but the palatal root is usually separate. 
Most often, maxillary second molars possess three roots and three 
canals.
summary: The buccal roots of the maxillary second molar are straighter and closer together than those of the maxillary first molar, with a tendency for root fusion and usually possessing three roots and three canals.

text:
The mesiobuccal root of the maxillary second molar is not as 
complex as that formed in the maxillary first molar. The tendency 
for a very wide mesiobuccal canal is not present in the maxillary 
second molar. The presence of two canals in the mesiobuccal root 
is not as common in the maxillary second molar as in the maxil-
lary first molar; however, it does occur (see Fig. 13.14A, 5 and 7).
summary: Comparison of the complexity of the mesiobuccal root between maxillary second and first molars.

text:
The pulp horns may be well developed (see Fig. 13.14A, 1 to 3, 
5, 8, and 9; D, 10 to 18) or virtually absent (see Fig. 13.14A, 4, 6, 
and 7). The pulp chamber appears somewhat rectangular (exclud-
ing the pulp horns). The pulp canals gradually taper toward the 
apex until reaching the apical constriction, which occurs just 
before the apical foramen.
summary: Description of the development and structure of pulp horns, pulp chamber, and pulp canals in teeth.

text:
The mesiobuccal root canal of the maxillary second molar does 
not have the tendency to be extremely large, as is demonstrated in 
the mesiobuccal canal of the maxillary first molar. The apical fora-
men of the palatal root often appears to exit at the tip of the root 
(see Fig. 13.14A, 1 to 3 and 5 to 8; D, 11, 13, 14, 16, 17, and 18), 
but it may exist on the lingual (see Fig. 13.14A, 4 and 9; D, 15) or 
buccal aspect of the root (see Fig. 13.14D, 10 and 12).
summary: The mesiobuccal root canal of the maxillary second molar is not as large as the mesiobuccal canal of the maxillary first molar, with variations in the location of the apical foramen.

text:
201
CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and structure of pulp chambers and canals in dentistry.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.14B and E)
The mesiodistal section of the maxillary second molar is similar 
to that of the maxillary first molar. The buccal roots of the second 
molar are not as far apart as they are in the maxillary first molar, 
and their buccal roots have a greater tendency to be fused.
summary: Comparison of mesiodistal sections of maxillary second molar and first molar.

text:
The pulp horns are usually well developed (see Fig. 13.14B, 1 
to 5, 8, and 9; E, 10 to 15 and 17). Some teeth demonstrate an 
obvious blunting or absence of the pulp horns (see Fig. 13.14B, 6 
and 7; E, 18). The mesiobuccal pulp horn is often larger than the 
distobuccal pulp horn (see Fig. 13.14B, 1, 4, 5, 8, and 9; E, 10, 
12, 13, 15, 17, and 18).
summary: Description of the development and size differences of pulp horns in teeth.

text:
The pulp chamber appears much smaller in the mesiodistal sec-
tion than in the buccolingual section. The pulp chamber is square 
(excluding the pulp horns) when viewed from the buccal aspect. 
The pulp canals gently taper from the pulp chamber to the apical 
constriction. The mesiobuccal pulp canal has a greater tendency 
to be curved than the distobuccal canal. The majority of the apical 
foramen appears to exit at the tip of the root (see Fig. 13.14B, 1, 
2, and 4 to 9; E, 10 to 16 and 18).
summary: The pulp chamber in teeth appears smaller in the mesiodistal section than in the buccolingual section, with pulp canals tapering towards the apical constriction and the mesiobuccal pulp canal being more curved than the distobuccal canal.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.14C)
The cervical cross section of the maxillary second molar demon-
strates angulations of the outline form that are more extreme than
summary: The text describes the cervical cross section of a maxillary second molar with extreme angulations.

text:
those found in the maxillary first molar. The mesiobuccal angle 
is more acute and the distobuccal angle is more obtuse than that 
found in the maxillary first molar, and the outline form of the 
pulp chamber reflects these differences.
summary: Differences in angles and outline form of the pulp chamber in maxillary first molars compared to other teeth.

text:
The mesiobuccal canal orifice is located farther to the buccal and 
mesial aspect of the pulp chamber (see Fig 13.14C, 4 and 5). The 
distobuccal canal more nearly approaches the midpoint between 
the mesiobuccal and palatal canal (see Fig. 13.14C, 4). The palatal 
canal is located at the most lingual aspect of the root.
summary: Description of the location of mesiobuccal, distobuccal, and palatal canals within the root.

text:
Because of the tendency for the roots to be fused or at least 
closer together, the orifices of the root canals are much closer 
together in the maxillary second molar than in the maxillary first 
molar (see Fig. 13.14C, 4). In the cervical cross section, the trian-
gularity of the floor of the pulp chamber is clearly demonstrated.
summary: Root canals in the maxillary second molar are closer together due to fused roots, with a triangular floor in the pulp chamber.

text:
Midroot Cross Section (see Fig. 13.14C)
The palatal root of the maxillary second molar may be the largest 
of the three roots (see Fig. 13.14C, 7 and 8). The mesiobuccal root 
may have a larger buccolingual dimension, but it has a narrower 
mesiodistal dimension. The distobuccal canal is the smallest root 
of the three.
summary: Description of the midroot cross section of the maxillary second molar with details on root sizes and dimensions.

text:
The distobuccal and palatal roots have round or oval outline 
forms. The mesiobuccal root is usually rectangular with rounded
summary: Description of the outline forms of distobuccal, palatal, and mesiobuccal roots in dental anatomy.

summary: The text block is too short to provide a summary.

text: B
summary: The text block is too short to provide a summary.

text:
• Fig. 13.14  Maxillary second molar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the 
pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing the 
buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Five cross sections at cervical line and four cross sections 
at midroot. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) Mesiodistal 
section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of a maxillary second molar and its pulp cavity.

text:
202
CHAPTER 13    Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
corners. If one canal is present, the canal follows the outline form 
of the root and is usually narrower at the middle of the root, 
which makes the canal appear as two canals (see Fig. 13.14C, 7). 
If two separate canals are present, they are usually round (see Fig. 
13.14C, 8).
summary: Description of the appearance of root canals in dental anatomy.

text: Maxillary Third Molar
summary: The maxillary third molar is a tooth located in the upper jaw.

text:
The maxillary third molar has the most variable anatomy of any 
of the maxillary teeth. A description of the pulpal anatomy is 
not provided here because of the tremendous variability of the 
maxillary third molar. A sample of longitudinal and cross sec-
tions, displayed in the same manner as for all the other maxillary 
teeth, shows a comparison of this molar with the other maxillary 
molars (Fig. 13.15). When the maxillary third molar is compared 
in development and eruption with the other maxillary molars, it 
is evident that the third molar is smaller than the other molars. 
The crown is usually triangular or round rather than quadri-
lateral. The roots are shorter, more curved, and have a greater 
tendency for root fusion, which makes these teeth appear to be 
single rooted (see Fig. 13.15A, 8; B, 3, 5, and 8; D, 10 and 12; 
E, 11 to 14, and 16). Because the maxillary third molar is 8 or
summary: The maxillary third molar has highly variable anatomy compared to other maxillary teeth, with smaller size, triangular or round crown shape, shorter and more curved roots, and a tendency for root fusion.

text:
9 years younger than the first molar, the pulp chamber will have 
less secondary dentin than the older first and second molars. 
This allows easier access to the canals. However, because of the 
higher incidence in malformations of the roots, the endodontic 
procedure may be very difficult.
summary: The pulp chamber of the second molar is typically less calcified than the first and second molars, making access to the canals easier but potentially complicating endodontic procedures due to root malformations.

text:
Third molars have generally been condemned without fully 
appreciating their possible usefulness in later years. If these teeth 
can be managed well and are functioning, they should be main-
tained, because they can provide suitable support for restorative 
procedures in later years.
summary: Third molars, often criticized, can be valuable if well managed and functional, providing support for future restorative procedures.

text: Pulp Cavities of the Mandibular Teeth
summary: The text discusses the pulp cavities of the mandibular teeth.

text: Mandibular Central Incisor
summary: The mandibular central incisor is a specific tooth located in the lower jaw.

text:
Labiolingual Section (see Fig. 13.16A and D)
The mandibular central incisor is the smallest tooth in the mouth, 
but its labiolingual dimension is very large. This tooth usually 
has one canal; two canals may be found, but not very frequently. 
The pulp horn is well developed in this tooth (see Fig. 13.16A, 
1 to 6 and 8; D, 10 to 18). As attrition occurs, reactive dentin 
is produced; it will essentially move the pulp tissue farther from
summary: The mandibular central incisor has a large labiolingual dimension with usually one canal and a well-developed pulp horn.

• Fig. 13.15  Maxillary third molar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp 
cavity. This aspect does not appear in the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing the buccal 
or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Five cross sections at the cervical line and four cross sections at the 
midroot. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) Mesiodistal 
section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the maxillary third molar pulp cavity.

text:
203
CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and structure of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
the original location of the external surface of the tooth (see Fig. 
13.16A, 9). The pulp chamber may be very large (see Fig. 13.16A, 
1, 2, 4, 6, and 8; D, 10, 11, 13, and 17), intermediate in size (see 
Fig. 13.16A, 3, 5, 7, and 9; D, 12, 14, and 15), or very small (see 
Fig. 13.16D, 16 and 18).
summary: The text describes the varying sizes of pulp chambers in teeth.

text:
The pulp canal may taper gently to the apex (see Fig. 13.16A, 
2, 3, and 7; D, 10, 11, 14, 16, and 18) or narrow abruptly in the 
apical 3 to 4 mm of the root (see Fig. 13.16A, 1, 4, 5, 6, and 8; D, 
12, 13, 15, and 17).
summary: The pulp canal in teeth can taper gently or narrow abruptly towards the apex.

text:
The apical foramen may appear to exit at the apex (see Fig. 
13.16A, 1, 4, 6, 7, and 9; D, 11, 12, 15, 16, and 18) or on the 
buccal aspect of the root (see Fig. 13.16A, 2, 3, 5, and 8; D, 10, 
13, 14, and 17).
summary: The apical foramen can exit at the apex or on the buccal aspect of the root.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.16B and E)
A buccal or facial view of a mesiodistal section of the mandibu-
lar central incisor demonstrates the narrowness of the pulp cavity. 
A small endodontic file can generally be used to negotiate these 
canals in spite of this narrowness because of the wide labiolingual 
dimension of the pulp chamber. However, secondary or tertiary 
(irritation-induced) dentin may interfere with endodontic treat-
ment (see Fig. 13.16D, 16 and 18; E, 13 and 18).
summary: The mesiodistal section of the mandibular central incisor shows a narrow pulp cavity with potential interference from secondary or tertiary dentin.

text:
The pulp horn is usually prominent but single. The canal also 
appears narrow, having a gentle taper from the pulp chamber to the 
apical constriction. The canal may exit at the apex (see Fig. 13.16B, 2, 
5, and 8; E, 12, 14, 16, and 17) or mesially or distally to the apex of the 
root (see Fig. 13.16B, 1, 3, 4, 6, 7, and 9; E, 10, 11, 13, 15, and 18).
summary: Description of the anatomy of the pulp horn and canal in a tooth, including variations in exit points.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.16C)
The cervical cross section demonstrates the proportions of the 
root. The mesiodistal dimension is small, whereas the labiolin-
gual dimension is very large. The external shape is variable; it 
may be round, oval, or elliptical. The more nearly round the root, 
the more nearly round the canal (see Fig. 13.16C). Two separate 
canals may be present, or a dentinal island may make it appear as 
though two canals were present (Fig. 13.17).
summary: The cervical cross section of a tooth root shows small mesiodistal and large labiolingual dimensions with variable external shapes, which can affect the shape of the canal.

text: Mandibular Lateral Incisor
summary: The mandibular lateral incisor is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Labiolingual Section (Fig. 13.18A and D)
The mandibular lateral incisor tends to be a little larger than the 
mandibular central incisor in all dimensions, and the pulp cham-
ber is also larger. The form and function of the mandibular lateral 
incisor are identical to those of the central incisor.
summary: Comparison of mandibular lateral and central incisors in size and pulp chamber, with similar form and function.

text:
• Fig. 13.16  Mandibular central incisor (first incisor). (A) Labiolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal 
aspect of the pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, 
exposing the labial or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Cervical cross section at the cementoenamel 
junction, exposing the pulp chamber. These are the openings to root canals that will be seen in the floor 
of the pulp chamber. (D) Labiolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) 
Mesiodistal section, exposing the labial or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the mandibular central incisor showing pulp cavity aspects.

text:
204
CHAPTER 13    Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and physiology of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
The pulp horn is usually prominent. The pulp chamber may 
possess a dimension that is very large (see Fig. 13.18A, 2, 4, 5, 
8, and 9; D, 10, 11, 16, 17, and 18), intermediate in size (see 
Fig. 13.18A, 1, 3, 6, and 7; D, 12), or small (see Fig. 13.18D, 14 
and 15). The pulp canal may taper gently from the apex (see Fig. 
13.18A, 1, 2, 4, 6, 7, and 9; D, 12, 14 to 17) or narrow abruptly 
in the last 3 to 4 mm of the canal (see Fig. 13.18A, 3, 5, and 8; D, 
10 to 13). The apical foramen may appear to exit at the tip of the 
root (see Fig. 13.18A, 1 to 6, 8, and 9; D, 12 to 15, 17, and 18) 
or on the buccal or lingual aspect of the root tip (see Fig. 13.18A, 
7; D, 10, 11, and 16).
summary: Description of variations in size and shape of pulp chamber, canal, and apical foramen in dental anatomy.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.18B and E)
As viewed from this aspect, the pulp chamber and canal will dem-
onstrate a slender cavity. The mandibular lateral incisor resembles 
the mandibular incisor, but it may appear a little wider and have 
a pulpal dimension that is larger. The pulp horns are prominent, 
and the pulp chamber and canal gently taper to the apex. The api-
cal foramen may appear to exit at the tip (see Fig. 13.18A, 1, 2, 3, 
6, and 9; D, 12 to 15, 17, and 18) or on the mesial or distal aspect 
of the root tip (see Fig. 13.18A, 5, 7, and 8; D, 10, 11 and 16).
summary: Description of the mesiodistal section of the mandibular lateral incisor and its pulp chamber and canal.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.18C)
The cervical cross section of the mandibular lateral incisor shows 
the pulp canal centered in the root. A comparison of several of
summary: Description of the cervical cross section of the mandibular lateral incisor with the pulp canal centered in the root.

text:
the sections demonstrates a root somewhat larger than that of the 
mandibular central incisor. Considerable variation is evident in 
the form of the root. The root’s outline form is oval to elliptical. 
Some cross sections of the larger teeth resemble the cervical cross 
sections of small mandibular canines (see Fig. 13.18C, 2, 3, and 
4). The root canal follows the outline form of the root, and some 
roots demonstrate root grooves (see Fig. 13.18C, 6).
summary: The text describes the anatomy of a tooth root, noting its size, shape, and variations, with some roots showing grooves.

text: Mandibular Canine
summary: The mandibular canine is a specific tooth located in the lower jaw.

text:
Labiolingual Section (Fig. 13.19A and D)
The pulp cavity of the mandibular canine is similar in size and 
shape to that of the maxillary canine. The mandibular canine 
tends to be a little shorter, although the opposite can be found. 
It is not uncommon to find two roots or at least two canals in the 
mandibular canine. A dentinal island may be found in any tooth 
that demonstrates an extremely wide labiolingual dimension and a 
narrow mesiodistal dimension. Because the presence of two canals 
cannot be easily detected radiographically, their presence must be 
ruled out clinically as well. The pulp cavity in a tooth of this kind 
varies according to where the section is examined (see Fig. 8.24, 
1, 2, 5, and 6).
summary: The pulp cavity of the mandibular canine can have variations in size, shape, and number of roots or canals, requiring clinical examination to rule out presence of two canals.

text:
The pulp horn is prominent in the mandibular canine 
unless an extensive amount of attrition has taken place (see Fig. 
13.19A, 1 and 3). The pulp chamber is usually very wide (see 
Fig. 13.19A, 1, 3, 4, 5, and 7; D, 10, 12, 14, 15, 17, and 18) 
but may be average to small (see Fig. 13.19A, 2, 6, and 9; D, 11, 
13, and 16).
summary: The pulp chamber in the mandibular canine is usually wide but can be average to small.

text:
Some mandibular canines demonstrate an abrupt narrowing of 
the pulp cavity when passing from the region of the pulp chamber 
to the region of the pulp canal (see Fig. 13.19A, 8; D, 13). Other 
mandibular canines demonstrate an abrupt narrowing of the pulp 
canal in the apical region (see Fig. 13.19A, 1 to 6; D, 11, 12, and 
18), after which the canal gently tapers to the apex. If an abrupt 
narrowing of the canal is absent, the tooth will demonstrate a 
canal that gently tapers to the apical foramen.
summary: Mandibular canines can demonstrate different patterns of narrowing in the pulp cavity and canal.

text:
The apical foramen often appears to exit at the tip of the apex 
(see Fig. 13.19A, 3, 5, 7, and 9; D, 10, 12, 14 to 16), slightly 
buccally (see Fig. 13.19A, 1, 2, 6, and 8; D, 11, 13, and 17), or 
lingually to the root tip (see Fig. 13.19D, 18).
summary: The apical foramen can exit at the tip of the apex, slightly buccally, or lingually to the root tip.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.19B and E)
The mesiodistal cross section of the mandibular canine appears 
very similar to that of the maxillary canine. The mesiodistal sec-
tion demonstrates how narrow this tooth is in the mesiodistal 
aspect. This view also shows the degree of curvature of the apical 
portion of the root. The curvature of the root canal may be in 
the mesial direction (see Fig. 13.19E, 17). The pulp horn is usu-
ally prominent but appears blunted in this view. The pulp cham-
ber and canal show a continuous gentle taper to the apex, where 
the apical foramen appears to exit at the tip of the root (see Fig. 
13.19B, 1 to 4; E, 10, 11, 13, 15, and 17) or slightly mesially or 
distally to the root tip (see Fig. 13.19B, 5 to 7; E, 12, 14, and 18).
summary: The mesiodistal section of the mandibular canine shows narrowness in the mesiodistal aspect and curvature of the root canal.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.19C)
A cervical cross section of the mandibular canine shows consid-
erable variation in size and shape (see Fig. 13.19C, 1 to 9). The 
outline form of the root may be oval (see Fig. 13.19C, 1, 4, 7, 
and 8), rectangular (see Fig. 13.19C, 2, 5, 6, and 9), or triangu-
lar (see Fig. 13.19C, 3). The size and shape of the canal are also 
variable. The pulp cavity’s outline form closely resembles that of 
the root form.
summary: The cervical cross section of the mandibular canine shows variation in size, shape, and canal morphology.

text: • Fig. 13.17  Mandibular central incisor with two canals.
summary: Illustration of a mandibular central incisor with two canals.

text:
205
CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy of pulp chambers and canals.

text: Mandibular First Premolar
summary: The mandibular first premolar is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Buccolingual Section (Fig. 13.20A and D)
The mandibular first premolar looks like a small mandibular 
canine with an extra small cusp. The pulp cavity also looks similar 
to that of the mandibular canine. The majority of these teeth have 
one canal, but two or three canals are possible (see Fig. 13.20A, 
9; D, 18).
summary: The mandibular first premolar resembles a small mandibular canine with an extra small cusp and typically has one canal, but two or three canals are possible.

text:
The pulp horn of the buccal cusp is prominent in some teeth 
(see Fig. 13.20A, 1, 2, 4, and 6 to 9; D, 10 to 18). The pulp horn 
of the lingual cusp may be prominent but small (see Fig. 13.20D, 
15 to 17) or vestigial (see Fig. 13.20A, 1, 4, and 6 to 9; D, 10 to 
12), or it may be completely absent (see Fig. 13.20A, 2, 3, and 5; 
D, 14 and 18).
summary: The prominence of pulp horns in buccal and lingual cusps of teeth varies, with some being prominent, small, vestigial, or completely absent.

text:
The pulp chamber is usually very large. The pulp cavity may 
taper gently toward the apex (see Fig. 13.20A, 2, 3, 5, and 6; D, 
12 and 13) or abruptly as the root canal starts (see Fig. 13.20A, 
1, 4, and 7; D, 11, 17, and 18), or it may gently and abruptly 
constrict in the apical region (see Fig. 13.20A, 2 and 8; D, 10, 14, 
15, and 16).
summary: The pulp chamber in teeth can vary in size and shape, tapering towards the apex or constricting in the apical region.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to exit at the apex (see Fig. 
13.20A, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 9; D, 10 to 13 and 18) or slightly to the
summary: The apical foramen typically exits at the apex of the tooth.

text:
buccal (see Fig. 13.20A, 8; D, 14 to 16) or lingual aspect of the 
root tip (see Fig. 13.20A, 1 and 4; D, 17).
summary: The text describes the buccal or lingual aspect of the root tip.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.20B and E)
The pulp horn is prominent and may be very fine at its occlusal 
extent (see Fig. 13.20B, 6 and 9; E, 12 and 18). The pulp chamber 
and root canal taper gently to the apex.
summary: Description of the mesiodistal section of a tooth showing a prominent pulp horn and gentle tapering of the pulp chamber and root canal.

text:
The apical foramen may appear to exit at the tip of the root (see 
Fig. 13.20B, 3, 5, 8, and 9; E, 11, 14, 17, and 18) or on the buccal 
or lingual aspect of the root (see Fig. 13.20B, 1, 2, 4, 6, and 7; E, 
10, 12, 13, 15, and 16).
summary: The apical foramen can exit at the tip of the root or on the buccal/lingual aspect.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.20C)
The crown and root sizes of the mandibular premolars vary con-
siderably, and the pulp cavities vary proportionately. The outline 
form of the root may be oval (see Fig. 13.20C, 2, 6, and 9), rectan-
gular (see Fig. 13.20C, 1, 3, and 4), or triangular (see Fig. 13.20C, 
5, 7, and 8).
summary: Mandibular premolars have varying crown and root sizes, leading to different pulp cavity shapes.

text:
The pulp cavity may be rounded (see Fig. 13.20C, 5), ellip-
tical (see Fig. 13.20C, 1, 3, 4, 6, 8, and 9), or triangular (see 
Fig. 13.20C, 7), depending on the external shape of the root. If 
two separate canals are present and the cross section is below the
summary: The shape of the pulp cavity varies depending on the external shape of the root, being rounded, elliptical, or triangular.

distal aspect of the pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal

namel junction, exposing the pulp chamber. These are the openings to root canals that will be seen in the 
floor of the pulp chamber. (D) Labiolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. 
(E) Mesiodistal section, exposing the labial or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.

text:

CHAPTER 13    Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
bifurcation level, two or three round canals would be seen rather 
than elliptical or ribbon-shaped canals.
summary: At the bifurcation level, two or three round canals are typically seen instead of elliptical or ribbon-shaped canals.

text: Mandibular Second Premolar
summary: The mandibular second premolar is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Buccolingual Section (Fig. 13.21A and D)
The mandibular second premolar has a larger crown and root 
than the first premolar. The dimensions of the pulp cavities are 
increased, but the extremely wide dimensions are confined to the 
crown and the upper portion of the root canal. Another difference 
between the first and second premolars is that the pulp horns in 
the second premolar tend to be more prominent and the lingual 
pulp horn is more often present.
summary: Comparison of mandibular first and second premolars in terms of crown and root size, pulp cavity dimensions, and prominence of pulp horns.

text:
The pulp horns are prominent in most of the teeth (see Fig. 
13.21A, 1, 2, 3, 7, and 9; D, 10, 13, 16, and 17), but the lingual 
pulp horn may be vestigial (see Fig. 13.21A, 4 to 6; D, 11, 12, 14, 
15, and 16) or nonexistent (see Fig. 13.21A, 8).
summary: The text describes the prominence of pulp horns in teeth, with lingual pulp horns being vestigial or nonexistent in some cases.

text:
The pulp chambers are usually large and may abruptly constrict 
(see Fig. 13.21A, 1, 2, 4, 5, 7, and 8; D, 11, 13, 14, 16, and 18) 
or gently taper into the pulp canal (see Fig. 13.21A, 1, 3, 6, and 9; 
D, 10, 12, 15, and 17).
summary: Description of the variations in size and shape of pulp chambers in dental anatomy.

text:
The apical foramen may appear to exit at the apex (see Fig. 13.21A, 
1 to 6, 8, and 9; D, 10 to 14, 16, and 17) or on the buccal or lingual 
aspect of the root tip (see Fig. 13.21A, 7; D, 15 and 18).
summary: The apical foramen can exit at the apex or on the buccal or lingual aspect of the root tip.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.21B and E)
The mandibular second premolar is very similar to the mandibular 
first premolar except that the overall dimensions of the second 
premolar are slightly larger. In general the mesiodistal cross sec-
tion of the mandibular premolars and the canine are similar. The 
mandibular second premolar usually has one root and canal that 
may be curved, but generally in the distal direction.
summary: Comparison of mandibular second premolar to first premolar in terms of dimensions and root canal characteristics.

text:
The pulp horns are prominent, and the pulp chamber and root 
canal gently taper toward the apex. The apical foramen appears to 
exit at the tip of the root in the majority of cases.
summary: Description of the anatomy of pulp horns, pulp chamber, root canal, and apical foramen in teeth.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.21C)
The amount of root structure is substantial in the mandibular sec-
ond premolar, as is clearly demonstrated in the cervical cross sec-
tion. The outline form of the root is rectangular (see Fig. 13.21C, 
1, 3, 6, 8, and 9), oval (see Fig. 13.21C, 4 and 7), or triangular (see 
Fig. 13.21C, 2 and 5).
summary: The cervical cross section of the mandibular second premolar shows substantial root structure with rectangular, oval, or triangular outlines.

• Fig. 13.19  Mandibular canine. (A) Labiolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp 
cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing the labial 
or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Cervical cross section at the cementoenamel junction, exposing the 
pulp chamber. These are the openings to root canals that will be seen in the floor of the pulp chamber. (D) 
Labiolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) Mesiodistal section, expos-
ing the labial or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the mandibular canine pulp cavity.

text:
207
CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
The pulp cavity generally follows the outline of the tooth unless 
multiple canals are present (see Fig. 13.21C, 6).
summary: The pulp cavity of a tooth typically follows its outline, unless multiple canals are present.

text: Mandibular First Molar
summary: The mandibular first molar is a key tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Buccolingual Section (Fig. 13.22A and D)
The buccolingual cross section of the mandibular first molar dem-
onstrates a large pulp chamber that may extend well down into 
the root formation (see Fig. 13.22A, 1 and 2; D, 16 and 18). 
The mesial root usually has a more complicated root canal system 
because of the presence of two canals. The distal root usually has 
one large canal, but two canals are often present. Occasionally 
there is a fourth canal that has its own separate root.
summary: The buccolingual cross section of the mandibular first molar shows a large pulp chamber with varying root canal systems.

text:
The pulp horns are quite prominent in most mandibular first 
molars (see Fig. 13.22A, 1, 2, 5, 6, 8, and 9; D, 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, 
17, and 18), but the pulp horns of some of mandibular first molars 
are quite small (see Fig. 13.22A, 3, 4, and 7; D, 13 and 16). The 
pulp chambers of the mesial roots are square to rectangular (exclud-
ing the pulp horns) (see Fig. 13.22A, 1, 2, 4, 6, 7, and 9; D, 10, 11, 
12, 14, 16, and 18), but this configuration is not seen in a root with 
a single canal (see Fig. 13.22A, 3 and 8; D, 13, 15, and 17).
summary: Description of pulp horns and chambers in mandibular first molars.

text:
One or both of the mesial canals may be significantly curved 
(see Fig. 13.22A, 1 and 2; D, 16 and 18), moderately curved (see 
Fig. 13.22A, 4 and 6; D, 10, 12, and 14), or relatively straight (see 
Fig. 13.22A, 7 and 9). The two canals may join each other in the 
apical region to exit in a common foramen (see Fig. 13.22A, 1, 2, 
and 6; D, 14), or they may have separate apical foramina (see Fig. 
13.22A, 4, 7, and 9; D, 10, 12, 16, and 18).
summary: Mesial canals in teeth can vary in curvature and may join together or have separate apical foramina.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to exit on the tip of the 
broad mesial root (see Fig. 13.22A, 1, 2, 4, 6, 7, and 9; D, 10, 14, 
and 16), but in some roots one of the two canals exits on the side 
of the root tip (see Fig. 13.22D, 12 and 18). The diameter of the 
mesial canals is usually very small and demonstrates a slight taper.
summary: The apical foramen of mesial root canals in some cases exits on the side of the root tip with small diameter and slight taper.

text:
The distal root usually has one large pulp chamber, which is very 
wide in the buccolingual dimension (see Fig. 13.22A, 3, 5, and 8; 
D, 15 and 17), whereas other distal roots may possess a pulp cham-
ber that is more constricted (see Fig. 13.22D, 11 and 13). The distal 
root usually has one large pulp canal, which may show a consider-
able buccolingual dimension until the canal constricts abruptly a 
few millimeters from the apex of the root (see Fig. 13.22A, 3, 5 and 
8; D, 17). A constriction of the canal in the last few millimeters 
of the root is not always present (see Fig. 13.22D, 15). When two
summary: Description of the pulp chamber and canal in the distal root of teeth.

the pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing 
the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Cervical cross section at the cementoenamel junction, 
exposing the pulp chamber. These are the openings to root canals that will be seen in the floor of the pulp 
chamber. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) Mesiodistal 
section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the mandibular first premolar showing the pulp cavity and root canals.

text:
208
CHAPTER 13    Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
canals are present, they will be partially or completely separated by a 
dentinal island (see Fig. 13.22D, 11). The apical foramen of a root 
with a single canal usually appears to be located at the apex of the 
root (see Fig. 13.22A, 3 and 8; D, 13), but it may be slightly buccal 
or lingual to this apex (see Fig. 13.22A, 5; D, 15 and 17).
summary: Description of the location of apical foramen in roots with single canals.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.22B and E)
The mesiodistal section of the mandibular first molar presents few 
variations in the form of the pulp chamber or canals. The mesial 
and distal pulp cavities have canals and chambers that are centered 
within the roots and crowns.
summary: The mesiodistal section of the mandibular first molar shows few variations in the pulp chamber or canals, with chambers centered within the roots and crowns.

text:
The pulp horns may be prominent (see Fig. 13.22B, 8; E, 11, 
14, and 15), be moderately evident (see Fig. 13.22B, 2, 3, 6, and 
7; E, 12), be barely detectable (see Fig. 13.22B, 4; E, 13 and 16), 
or demonstrate a combination of these variations (see Fig. 13.22B, 
1 and 9; E, 17 and 18).
summary: The text describes variations in the prominence of pulp horns in dental anatomy.

text:
The pulp chambers are usually rectangular (excluding the pulp 
horns) and may be large (see Fig. 13.22B, 1, 4 to 7, and 9; E, 10 
to 18), or very small (see Fig. 13.22B, 2, 3, and 8).
summary: The pulp chambers in teeth can vary in size and shape, often being rectangular and either large or very small.

text:
The mesial root and canal usually show considerable curvature 
(see Fig. 13.22B, 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, and 9; E, 12, 13, 15, 16, and 18). 
Some canals demonstrate less curvature (see Fig. 13.22B, 6; E, 10,
summary: The mesial root and canal in dental anatomy exhibit varying degrees of curvature.

text:
11, 14, and 17). Extensive secondary or reactive dentin deposition 
may also be seen (see Fig. 13.22B, 2).
summary: The text discusses extensive secondary or reactive dentin deposition.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to exit at the tip of the root 
(see Fig. 13.22B, 1, 5, 7, and 8; E, 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, and 17) but 
may appear to exit on the mesial (see Fig. 13.22B, 2, 4, 6, and 9; 
E, 16) or on the distal aspect of the root (see Fig. 13.22B, 3).
summary: The location of the apical foramen in a tooth can vary, appearing at the tip, mesial, or distal aspect of the root.

text:
The distal root is usually straighter and tends to be a little 
shorter than the curved mesial root (see Fig. 13.22B, 1, 3, 6, and 
8; E, 12, 14, and 15); however, it may be the same length (see Fig. 
13.22B, 2, 4, and 7; E, 10, 11, 13, 16, 17, and 18) or even slightly 
longer (see Fig. 13.22B, 5 and 9). The distal canal is usually larger 
than the mesial canal (see Fig. 13.22B, 2, and 4 to 7; E, 11, 14, 15, 
16, and 18), but the canals may look very similar in size viewed 
from the buccal aspect (see Fig. 13.22B, 1, 3, 8, and 9; E, 10, 12, 
13, and 17).
summary: Description of the differences in size and shape between distal and mesial roots and canals in dental anatomy.

text:
The distal canal usually tapers gently to the apical constriction. 
The apical foramen most often appears to be located on the distal 
aspect of the root (see Fig. 13.22B, 2, 3, 5, 7, and 8; E, 13, 16, 
and 17). In some teeth, this distal deviation is quite marked (see 
Fig. 13.22B, 5 and 7; E, 13 and 17). Mesial deviation of the canal 
does occur (see Fig. 13.22B, 6); however, it is usually only a minor 
deviation. The apical foramen of the distal root will often appear
summary: The distal canal in teeth usually tapers gently to the apical constriction, with the apical foramen typically located on the distal aspect of the root.

• Fig. 13.21  Mandibular second a premolar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect 
of the pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, expos-
ing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Cervical cross section at the cementoenamel junc-
tion, exposing the pulp chamber. These are the openings to root canals that will be seen in the floor of 
the pulp chamber. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) 
Mesiodistal section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of a mandibular second premolar showing pulp cavity anatomy.

text:
209
CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and physiology of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
to be located at the tip of the root (see Fig. 13.22B, 1; E, 10, 11, 
12, 14, 15, and 18).
summary: Description of the location of the tip of the root in a dental anatomy diagram.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.22C, 1 to 5)
The cervical cross section of the mandibular first molar is gener-
ally quadrilateral in form. Distally, it tapers a little from the wider 
buccolingual measurement of the mesial aspect of the tooth. The 
pulp chamber’s outline generally follows that of the root (see Fig. 
13.22C, 1, 2, and 5) but may show buccal (see Fig. 13.22C, 3) 
and/or lingual (see Fig. 13.22C, 4) projections of dentin if the 
pulp chamber is excessively narrowed by secondary or reactive 
osteodentin.
summary: The cervical cross section of the mandibular first molar is generally quadrilateral in form and may show buccal and/or lingual projections of dentin if the pulp chamber is excessively narrowed.

text:
The pulp chamber’s floor has two small funnel-shaped open-
ings into the mesial root (one buccal and one lingual), whereas the 
distal aspect of the pulp chamber usually shows a single opening 
that is less constricted.
summary: Description of the openings in the pulp chamber floor of mesial and distal roots.

text:
Midroot Cross Section (see Fig. 13.22C, 6 to 9)
The midroot view of the mandibular molar usually demonstrates 
the root canal form, which is consistent with the major form of 
this tooth.
summary: The midroot view of the mandibular molar shows the root canal form consistent with the major form of this tooth.

text:
The mesial root usually is somewhat kidney-shaped, with two 
separate canals (see Fig. 13.22C, 7 and 9), but a figure-eight 
shape of the root is also very common (see Fig. 13.22C, 6 and
summary: The mesial root of a tooth can have a kidney-shaped or figure-eight shape with two separate canals.

text:
8). The two canals may be totally separate (see Fig. 13.22C, 6 
and 8), or one may be confluent with the other canal (see Fig. 
13.22C, 7 and 9). Even three canals may be found in this root 
on occasion.
summary: Root canals in a tooth may be separate or confluent with each other, and occasionally three canals may be present in a single root.

text:
The distal root is usually rounder than the mesial root (see 
Fig. 13.22C, 7 and 9), but a very wide root is also common 
(see Fig. 13.22C, 6 and 8). Those roots that tend to be round 
usually demonstrate only one canal, whereas the broader distal 
roots tend to have two canals (see Fig. 13.22C, 6 and 8) or a 
very thin canal that is single; they may also possess a dentinal 
island (see Fig. 13.22C, 8). Even in a root with a single canal, 
the distal canal tends to show a developmental depression or 
concavity on the mesial aspect of the root (see Fig. 13.22C, 7 
and 9).
summary: The distal root of a tooth can vary in shape and number of canals, with rounder roots typically having one canal and wider roots having two canals or a thin single canal.

text: Mandibular Second Molar
summary: The mandibular second molar is a specific tooth in the lower jaw.

text:
Anatomically, the mandibular second molar has many similarities 
with the mandibular first molar (Fig. 13.23). The proportions of 
the crown and root are very similar to those of the mandibular first 
molar. The roots of the second molar may be straighter with less 
divergence from the furcation than in the first molar. The roots 
may be shorter, but there is no assurance that any of these differ-
ences will be manifested in any one tooth.
summary: The mandibular second molar shares many anatomical similarities with the mandibular first molar, including similar crown and root proportions.

text:
• Fig. 13.22  Mandibular first molar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the 
pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing the 
buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Five cross sections at the cervical line and four cross sec-
tions at the midroot. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) 
Mesiodistal section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the mandibular first molar and its pulp cavity.

text:
210
CHAPTER 13    Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and physiology of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
Buccolingual Section (see Fig. 13.23A and D)
The buccolingual section of the mandibular second molar demon-
strates a pulp chamber and pulp canals that tend to be more vari-
able and complex than those found in the mandibular first molar.
summary: The buccolingual section of the mandibular second molar shows more variable and complex pulp chamber and pulp canals compared to the mandibular first molar.

text:
The pulp horns of the mandibular second molar are usually 
rather prominent (see Fig. 13.23A, 1, 3, 5, 6, 8, and 9; D, 10, 13, 
14, 15, 17, and 18), but some pulp horns may be small to nonex-
istent (see Fig. 13.23A, 2, 4, and 7; D, 11, 12, and 16). The pulp 
chamber of the mesial root (see Fig. 13.23A, 1, 3, 5, 6, and 8; D, 
12, 13, 14, 16, 17, and 18) is well demarcated because of the pres-
ence of two canals. The pulp chamber (excluding the pulp horns) 
may be somewhat square (see Fig. 13.23A, 1, 3, and 8; D, 10, 12, 
14, 16, 17, and 18) or rectangular (see Fig. 13.23A, 5 and 6; D, 13).
summary: Description of the pulp horns and chamber of the mandibular second molar.

text:
Two root canals are usually present in the mesial root, but 
only one may be present. The mesial canals may be large (see Fig. 
13.23A, 1; D, 17 and 18), medium (see Fig. 13.23A, 3, 5, 6, 
and 8; D, 13), or small (see Fig. 13.23D, 12, 14, and 16). The 
curvature of these canals may be severe (see Fig. 13.23A, 1; D, 
13), moderate (see Fig. 13.23A, 5 and 8; D, 12 and 16), virtually 
absent (see Fig. 13.23D, 14 and 18), or a combination of these 
variations (see Fig. 13.23A, 3 and 6; D, 17). Most of the canals 
appear to exit from the mesial root separately (see Fig. 13.23A, 3,
summary: The mesial root of a tooth may have two root canals, which can vary in size and curvature.

text:
5, 6, and 8; D, 12, 13, 14, 16, and 18), but some join just before 
reaching the apex, so that a common canal exits from the apex (see 
Fig. 13.23A, 1; D, 17).
summary: Some root canals in teeth join just before reaching the apex, resulting in a common canal exiting from the apex.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to be located at the tip of 
the root (see Fig. 13.23A, 1, 3, and 6; D, 12, 17, and 18), but 
some appear to exit slightly to the buccal or lingual aspect of the 
apex of the root (see Fig. 13.23A, 5 and 8; D, 14 and 16).
summary: The apical foramen is typically located at the tip of the root, but can also exit slightly to the buccal or lingual aspect.

text:
The pulp chamber of the distal root of the mandibular second 
molar is not as easily identified because of the extremely large pulp 
canal that is usually present (see Fig. 13.23A, 2, 4, 7, and 9; D, 11 
and 15). One canal is usually present in the distal root, but two 
totally or partially separate canals are possible (see Fig. 13.23D, 10).
summary: The pulp chamber of the distal root of the mandibular second molar may have a large pulp canal with one or two separate canals.

text:
Pulp horns may be present, but they are not nearly as promi-
nent as in the mesial root (see Fig. 13.23A, 2, 4, 7, and 9; D, 11 
and 15) unless two canals are present (see Fig. 13.23D, 10).
summary: Pulp horns in the distal root are less prominent compared to the mesial root, unless two canals are present.

text:
The pulp canal is usually very large in the mesiobuccal sections. 
The pulp canal may taper gently from the pulp chamber until the 
apical constriction (see Fig. 13.23A, 2 and 7; D, 10 and 15), or an 
abrupt constriction of the canal may occur in the last 2 to 3 mm 
of the canal (see Fig. 13.23A, 4 and 9; D, 11). The apical foramen 
often appears to be located at the tip of the root (see Fig. 13.23A, 
1, 4, 7, and 9; D, 10, 11, and 15).
summary: The pulp canal in the mesiobuccal sections may taper gently or have an abrupt constriction towards the apical foramen.

text:
• Fig. 13.23  Mandibular second molar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of 
the pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing 
the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Five cross sections at the cervical line and four cross 
sections at the midroot. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. 
(E) Mesiodistal section, exposing the buccal aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of the mandibular second molar and its pulp cavity.

text:
211
CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and physiology of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.23B and E)
The mesiodistal sections of the mandibular second molar are very 
similar to those of the mandibular first molar. However, the roots 
of the mandibular first molar tend to be straighter and closer 
together (less furcation deviation).
summary: Comparison of mesiodistal sections of mandibular second molar and mandibular first molar roots.

text:
The pulp horns are usually prominent (see Fig. 13.23B, 1, 2, 3, 
5, 7, 8, and 9; E, 10, 11, 13, 15, and 18), but some are small or 
absent (see Fig. 13.23B, 4 and 6; E, 12, 14, 16, and 17).
summary: The text describes the prominence of pulp horns in teeth, with some being small or absent.

text:
The pulp chamber is rectangular (excluding the pulp horns). 
The size of the chamber varies from very large (see Fig. 13.23B, 1, 
3, 4, 5, 7, and 9; E, 13 and 16) to very small (see Fig. 13.23B, 2 
and 8; E, 11, 14, 17, and 18).
summary: The pulp chamber in teeth can vary in size from very large to very small.

text:
The curvature of the mesial canal may be severe (see Fig. 
13.23B, 3, 6, 8, and 9; E, 11, 14, 16, and 17), moderate (see Fig. 
13.23B, 2, 4, and 7; E, 10, 13, 15, and 18), or essentially straight 
(see Fig. 13.23B, 1 and 5; E, 12). The canals gently taper from the 
pulp chamber to the apical constriction.
summary: The mesial canal can have varying degrees of curvature and tapers gently towards the apical constriction.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to be located at the tip of 
the root (see Fig. 13.23B, 2, 4 through 7, and 8; E, 11, 12, 13, 15, 
17, and 18), but the foramen may appear to be located mesially 
(see Fig. 13.23B, 3; E, 10, 13, and 16) or distally (see Fig. 13.23B, 
9; E, 14) on the root tip.
summary: The location of the apical foramen in a tooth root can vary, appearing at the tip, mesially, or distally.

text:
The distal canal may be slightly curved (see Fig. 13.23B, 1 
to 5, and 7; E, 11, 14, and 16) or straight (see Fig. 13.23B, 4, 
6, 8, and 9; E, 10, 12, 13, 17, and 18). The distal root may be 
slightly shorter than (see Fig. 13.23B, 1, 2, 4, and 7), equal to 
(see Fig. 13.23B, 3, 5, and 6; E, 10, 13, 14, 16, and 17), or 
longer than (see Fig. 13.23B, 8 and 9; E, 11, 12, 15, and 18) 
the mesial root.
summary: Description of variations in curvature and length of distal root compared to mesial root in dental anatomy.

text:
The distal canal is usually larger than the mesial canals (see Fig. 
13.23B, 3, 4, and 6 to 9; E, 11, 13, 15, and 16) but may be equal to 
the mesial canals (see Fig. 13.23B, 1, 2, and 5; E, 12, 14, and 18). 
The distal canal tapers gently to the apex.
summary: The distal canal in teeth may vary in size compared to mesial canals and tapers gently to the apex.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to be located at the tip of 
the root (see Fig. 13.23B, 1 to 7; E, 10 to 13, 16, and 18), but the 
foramen may appear to exit mesially (see Fig. 13.23B, 9) or dis-
tally (see Fig. 13.23B, 8; E, 14, 15, and 17) to the apex of the root.
summary: The location of the apical foramen in a tooth can vary, appearing at the tip of the root or exiting mesially or distally.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.23C, 1 to 5)
The cervical cross section of the mandibular second molar is simi-
lar to that of the mandibular first molar (see Fig. 13.23C, 1 to 5). 
The outline form of the mandibular second molar is more trian-
gular (rather than quadrilateral, like that of the mandibular first 
molar) because of the smaller dimensions that are usually seen in 
the distal aspect of this tooth. The pulp chamber also tends to be 
triangular. The floor of the pulp chamber may have two open-
ings, one mesially and one distally, which are centered within the 
dentin. If only one canal is present in the distal root, it will be 
centered within the dentin.
summary: The cervical cross section of the mandibular second molar is similar to the first molar but more triangular due to smaller dimensions, with a triangular pulp chamber and potentially two openings in the floor.

text:
Midroot Cross Section (see Fig. 13.23C, 6 to 9)
Midroot cross sections of the mandibular molars demonstrate that 
the mesial root is very broad buccolingually and narrow mesiodis-
tally (see Fig. 13.23C, 6 to 9). The outline form is kidney-shaped 
(see Fig. 13.23C, 6 and 7) or slightly in the form of a figure eight 
(see Fig. 13.23C, 8 and 9).
summary: Midroot cross sections of mandibular molars show a broad buccolingual mesial root with a kidney-shaped outline or slightly in the form of a figure eight.

text:
The canals may be totally separate (see Fig. 13.23C, 9) or con-
fluent (see Fig. 13.23C, 6, 7, and 8), which makes it difficult to 
determine the presence of two mesial canals (see Fig. 13.23C, 8). 
The distal root may be rounder than the mesial root because the 
outline form of this root is usually oval (see Fig. 13.23C, 6 and 9);
summary: Description of variations in root canal anatomy with potential challenges in identifying mesial canals.

text:
however, broad distal roots are also seen (see Fig. 13.23C, 7 and 
8). One canal is usually present in the distal root, but two canals 
are often present.
summary: The text discusses the presence of one or two canals in broad distal roots of teeth.

text: Mandibular Third Molar
summary: The mandibular third molar is a tooth located at the back of the lower jaw.

text:
The pulp cavities of the mandibular third molar vary greatly (Fig. 
13.24). The pulp cavity resembles the second mandibular molar 
most, but the crown looks too large for the roots, which may be 
shorter and curved and tend to be fused.
summary: The pulp cavities of the mandibular third molar vary greatly in size and shape, resembling the second mandibular molar but with a crown that appears too large for the roots.

text:
Buccolingual Section (see Fig. 13.24A and D)
In the buccolingual section, the pulp cavities of the mandibular 
third molar show a great deal of variation. Two roots and three 
canals are often present (see Fig. 13.24B, 6 and 7), but two canals 
or two roots are also possible (see Fig. 13.24C, 8 and 9). One 
canal and one root can also be found, but usually these teeth are 
not of much value for restorative purposes because they have short 
roots that taper quickly.
summary: The buccolingual section of mandibular third molars can have varying numbers of roots and canals, affecting their restorative value.

text:
Most mandibular third molars have prominent pulp horns (see 
Fig. 13.24A, 1, 2, and 4 to 9; D, 10, 11, 12, 14, 15, 17, and 18), 
although others demonstrate small to nonexistent pulp horns (see 
Fig. 13.24A, 3; D, 13 and 16).
summary: Mandibular third molars can have prominent or small to nonexistent pulp horns.

text:
The mesial roots of most mandibular third molars (see Fig. 
13.24A, 2 and 9; D, 10, 11, 13, and 14) demonstrate a square 
pulp chamber (excluding the pulp horns). The mesial root usually 
has two canals (see Fig. 13.24A, 2, 5, and 9; D, 10, 11, and 14), 
but a single mesial root can be found (see Fig. 13.24D, 14). The 
canals may be very curved (see Fig. 13.24A, 5 and 9; D, 10) or 
relatively straight (see Fig. 13.24A, 2; D, 11 and 13) as they taper 
gently toward the apical constriction.
summary: Mesial roots of mandibular third molars typically have a square pulp chamber and two canals, although a single canal is possible, with varying degrees of curvature towards the apex.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to be located on the tip of 
the root (see Fig. 13.24A, 1 and 5; D, 10, 11, and 13), but it may 
be located buccally (see Fig. 13.24A, 9; D, 14) or lingually to the 
tip of the root. If two canals are present, they usually possess sepa-
rate apical foramina (see Fig. 13.24A, 2 and 5; D, 10, 11, and 13), 
but some canals join in the apical region, exiting through a com-
mon foramen (see Fig. 13.24A, 9).
summary: The location of the apical foramen in a tooth root can vary, with some teeth having separate apical foramina for each canal while others may have a common foramen.

text:
The distal root of mandibular third molars possesses a very large 
pulp chamber and canal that are difficult to delineate into separate 
areas (see Fig. 13.24A, 1, 3, 4, 6, 7, and 8; D, 12, and 15 to 18).
summary: Mandibular third molars have a complex pulp chamber and canal structure.

text:
The pulp canals, which are very large (see Fig. 13.24A, 1, 4, 6, 
and 7; D, 12, 15, and 18), may taper gently to the root tip (see 
Fig. 13.24A, 4, 6, and 7; D, 16 and 18), or may demonstrate an 
abrupt constriction of the canal in the last few millimeters (see 
Fig. 13.24A, 1; D, 12, 15, and 17).
summary: The pulp canals in teeth can vary in size and shape, tapering gently or demonstrating an abrupt constriction towards the root tip.

text:
The pulp chambers are square or rectangular (excluding the 
pulp horns). The pulp chambers, which are very small (see Fig. 
13.24A, 3 and 8), tend to show a constriction at the junction of 
the pulp chamber and canal, after which they taper gently to the 
apical constriction.
summary: Description of the shape and structure of pulp chambers in teeth.

text:
The apical foramen usually appears to be located at the tip of 
the root (see Fig. 13.24A, 3, 6, 7, and 8; D, 16 and 17), but it may 
be located buccally or lingually to the root tip (see Fig. 13.24A, 1 
and 4; D, 15 and 18).
summary: The apical foramen can be located at the tip of the root or buccally/lingually to the root tip.

text:
Mesiodistal Section (see Fig. 13.24B and E)
The pulp horns of the mandibular third molar may be prominent 
(see Fig. 13.24B, 1 and 5; E, 10, 11, 12, 14, and 15), small (see 
Fig. 13.24A, 4, 6, and 7; D, 17), or nearly absent (see Fig. 13.24B, 
2, 3, 8, and 9; E, 13, 16, and 18).
summary: Description of variations in pulp horns of mandibular third molars.

summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy of pulp chambers and canals.
