text:
• Fig. 13.24  Mandibular third molar. (A) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the 
pulp cavity. This aspect does not appear on the dental radiographs. (B) Mesiodistal section, exposing the 
buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity. (C) Five cross sections at the cervical line and four cross sec-
tions at the midroot. (D) Buccolingual section, exposing the mesial or distal aspect of the pulp cavity. (E) 
Mesiodistal section, exposing the buccal or lingual aspect of the pulp cavity.
summary: Illustrations of different sections of a mandibular third molar and its pulp cavity.

text:
The pulp chambers are usually square or rectangular (excluding 
pulp horns) when viewed from the buccal aspect (see Fig. 13.24B, 
1 to 4, 7, and 9; E, 10, 12, 13, 15, 17, and 18), but they may be 
somewhat square (see Fig. 13.24B, 5; E, 14).
summary: Pulp chambers in teeth are typically square or rectangular when viewed from the buccal aspect.

text:
The degree of curvature of the mesial root may be slight (see 
Fig. 13.24E, 13, single-rooted), moderate (see Fig. 13.24B, 1, 2, 
5, 8, and 9; E, 11, 15, and 17), or severe (see Fig. 13.24B, 3, 4, 6, 
and 7; E, 10, 12, 14, 16, and 18).
summary: The text describes the varying degrees of curvature of the mesial root in different dental cases.

text:
The canal within the mesial root may be large (see Fig. 
13.24B, 2 and 4; E, 10) or very small (see Fig. 13.24B, 1, 3, 
5, 8, and 9; E, 11, 12, and 14 to 18). The canals usually taper 
gently to the apical constriction. The apical foramen may appear 
to be located at the apex of the root (see Fig. 13.24B, 1, 2, 3, 
5, 6, 8, and 9; E, 11, 12, 14, 17, and 18) or mesially (see Fig. 
13.24B, 7) or distally to the apex of the root (see Fig. 13.24B, 
4; E, 10 and 15).
summary: Description of variations in size and location of canals within the mesial root of a tooth.

text:
The length of the mesial roots may be equal to (see Fig. 13.24B, 
2, 3, and 8; E, 10 and 11), shorter than (see Fig. 13.24B, 5 and 9; 
E, 18), or longer than (see Fig. 13.24B, 1, 4, 6, and 7; E, 12, 14, 
15, and 17) the length of the distal root.
summary: Mesial roots can be equal to, shorter than, or longer than the length of the distal root.

text:
The distal canal may be larger than the mesial canal (see Fig. 
13.24B, 2 to 5 and 9; E, 14 and 18), but many are equal in size (see
summary: The distal canal in teeth may vary in size compared to the mesial canal.

text:
Fig. 13.24B, 1, 6, 7, and 8; E, 10, 11, 12, 15, and 17). The distal 
canal gently tapers to the apical constriction (see Fig. 13.24B, 1 
to 8; E, 10 to 18).
summary: The distal canal gently tapers to the apical constriction.

text:
The apical foramen may appear to be located at the apex of 
the root (see Fig. 13.24B, 1 to 5, 7, and 9; E, 10, 11, 12, 15, 17, 
and 18), or it may be mesial (see Fig. 13.24B, 8) or distal (see Fig. 
13.24B, 6; E, 14) to the apex of the root.
summary: The apical foramen can be located at the apex of the root, mesial, or distal to it.

text:
Some teeth show only one root with one or two canals. If only 
one canal is present (see Fig. 13.24E, 13), the canal will be very 
large. If the third molar is multirooted, the canals will be much 
smaller (see Fig. 13.24E, 16).
summary: Teeth can have one or two canals, with larger canals in single-rooted teeth and smaller canals in multirooted teeth.

text:
Cervical Cross Section (see Fig. 13.24C, 1 to 5)
The cervical cross section demonstrates a variable outline form 
that may be rectangular (see Fig. 13.24C, 1 to 4) or triangular (see 
Fig. 13.24C, 5).
summary: The cervical cross section can have a rectangular or triangular outline form.

text:
Midroot Cross Section (see Fig. 13.24C, 6 to 9)
The mesial root, when present, is oval to figure eight in shape 
(see Fig. 13.24C, 6 and 7). The distal root is oval (see Fig. 
13.24C, 6) or kidney-shaped (see Fig. 13.24C, 7). If the roots 
are fused (see Fig. 13.24C, 8) or only one root is present (see
summary: Description of the shape of mesial and distal roots in a midroot cross section.

Fig. 13.24C, 9), the canals are usually larger. The canals in the 
roots that are kidney-shaped or are in the form of a figure eight 
are more ellipsoidal.
summary: Root canals that are kidney-shaped or in the form of a figure eight are more ellipsoidal.

text: Radiographs: Pulp Chamber and Canals
summary: Radiographs are used to visualize the pulp chamber and canals in dentistry.

text:
Visualization of the pulp chamber and pulp canal or canals by 
standard radiography or digital radiography provides the clini-
cian with evidence to augment what has been found clinically. 
All teeth should be examined periodically radiographically and 
clinically. Knowing what might be expected anatomically about 
the pulp chamber and pulp canals, which has been considered 
in a previous section, helps when radiographs are taken. The 
radiographs in Fig. 13.25, A through I illustrate normal pulp 
chambers and pulp canals. They are what are seen generally in 
the dental office, not the highly selected radiographs of the vari-
ous teeth.
summary: Radiographic visualization of pulp chambers and canals aids clinicians in assessing dental health and identifying abnormalities.

text: Crown and Root Fractures
summary: This text block likely discusses crown and root fractures in dentistry.

text:
Fractures of teeth may involve the crown, the crown and root, or the 
root. Probably the most common are fractures of the crown. In some 
cracked teeth, only the enamel is involved; in others, both the enamel 
and dentin may be affected; but initially or later, the pulp also may 
be involved with or without the loss of tooth structure (e.g., cusp). 
In severe trauma, the whole crown may be lost. The clinician should 
be familiar with the most likely places, morphologically, for cracking 
or fractures to occur. The most likely places involve developmental 
grooves (Fig 13.26), often in relation to restorations.
summary: Fractures of teeth can involve the crown, crown and root, or root, with the most common being crown fractures often related to developmental grooves and restorations.

text:
Fractures of cusps of the maxillary first premolar and mandibular 
first molars often occur along developmental grooves or stress lines, 
as shown in Fig. 13.26. Such fractures may occur in connection 
with bruxism and clenching. It is not uncommon for the distolin-
gual cusp of the mandibular first molar to fracture in association 
with a large restoration, which leads to pulpitis (Fig. 13.27).
summary: Fractures of cusps in premolars and molars can occur due to developmental grooves or stress lines, often associated with bruxism and clenching.

CHAPTER 13  Pulp Chambers and Canals
summary: Chapter 13 discusses the anatomy and structure of pulp chambers and canals.

text:
Fractures of the root cause symptoms that resemble those of 
other dental problems; therefore the diagnosis of root fracture may 
be difficult,4 especially when the fracture does not appear on the 
radiograph (Fig. 13.28).
summary: Root fractures can be challenging to diagnose as they may mimic symptoms of other dental issues, particularly when not visible on radiographs.

text:
Fractures may extend from the crown and may reach the pulp 
or involve only the root adjacent to the periodontal ligament. 
Horizontal root fractures are most likely the result of external 
physical trauma or clenching and bruxism. Vertical root fractures 
may be caused by bruxing and clenching or may be the result of 
restorations with endodontic posts in root canals.
summary: Root fractures in teeth can be horizontal or vertical, caused by external trauma, clenching, bruxism, or restorations with endodontic posts.

text:
Relation of Posterior Root Apices to the 
Mandibular Canal
summary: The text discusses the relationship between the posterior root apices and the mandibular canal.

text:
Of interest to the clinician doing endodontics, periapical surgery, 
or placement of implants is the position of the mandibular nerve 
(canal) and the mental foramen.
summary: The position of the mandibular nerve and mental foramen is important for clinicians in endodontics, periapical surgery, and implant placement.

text:
The mandibular nerve traversing the mandible in the mandib-
ular canal occupies different positions relative to the apices of the 
molar and premolar teeth (Fig. 13.29, A to D). In Fig. 13.30, the 
distances from the outer to the inner surface of the buccal plate 
(1), from the inner surface of the cortical plate to the apex of a 
tooth (2), and from the canal to the apex of the tooth (3) reflect 
the data obtained from sections of the mandible.5
summary: The mandibular nerve's position in the mandibular canal varies in relation to the apices of molar and premolar teeth, with distances from outer to inner buccal plate, cortical plate to tooth apex, and canal to tooth apex reflecting data from mandible sections.

text:
The mean width of the buccal plate (see Fig. 13.30B, 1) over 
the premolar is 1.9 ± 0.49 mm; over the first molar, 2.38 ± 0.57 
mm; over the second molar, 5.6 ± 0.93 mm; and over the third 
molar, 2.34 ± 1.0 mm.
summary: The text provides measurements of the mean width of the buccal plate over different teeth.

text:
The mean distance from the inner buccal plate to the apex of 
the tooth (see Fig. 13.30B, 2) for the second premolar is 3.78 ± 
1.04 mm; for the first molar, 4.1 ± 0.98 mm; for the second molar, 
7.1 ± 1.4 mm; and for the third molar, 4.03 ± 1.8 mm.
summary: Mean distances from inner buccal plate to apex of different teeth are provided.

text:
The mean vertical distance from the canal to the apex (see Fig. 
13.30B, 3) for the second premolar is 3.07 ± 0.43 mm; for the first 
molar, 4.03 ± 0.31 mm; for the second molar, 2.5 ± 0.25 mm; and 
for the third molar, 1.96 ± 0.27 mm.
summary: The text provides mean vertical distances from the canal to the apex for different types of teeth.

text:
With regard to the buccolingual alignment of the mandibular 
canal to root apices, the canal is in vertical alignment with the sec-
ond premolars for 65% of the time, slightly lingual to the apices of 
the first molar apices for 71% of the time, in line with the apices 
of second molars for 73% of the time, and in line with the third 
molars for 56% of the time.
summary: The mandibular canal's buccolingual alignment with root apices varies depending on tooth position.

text:
Data are based on the vertical axis of each tooth with the recog-
nition that more than one apex is present. Thus the position of the 
mandibular canal relative to the apices of the teeth tends to follow 
the dotted line in Fig. 13.29.
summary: The position of the mandibular canal relative to the apices of the teeth is depicted in Fig. 13.29.

text:
The position of the mental foramen relative to the mandibular 
premolars and first molar can be described as follows: the foramen 
is between the first and second premolars 33% of the time, in 
line with the second premolar 11% of the time, and distal to the 
second premolar 56% of the time. In terms of vertical position, 
the foramen can be found coronal to the apices 22% of the time, 
at the apices 15% of the time, and below the apices 63% of the 
time.5
summary: The position of the mental foramen relative to mandibular premolars and first molar varies with majority being distal to the second premolar and below the apices vertically.

text: For additional study resources, please visit Expert Consult.
summary: Additional study resources can be found on Expert Consult.

text:
The development of the dentitions has been discussed and a brief 
review of the development of the neurocranium and splanchno-
cranium has been presented in Chapter 2. Therefore, in this chap-
ter, the focus is on the dentoalveolar and dento-osseous structures 
of the permanent dentition. The forms of the roots of the teeth 
and their sizes and angulations govern the shape of the alveoli in 
the jawbones, and this in turn shapes the contour of the dento-
osseous portions facially.
summary: Chapter focuses on the dentoalveolar and dento-osseous structures of the permanent dentition, discussing the roots of the teeth, their sizes, and angulations.

text:
The osseous structures that support the teeth are the maxilla 
and the mandible. The maxilla, or upper jaw, consists of two 
bones: a right maxilla and a left maxilla sutured together at the 
median line. Both maxillae in turn are joined to other bones of 
the head (Fig. 14.1). The mandible, or lower jaw, has no osseous 
union with the skull and is a movable (ginglymoarthrodial) joint.
summary: The maxilla and mandible are the osseous structures that support the teeth, with the maxilla consisting of two bones sutured together and the mandible being a movable joint.

text: The Maxillae
summary: The maxillae are a pair of bones that form the upper jaw and contain the upper teeth.

text:
The maxillae make up a large part of the bony framework of the 
facial portion of the skull. They form the major portion of the roof 
of the mouth, or hard palate, and assist in the formation of the 
floor of the orbit and the sides and base of the nasal cavity. They 
support the 16 permanent maxillary teeth.
summary: The maxillae are a significant part of the facial skull structure, contributing to the roof of the mouth, orbit floor, nasal cavity, and supporting the 16 permanent maxillary teeth.

text:
Each maxilla is an irregular bone, somewhat cuboidal in shape, 
which consists of a body and four processes: the zygomatic, frontal, 
palatine, and alveolar processes. The maxilla is hollow and contains 
the maxillary sinus air space, also called the antrum of Highmore. 
From the dental viewpoint, in addition to its general shape and the 
processes mentioned, several landmarks on this bone are among the 
most important, including the incisive fossa, canine fossa, canine 
eminence, infraorbital foramen, posterior alveolar foramina, maxil-
lary tuberosity, pterygopalatine fossa, and incisive canal.
summary: The maxilla is an irregular bone with various processes and landmarks, including the maxillary sinus and important dental landmarks.

text:
The body of the maxilla has the following four surfaces: ante-
rior or facial, infratemporal, orbital, and nasal.
summary: The maxilla has four surfaces: anterior or facial, infratemporal, orbital, and nasal.

text: Anterior Surface
summary: The text block discusses the anterior surface.

text:
The anterior or facial surface (Figs. 14.2 and 14.3) is separated above 
from the orbital aspect by the infraorbital ridge. Medially, it is lim-
ited by the margin of the nasal notch, and posteriorly, it is separated 
from the posterior surface by the anterior border of the zygomatic 
process, which has a confluent ridge directly over the roots of the 
first molar. The ridge corresponding to the root of the canine tooth 
is usually the most pronounced and is called the canine eminence.
summary: The anterior or facial surface of the maxilla is described in relation to anatomical landmarks such as the infraorbital ridge, nasal notch, zygomatic process, and canine eminence.

text:
Anterior to the canine eminence, overlying the roots of the 
incisor teeth, is a shallow concavity known as the incisive fossa.
summary: The text describes the incisive fossa located anterior to the canine eminence overlying the roots of the incisor teeth.

text: LEARNING OBJECTIVES
summary: Introduction to the learning objectives of the dental textbook.

text: 1.	 Correctly define and pronounce the new terms as empha-
summary: Emphasize the correct definition and pronunciation of new dental terms.

text:
sized in the bold type.
	2.	 Identify the primary bony landmarks of the maxilla and the
summary: Identifying the primary bony landmarks of the maxilla is crucial in dental anatomy.

text:
mandible.
	3.	 Describe the form of the alveoli for each permanent tooth.
	4.	 List the arterial supply for each permanent tooth
	5.	 List the nerve supply to the jaws and teeth.
summary: The text discusses the form of alveoli, arterial supply, and nerve supply for each permanent tooth in the mandible.

text:
218
CHAPTER 14    Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
Posterior to the canine eminence on a higher level is a deeper con-
cavity called the canine fossa. The floor of this canine fossa is 
formed in part by the projecting zygomatic process. Above this 
fossa and below the infraorbital ridge is the infraorbital foramen, 
the external opening of the infraorbital canal. The major portion 
of the canine fossa is directly above the roots of the premolars.
summary: The canine fossa is located posterior to the canine eminence and is formed in part by the zygomatic process, with the infraorbital foramen located above it.

text: Posterior Surface
summary: The posterior surface of a tooth refers to the back side of the tooth.

text:
The posterior or infratemporal surface (Fig. 14.4; see also Fig. 14.3) is 
bounded above by the posterior edge of the orbital surface. Inferiorly 
and anteriorly, it is separated from the anterior surface by the zygo-
matic process and the zygomatic ridge, which runs from the inferior 
border of the zygomatic process to the alveolus of the maxillary first 
molar. This surface is more or less convex and is pierced in a down-
ward direction by two or more posterior alveolar foramina. These two 
canals are on a level with the lower border of the zygomatic process 
and are somewhat distal to the roots of the third molar.
summary: The posterior or infratemporal surface of the maxilla is described in relation to surrounding structures and features such as alveolar foramina.

text:
The inferior portion of this surface is more prominent where 
it overhangs the root of the third molar and is called the maxil-
lary tuberosity. Medially, this tuberosity is limited by a sharp, 
irregular margin that articulates with the pyramidal process of the 
palatine bone and, in some cases, the lateral pterygoid plate of the 
sphenoid bone. The maxillary tuberosity is the origin for some 
fibers of the medial pterygoid muscle.
summary: The maxillary tuberosity is a prominent structure on the inferior surface of the maxilla, serving as the origin for some fibers of the medial pterygoid muscle.

text:
A portion of the infratemporal surface superior to the maxil-
lary tuberosity is the anterior boundary to the pterygomaxillary 
fissure.
summary: The infratemporal surface superior to the maxillary tuberosity serves as the anterior boundary to the pterygomaxillary fissure.

text: Orbital Surface
summary: The orbital surface refers to the portion of the skull that forms the floor of the eye socket.

text:
The orbital surface is smooth and together with the orbital surface 
of the zygomatic bone forms the floor of the orbit. The junction of 
this surface and the anterior surface forms the infraorbital margin 
or ridge, which runs superiorly to form part of the nasal process. 
Its posterior border or edge coincides with the inferior boundary 
of the inferior orbital fissure.
summary: The orbital surface, in conjunction with the zygomatic bone, forms the floor of the orbit and the infraorbital margin.

text:
The thin medial edge of the orbital surface is notched anteri-
orly, forming the lacrimal groove. Behind this groove, it articu-
lates for a short distance with the lacrimal bone, then for a greater 
length with a thin portion of the ethmoid bone, and terminates 
posteriorly in a surface that articulates with the orbital process of 
the palatal bone. Its lateral area is continuous with the base of the 
zygomatic process (see Fig. 14.3).
summary: The orbital surface has a thin medial edge that forms the lacrimal groove and articulates with the lacrimal bone, ethmoid bone, and palatal bone.

text:
• Fig. 14.1  Representation of an adult skull with permanent dentition. The 
maxilla consists of a body and four processes (malar, nasal, alveolar, and 
palatine) that articulate by synarthrosis with cranial and other facial bones 
(e.g., frontal, nasal, ethmoid, malar bones). The mandible articulates with 
the temporal bone by the temporomandibular joint (see Fig. 15.6).
summary: Description of the articulation of the maxilla and mandible with other cranial and facial bones.

summary: The nasal process is a bony projection of the maxilla that contributes to the formation of the nasal cavity.

text: Frontal process
summary: The frontal process is a bony structure of the skull that plays a role in facial anatomy.

text: Orbital surface
summary: The orbital surface is a key anatomical feature relevant to dental surgery.

text: Infra-orbital canal
summary: The infra-orbital canal is a bony canal located beneath the eye socket.

text: Zygomatic process
summary: The zygomatic process is a bony projection of the maxilla that articulates with the zygomatic bone.

text:
Posterior alveolar
foramina
summary: The posterior alveolar foramina are anatomical structures located in the posterior region of the alveolar bone.

text:
Nasal foramen of
incisive canal
summary: The nasal foramen of the incisive canal is a key anatomical feature in the maxilla.

text: Palatine process
summary: The palatine process is a part of the maxilla bone that forms the anterior part of the hard palate.

text: Floor of nose
summary: The floor of the nose is an important anatomical structure in dentistry.

text:
Part of greater
palatine
summary: Part of the greater palatine

text:
Roughened area
for attachment of
palatine bone
summary: The roughened area is for the attachment of the palatine bone.

text: • Fig. 14.4  Posterior view of left maxilla.
summary: Illustration showing the posterior view of the left maxilla.

text:
219
CHAPTER 14  Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
Traversing the posterior portion of the orbital surface is the 
infraorbital groove. This groove begins at the center of the pos-
terior surface and runs anteriorly. The anterior portion of this 
groove is covered, becoming the infraorbital canal, the anterior 
opening of which is located directly below the infraorbital ridge 
on the anterior surface.
summary: The infraorbital groove on the posterior orbital surface transitions into the infraorbital canal on the anterior surface.

text:
If the covered portion of this canal were to be laid open, the 
orifices of the middle and anterior superior alveolar canal would 
be seen transmitting the corresponding vessels and nerves to the 
premolars, canines, and incisor teeth.
summary: The middle and anterior superior alveolar canals transmit vessels and nerves to premolars, canines, and incisor teeth.

text: Nasal Surface
summary: The nasal surface refers to the area of a dental structure that is in contact with the nasal cavity.

text:
The nasal surface (Figs. 14.5 and 14.6) is directed medially toward 
the nasal cavity. It is bordered below by the superior surface of the 
palatine process. Anteriorly, it is limited by the sharp edge of the 
nasal notch. Above and anteriorly, it is continuous with the medial 
surface of the frontal process. Behind this, it is deeply channeled 
by the lacrimal groove, which is converted into a canal by articula-
tion with the lacrimal and inferior turbinate bones.
summary: Description of the nasal surface anatomy and its surrounding structures.

text:
Behind this groove, the upper edge of the nasal surface corre-
sponds to the medial margin of the orbital surface, and the maxilla 
articulates in this region with the lacrimal bone, a thin portion of 
the ethmoid bone, and the orbital process of the palatine bone.
summary: The maxilla articulates with the lacrimal bone, ethmoid bone, and palatine bone in the region of the nasal surface.

text:
The posterior border of the maxilla, which articulates with 
the palatine bone, is traversed obliquely from above downward 
and slightly medially by a groove, which, by articulation with the 
palate bone, is converted into the greater palatine canal. Toward 
the posterior and upper part of this nasal surface, a large, irregu-
lar opening into the maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore) may 
be seen. In an articulated skull, this opening is partially covered 
by the uncinate process of the ethmoid bone and the inferior 
nasal concha.
summary: The text describes the anatomy of the posterior border of the maxilla and its articulation with the palatine bone, including the formation of the greater palatine canal and the presence of the maxillary sinus.

text:
Anterior to the lacrimal groove, the nasal surface is ridged for 
the attachment of the inferior nasal concha. Below this, the bone 
forms a lateral wall of the inferior nasal meatus. Above the ridge 
for a small distance on the medial side of the nasal process, the 
smooth lateral wall of the middle meatus appears.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the nasal surface and meatus in relation to the lacrimal groove.

text: Zygomatic Process
summary: The zygomatic process is a bony projection of the maxilla that articulates with the zygomatic bone.

text:
The zygomatic process may be seen in the lateral views of the max-
illary bone as a roughly triangular eminence whose apex is placed 
inferiorly directly over the first molar roots. The lateral border is 
rough and sponge-like in appearance, where it has been disarticu-
lated from the zygomatic or cheek bone (see Figs. 14.1 and 14.3).
summary: The zygomatic process is a triangular eminence in the maxillary bone seen in lateral views.

text: Frontal Process
summary: The frontal process is a bony structure in the skull that forms part of the nasal cavity and orbits.

text:
The frontal process (see Figs. 14.2 to 14.5) arises from the upper 
and anterior body of the maxilla.
summary: The frontal process arises from the upper and anterior body of the maxilla.

text:
Part of this process is formed by the upward continuation of the 
infraorbital margin medially. Its edge articulates with the nasal bone. 
Superiorly, the process articulates with the frontal bone. The medial 
surface of the frontal process forms part of the lateral wall of the nasal 
cavity. Anteriorly, the frontal process articulates with the nasal bone.
summary: The frontal process of the maxilla articulates with the nasal bone and frontal bone, forming part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

text: Palatine Process
summary: The palatine process is a bony structure in the maxilla that forms the anterior part of the hard palate.

text:
The palatine process (see Figs. 14.2 to 14.8) is a horizontal ledge 
extending medially from the nasal surface of the maxilla. Its supe-
rior surface forms a major portion of the nasal floor. The inferior 
surfaces of the combined left and right palatine processes form 
the hard palate as far posteriorly as the second molar, where they 
articulate with the horizontal parts of the palatine bone (Figs. 14.7 
and 14.8) at the transverse palatine suture.
summary: The palatine process is a horizontal ledge extending from the maxilla, forming a major portion of the nasal floor and contributing to the hard palate.

text:
Portion of
sphenoidal sinus
summary: The text block discusses a portion of the sphenoidal sinus.

text: Frontal process
summary: The frontal process is a bony structure in the skull.

text:
Middle meatus
Lacrimal groove
summary: The middle meatus and lacrimal groove are anatomical structures in the nasal cavity.

text: Conchal crest
summary: The conchal crest is a bony ridge located on the medial surface of the concha of the ear.

text: Inferior meatus
summary: The inferior meatus is a structure in the nasal cavity.

text:
Palatal process at
intermaxillary
suture
summary: The palatal process is located at the intermaxillary suture.

text: Incisive groove
summary: The incisive groove is an anatomical feature found in the maxillary central incisors.

text: Maxillary sinus
summary: The maxillary sinus is a paranasal sinus located in the maxilla bone.

text:
Greater palatine
groove
summary: The greater palatine groove is an anatomical feature in the palate.

text:
Hard palate of
palatal process
summary: The text block describes the hard palate of the palatal process.

text: • Fig. 14.5  Medial view of left maxilla.
summary: Illustration showing the medial view of the left maxilla.

text: Maxillary sinus
summary: The maxillary sinus is an air-filled cavity located within the maxilla bone.

text: Sphenoidal sinus
summary: The sphenoidal sinus is a paranasal sinus located behind the nose and eyes.

text:
Inferior nasal
concha
summary: The text discusses the anatomy of the inferior nasal concha.

text:
Medial lamina of
pterygoid process
summary: The medial lamina of the pterygoid process is a bony structure in the skull.

text: Hard palate
summary: The hard palate is the bony structure that forms the roof of the mouth.

text: Inferior meatus
summary: The inferior meatus is a structure located in the nasal cavity.

text: Incisive canals
summary: The incisive canals are anatomical structures located in the maxilla.

text: • Fig. 14.6  Medial view of right maxilla. This specimen has not been disarticulated completely and has the maxillary teeth in situ.
summary: Illustration of the medial view of the right maxilla with maxillary teeth in place.

text:
220
CHAPTER 14    Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
The inferior surface of the palatine process is rough and pit-
ted for the palatine mucous glands in the roof of the mouth and 
is pierced by numerous small foramina for the passage of blood 
vessels and nerve fibers. At the posterior border of the process is 
a groove or canal that passes the greater palatine nerve and ves-
sels to the palatal soft tissues. The posterior edge of the palatine 
process becomes relatively thin where it joins the palatine bone 
at the point of the greater palatine foramen. The palatine process 
becomes progressively thicker anteriorly from the posterior bor-
der. Anteriorly, the palatal process is confluent with the alveolar 
process surrounding the roots of the anterior teeth.
summary: The inferior surface of the palatine process contains pits for palatine mucous glands and foramina for blood vessels and nerve fibers, with a groove for the greater palatine nerve and vessels.

text:
Immediately posterior to the central incisor alveolus, when 
looking at the medial aspect of the maxilla, one sees a smooth 
groove that is half of the incisive canal, when the two maxil-
lae are joined together. The incisive fossa into which the canals 
open may be seen immediately lingual to the central incisors at 
the median line, or intermaxillary suture where the maxillae are 
joined. Two canals open laterally into the incisive foramen, the 
foramina of Stenson, carrying the nasopalatine nerves and vessels.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the incisive canal and fossa in the maxilla.

text:
Occasionally, two midline foramina are present, the foramina of 
Scarpi.
summary: Occasionally, two midline foramina known as the foramina of Scarpi may be present.

text:
Extending laterally from the incisive foramen to the space 
between the lateral incisor and canine alveoli are the remnants of 
the suture between the maxilla and premaxilla. In most mammals, 
the premaxilla remains an independent bone.
summary: The remnants of the suture between the maxilla and premaxilla extend laterally from the incisive foramen to the space between the lateral incisor and canine alveoli.

text: Alveolar Process
summary: The alveolar process is the part of the jawbone that surrounds and supports the teeth.

text:
The alveolar process makes up the inferior portion of the maxilla; 
it is the portion of the bone that surrounds the roots of the maxil-
lary teeth and that gives them their osseous support. The process 
extends from the base of the tuberosity posterior to the last molar 
to the median line anteriorly, where it articulates with the same 
process of the opposite maxilla (see Figs. 14.7 and 14.8). It merges 
with the palatine process medially and with the zygomatic process 
laterally (see Fig. 14.8).
summary: The alveolar process in the maxilla provides osseous support to the roots of maxillary teeth and articulates with the opposite maxilla, merging with the palatine and zygomatic processes.

text:
When one looks directly at the inferior aspect of the maxilla 
toward the alveoli with the teeth removed, it is apparent that the
summary: The text describes the view of the inferior aspect of the maxilla without teeth present.

text: Zygomatic process
summary: The zygomatic process is a bony projection of the maxilla that articulates with the zygomatic bone.

text: Tuberosity
summary: The tuberosity is a bony prominence located on the maxilla.

text:
Posterior border of palatal
process (point of suture
with horizontal portion
of palatal bone)
summary: Description of the posterior border of the palatal process and its suture point with the horizontal portion of the palatal bone.

text:
Hard palate of
palatal process
summary: The text block describes the hard palate of the palatal process.

text:
Point of intermaxillary
suture
summary: The point of intermaxillary suture is a critical anatomical landmark in dental anatomy.

text: Alveolar process
summary: The alveolar process is the part of the jaw that surrounds and supports the teeth.

text: • Fig. 14.7  Palatine view of maxilla. Note the dental foramina in the deepest portion of the permanent first molar alveolus.
summary: Illustration of palatine view of maxilla showing dental foramina in the deepest portion of the permanent first molar alveolus.

text:
Alveolus of
maxillary central
incisor
Interdental septum
between first and
second premolars
summary: Description of the alveolus of the maxillary central incisor and the interdental septum between first and second premolars.

text: Infra-orbital foramen
summary: The infra-orbital foramen is a bony opening located below the eye socket.

text: Zygomatic process
summary: The zygomatic process is a bony projection of the maxilla that articulates with the zygomatic bone.

text: Zygomatic ridge
summary: The zygomatic ridge is a bony prominence on the lateral aspect of the maxilla.

text:
Interradicular septa
between alveoli of
third molar
summary: Interradicular septa are present between the alveoli of the third molar.

text: Palatine process
summary: The palatine process is a part of the maxilla bone involved in the formation of the hard palate.

text:
Greater palatine
foramen
summary: The greater palatine foramen is an anatomical structure in the palate.

text: • Fig. 14.8  View of inferior surface of the maxilla showing alveolar process and alveoli.
summary: Illustration of the inferior surface of the maxilla displaying the alveolar process and alveoli.

text:
221
CHAPTER 14  Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
alveolar process is curved to conform with the dental arch. It com-
pletes, with its fellow of the opposite side, the alveolar arch sup-
porting the roots of the teeth of the maxilla.
summary: The alveolar process forms a curved structure that supports the roots of the teeth in the maxilla.

text:
The process has a facial (labial and buccal) surface and a lingual 
surface with ridges corresponding to the surfaces of the roots of 
the teeth supported by it. It is made up of labiobuccal and lingual 
plates of very dense but thin cortical bone separated by interdental 
septa of cancellous bone.
summary: The process consists of facial and lingual surfaces with ridges corresponding to tooth roots, made up of dense cortical bone separated by cancellous bone.

text:
The facial plate is thin, and the positions of the alveoli are well 
marked on it by visible ridges as far posteriorly as the distobuccal 
root of the first molar (see Fig. 14.2). The margins of these alve-
oli are frail, and their edges are sharp and thin. The buccal plate 
over the second and third molars, including the alveolar margins, 
is thicker. In general, the lingual plate of the alveolar process is 
heavier than the facial plate. In addition, the alveolar process is 
longer where it surrounds the anterior teeth, sometimes extending 
posteriorly to include the premolars. In short, it extends farther 
down in covering the lingual portion of the roots.
summary: Description of the thickness and positions of the facial and lingual plates of the alveolar process.

text:
The bone is very thick lingually over the deeper portions of the 
alveoli of the anterior teeth and premolars. The merging of the 
alveolar process with the palatal process brings about this forma-
tion. The lingual plate is paper thin over the lingual alveolus of 
the first molar, however, and rather thin over the lingual alveoli 
of the second and third molars. This thin lingual plate over the 
molar roots is part of the formation of the greater palatine canal 
(see Fig. 14.8).
summary: The thickness of the lingual bone varies over different teeth, with the lingual plate being thin over molar roots due to the formation of the greater palatine canal.

text:
The alveolar process is maintained by the presence of the teeth. 
Should any tooth be lost, the portion of the alveolar process that 
supported the missing tooth will be subject to atrophic reduction. 
Should all the teeth be lost, the alveolar process will eventually be 
virtually lost.
summary: Loss of teeth can lead to atrophic reduction of the alveolar process, eventually resulting in its virtual loss.

text: Alveoli (Tooth Sockets)
summary: Alveoli, also known as tooth sockets, are the bony structures in the jaw that hold the roots of the teeth in place.

text:
The alveolar cavities are formed by the facial and lingual plates 
of the alveolar process and by connecting septa of bone placed 
between the two plates. The form and depth of each alveolus are 
determined by the form and length of the root it supports (see 
Table 1.1).
summary: Alveolar cavities are formed by facial and lingual plates of the alveolar process and connecting septa of bone, with their form and depth determined by the root they support.

text:
The alveolus nearest the median line is that of the central inci-
sor (Fig. 14.9; see also Fig. 14.8). The periphery is regular and 
round, and the interior of the alveolus is evenly tapered and trian-
gular in cross section, with the apex toward the lingual.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the alveolus of the central incisor.

text:
The second alveolus in line is that of the lateral incisor. It is 
generally conical and egg-shaped, or ovoid, with the widest por-
tion to the labial. It is narrower mesiodistally than labiolingually 
and is smaller on cross section, although it is often deeper than 
the central alveolus. Sometimes it is curved at the upper extremity 
(Fig. 14.10; see also Fig. 14.8).
summary: Description of the anatomy of the alveolus of the lateral incisor, including its shape and dimensions.

text:
The canine alveolus is the third from the median line. It is 
much larger and deeper than those just described. The periphery 
is oval and regular in outline, with the labial width greater than 
the lingual. The socket extends distally. It is flattened mesially and 
somewhat concave distally. The bone is so frail at the canine emi-
nence on the facial surface of the alveolus that the root of the 
canine is often exposed on the labial surface near the middle third 
(see Fig. 14.2).
summary: Description of the anatomy of the canine alveolus, highlighting its size, shape, and fragility near the canine eminence.

text:
The first premolar alveolus (see Figs. 14.8 and 14.10) is kidney-
shaped in cross section, with the cavity partially divided by a spine 
of bone that fits into the mesial developmental groove of the root 
of this tooth. This spine divides the cavity into a buccal and a lin-
gual portion. If the tooth root is bifurcated for part of its length,
summary: Description of the kidney-shaped cross section of the first premolar alveolus with a dividing spine and bifurcated root.

text:
as is often the case, the terminal portion of the cavity is separated 
into buccal and lingual alveoli. The socket is flattened distally and 
much wider buccolingually than mesiodistally (see Table 1.1).
summary: The terminal portion of the cavity is separated into buccal and lingual alveoli, with the socket being wider buccolingually than mesiodistally.

text:
The second premolar alveolus is also kidney-shaped, but the 
curvatures are in reverse to those of the first premolar alveolus. 
The proportions and depth are almost the same. The septal spine 
is located on the distal side instead of the medial side, because the 
second premolar root is inclined to have a well-defined develop-
mental groove distally. This tooth usually has one broad root with 
a blunt end, but it is occasionally bifurcated at the apical third.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the second premolar alveolus including its shape, curvatures, proportions, depth, septal spine location, and root characteristics.

text:
The first molar alveolus (see Figs. 14.8 and 14.11) is made up 
of three distinct alveoli widely separated. The lingual alveolus is 
the largest; it is round, regular, and deep. The cavity extends in the 
direction of the hard palate, having a lingual plate over it that is 
very thin. The lingual periphery of this alveolus is extremely sharp 
and frail. This condition may contribute to the tissue recession 
often seen at this site.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the first molar alveolus and its potential contribution to tissue recession.

text:
The mesiobuccal and distobuccal alveoli of the first molar have 
no outstanding characteristics except that the buccal plates are 
thin. The bone is somewhat thicker at the peripheries than that 
found on the lingual alveolus. Nevertheless, it is thinner farther 
up on the buccal plate. It is not uncommon for one to find the 
roots uncovered by bone in spots when examining dry specimens.
summary: The buccal plates of the mesiobuccal and distobuccal alveoli of the first molar are thin, with thicker bone at the peripheries and roots sometimes uncovered by bone in dry specimens.

text:
The forms of the buccal alveoli resemble the forms of the roots 
they support. The mesiobuccal alveolus is broad buccolingually, 
with the mesial and distal walls flattened. The distobuccal alveolus 
is rounder and more conical.
summary: The forms of the buccal alveoli vary based on the roots they support, with the mesiobuccal alveolus being broad and the distobuccal alveolus rounder and more conical.

text:
The septa that separate the three alveoli (interradicular septa) 
are broad at the area that corresponds to the root bifurcation, and 
they become progressively thicker as the peripheries of the alveoli
summary: Interradicular septa in dental alveoli are broad at root bifurcation areas and thicken towards the peripheries.

text:
• Fig. 14.9  Alveoli of the central incisor, lateral incisor, and canine. (Case 
and photographs courtesy Lawrence C. Zoller, PhD, Las Vegas, NV.)
summary: Illustration of alveoli of the central incisor, lateral incisor, and canine.

text:
• Fig. 14.10  Alveoli of the premolar area. (Case and photographs courtesy 
Lawrence C. Zoller, PhD, Las Vegas, NV.)
summary: Illustration of alveoli in the premolar area with credit to Lawrence C. Zoller, PhD.

text:
222
CHAPTER 14    Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
are approached. The bone septa are very cancellous, which denotes 
a rich blood supply, as is true of all the septa, including those sepa-
rating the various teeth as well.
summary: The bone septa in the dental anatomy are cancellous and have a rich blood supply.

text:
A general description of the alveoli of the second molar would 
coincide with that of the first molar; these alveoli are closer 
together, since the roots of this tooth do not spread as much. As 
a consequence, the septa separating the alveoli are not as heavy.
summary: The alveoli of the second molar are closer together compared to the first molar due to less root spreading, resulting in lighter septa separating the alveoli.

text:
The third molar alveolus is similar to that of the second molar, 
except that it is somewhat smaller in all dimensions. Fig. 14.11 
shows a third molar socket to accommodate a tooth with three 
well-defined roots, a rare occurrence. Usually, the two buccal (and 
often all three) roots will be fused. The interradicular septum 
changes accordingly. If the roots of the tooth are fused, a septal 
spine will appear in the alveolus at the points of fusion on the 
roots marked by deep developmental grooves.
summary: The third molar alveolus is smaller than the second molar's, often with fused roots and a septal spine if fused.

text: Maxillary Sinus
summary: The maxillary sinus is a paranasal sinus located in the maxillary bone.

text:
The maxillary sinus lies within the body of the bone and is of cor-
responding pyramidal form; the base is directed toward the nasal 
cavity. Its summit extends laterally into the root of the zygomatic 
process. It is closed in laterally and above by the thin walls that 
form the anterolateral, posterolateral, and orbital surfaces of the 
body. The sinus overlies the alveolar process in which the molar 
teeth are implanted, more particularly, the first and second molars, 
the alveoli of which are separated from the sinus by a thin layer 
of bone. Occasionally, the maxillary sinus will extend forward far 
enough to overlie the premolars also. It is not uncommon to find 
the bone covering the alveoli of some of the posterior teeth extend-
ing above the floor of the cavity of the maxillary sinus, forming 
small hillocks.
summary: The maxillary sinus is located within the body of the bone, with its base directed towards the nasal cavity and its summit extending into the root of the zygomatic process.

text:
Regardless of the irregularity and the extension of the alveoli 
into the maxillary sinus, a layer of bone always separates the roots 
of the teeth and the floor of the sinus in the absence of pathologi-
cal conditions. A layer of sinus mucosa is also always between the 
root tips and the sinus cavity.
summary: A layer of bone always separates the roots of the teeth and the floor of the maxillary sinus, with sinus mucosa between the root tips and the sinus cavity.

text: Maxillary Articulation
summary: The maxillary articulation refers to the connection between the maxilla bone and the rest of the skull.

text:
The maxilla articulates with the nasal, frontal, lacrimal, and eth-
moid bones, above and laterally with the zygomatic bone, and 
occasionally with the sphenoid bone. Posteriorly and medially, it 
articulates with the palatal bone. Medially, it supports the inferior 
turbinate and the vomer and articulates with the opposite maxilla.
summary: The maxilla articulates with several bones including the nasal, frontal, and zygomatic bones.

text: The Mandible
summary: The mandible is the lower jawbone in the human skull.

text:
The mandible (Figs. 14.12 to 14.23) is horseshoe-shaped and sup-
ports the teeth of the lower dental arch. This bone is movable 
and has no bony articulation with the skull. It is the heaviest and 
strongest bone of the head and serves as a framework for the floor 
of the mouth. It is situated immediately below the maxillary and 
zygomatic bone, and its condyles rest in the mandibular fossa of 
the temporal bone. This articulation is the temporomandibular 
joint.
summary: The mandible is a horseshoe-shaped bone that supports the lower dental arch and serves as the framework for the floor of the mouth.

text:
The mandible has a horizontal portion, or body, and two verti-
cal portions, or rami. The rami join the body at an obtuse angle.
summary: The mandible consists of a horizontal body and two vertical rami that join at an obtuse angle.

text:
The body consists of two lateral halves, which are joined at the 
median line shortly after birth. The line of fusion, usually marked 
by a slight ridge, is called the symphysis. The body of the man-
dible has two surfaces (one external and one internal) and two 
borders (one superior and one inferior).
summary: Description of the anatomy of the body of the mandible including its surfaces and borders.

text:
To the right and left of the symphysis, near the lower border 
of the mandible, are two prominences called mental tubercles. 
A prominent triangular surface made by the symphysis and these 
two tubercles is called the mental protuberance (see Fig. 14.16).
summary: The mental protuberance is formed by the symphysis and two mental tubercles near the lower border of the mandible.

text:
Immediately posterior to the symphysis and immediately 
above the mental protuberance is a shallow depression called the 
incisive fossa. The fossa is immediately below the alveolar border 
of the central and lateral incisors and anterior to the canines. The 
alveolar portion of the mandible overlying the root of the canine 
is prominent and is called the canine eminence of the mandible. 
However, this eminence does not extend down very far toward the 
lower border of the mandible before it is lost in the prominence 
of the mental protuberance and the lower border of the mandible.
summary: Description of the incisive fossa, canine eminence, and their relation to the mandible's anatomy.

text:
The external surface of the mandible from a lateral viewpoint 
presents a number of important areas for examination.
summary: The external surface of the mandible from a lateral viewpoint presents important areas for examination.

text:
The oblique ridge (oblique line, radiographically) extends 
obliquely across the external surface of the mandible from the 
mental tubercle to the anterior border of the ramus, with which it 
is continuous. It lies below the mental foramen. It is usually not 
prominent except in the molar area (see Fig. 14.12).
summary: The oblique ridge extends across the external surface of the mandible from the mental tubercle to the anterior border of the ramus.

text:
This ridge thins out as it progresses upward and becomes the 
anterior border of the ramus and ends at the tip of the coronoid 
process. The coronoid process is one of two processes making up 
the superior border of the ramus. It is a pointed, flattened, smooth 
projection and is roughened toward the tip to give attachment for 
a part of the temporal muscle.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the coronoid process as part of the superior border of the ramus.

text:
The condyle, or condyloid process, on the posterior border 
of the ramus is variable in form. It is divided into a superior or 
articular portion and an inferior portion, or neck. Although the 
articular portion, the condyle, appears as a rounded knob when 
the mandible is viewed from a lateral aspect, from a posterior 
aspect, the condyle is much wider and oblong in outline (compare 
Figs. 14.12 and 14.13).
summary: The condyle of the mandible has a variable form, with a superior articular portion and an inferior neck, appearing as a rounded knob from a lateral view and wider and oblong from a posterior view.

text:
• Fig. 14.11  Alveoli of the molar area. Note the thinness of the buccal plates 
over the first molar roots compared with those of the second and third 
maxillary molars. The third molar alveoli are rarely separated as distinctly 
as seen in this specimen. Figs. 14.9 to 14.11 demonstrate a number of 
significant points concerning the maxillary alveoli. In Fig. 14.9, the facial 
cortical plate of bone is thin over the anterior teeth and is considerably 
thicker over the posterior teeth, especially the molars. Cancellous bone 
seems to exist buccal to some of the posterior roots. In Fig. 14.10, inter-
radicular septa are thick but with numerous nutrient canals. In Fig. 14.11, 
cancellous bone, furnishing numerous opportunities for blood supply, is 
evident in the apical portions of the alveoli. The anterior alveoli are lined 
laterally with a layer of smooth cortical bone. This lining is less prominent 
in the posterior alveoli.
summary: The text describes the differences in thickness and structure of alveoli in the molar area, highlighting the variations in buccal plates and cortical bone.

text:
223
CHAPTER 14  Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
The condyle is convex, fitting into the mandibular fossa of the 
temporal bone when the mandible is articulated to the skull, and 
forms, with the interarticular cartilage that lies between the two 
surfaces and with the tissue attachment, the temporomandibular 
joint (see Fig. 15.2).
summary: The condyle forms the temporomandibular joint by fitting into the mandibular fossa of the temporal bone.

text:
The neck of the condyle is a constricted portion immediately 
below the articular surface. It is flattened in front and presents 
a concave pit medially, the pterygoid fovea. A smooth, semi-
circular notch, the mandibular notch, forms the sharp upper 
border of the ramus between the condyle and coronoid process 
(see Fig. 14.14).
summary: The neck of the condyle is a constricted portion below the articular surface with specific anatomical features.

text:
The distal border of the ramus is smooth and rounded and 
presents a concave outline from the neck of the condyle to the 
angle of the jaw, where the posterior border of the ramus and the 
inferior border of the body of the mandible join. The border of
summary: Description of the distal border of the ramus of the mandible.

text:
this angle is rough, being the attachment of the masseter muscle 
(see Fig. 15.18) and the stylomandibular ligament (see Fig. 15.7).
summary: The angle mentioned in the text is rough due to the attachment of the masseter muscle and the stylomandibular ligament.

text:
An important landmark on the lateral aspect of the mandible is 
the mental foramen. It should be noted that this opening of the ante-
rior end of the mandibular canal is directed upward, backward, and 
laterally. The foramen is usually located midway between the superior 
and inferior border of the body of the mandible when the teeth are 
in position, and most often, it is below the second premolar tooth, 
a little below the apex of the root. The position of this foramen is 
not constant, and it may be between the first premolar and the sec-
ond premolar tooth. After the teeth are lost and resorption of alveolar 
bone has taken place, the mental foramen may appear near the crest 
of the alveolar border. In childhood, before the first permanent molar 
has come into position, this foramen is usually immediately below the 
first primary molar and nearer to the lower border.
summary: The position of the mental foramen on the lateral aspect of the mandible varies based on tooth position and bone resorption.

CHAPTER 14    Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
It is interesting to note that when the mandible is observed 
from a point directly opposite the first molar, most of the distal 
half of the third molar is hidden by the anterior border of the 
ramus. When the mandible is viewed from in front, directly oppo-
site the median line, the second and third molars are located 5 to 
7 mm lingually to the anterior border of the ramus (compare Figs. 
14.12 and 14.16).
summary: Description of the position of third molars in relation to the mandible from different viewing angles.

text: Internal Surface of the Mandible
summary: The internal surface of the mandible is an important anatomical feature in dentistry.

text:
Observation of the mandible from the rear shows that the median 
line is marked by a slight vertical depression, representing the line
summary: The mandible's median line is marked by a slight vertical depression when viewed from the rear.

text:
of union of the right and left halves of the mandible, and that 
immediately below this, at the lower third, the bone is roughened 
by eminences called the superior and inferior mental spines, or 
genial tubercles (see Figs. 14.15 and 14.34C).
summary: The mandible is formed by the union of its right and left halves, with roughened bone at the lower third containing superior and inferior mental spines.

text:
The internal surface of the body of the mandible is divided 
into two portions by a well-defined ridge: the mylohyoid line. 
It occupies a position closely corresponding to the lateral oblique 
ridge on the surface. It starts at or near the lowest part of the 
mental spines and passes backward and upward, increasing in 
prominence until the anterior portion of the ramus is reached; 
there, it smooths out and gradually disappears (see Figs. 14.14 
and 14.34C).
summary: The internal surface of the mandible is divided by the mylohyoid line, starting at the mental spines and gradually disappearing at the anterior portion of the ramus.

text: • Fig. 14.18  Alveolar process of the mandible showing alveoli.
summary: Illustration of the alveolar process of the mandible with alveoli.

text:
• Fig. 14.19  Closeup view of one of the three separate divisions of the mandibular alveoli (as shown in Figs. 
14.19 to 14.21). This picture indicates the relative sizes and shapes of the incisors for comparison with 
other mandibular teeth.

text:
• Fig. 14.20  This view of the mandibular alveoli includes the canine, the first and second premolars, and a 
clear view of the mandibular first molar alveoli. Note the excellent design for the anchorage of first molar 
roots. Apparently the blood supply for the interseptal bone lessens as anterior teeth are approached. The 
apical portion of the canine alveolus displays the single opening in the bone for the blood and nerve supply 
to the tooth pulp.
summary: Description of the mandibular alveoli anatomy and blood supply in relation to different teeth.

text:
226
CHAPTER 14    Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
This ridge is the point of origin of the mylohyoid muscle, 
which forms the central portion of the floor of the mouth. Imme-
diately posterior to the median line and above the anterior part of 
the mylohyoid ridge, a smooth depression called  the sublingual 
fossa may be seen. The sublingual gland lies in this area.
summary: Description of the mylohyoid muscle origin and the sublingual fossa in the floor of the mouth.

text:
A small, roughened oval depression, the digastric fossa, is 
found on each side of the symphysis immediately below the mylo-
hyoid line and extending onto the lower border. Toward the center 
of the body of the mandible, between the mylohyoid line and the 
lower border of the bone, a smooth oblong depression is located, 
called the submandibular fossa. It continues back on the medial 
surface of the ramus to the attachment of the lateral pterygoid 
muscle. The submandibular gland lies within this fossa.
summary: The mandible contains digastric and submandibular fossae, with the submandibular gland located in the latter.

text:
The mandibular foramen is located on the medial surface of 
the ramus midway between the mandibular notch and the angle 
of the jaw and also midway between the internal oblique line and 
the posterior border of the ramus. The mandibular canal begins at 
this point, passing downward and forward horizontally.
summary: The mandibular foramen is a key anatomical landmark for the mandibular canal.

text:
The anterior margin of the foramen is formed by the lingula, or 
mandibular spine, which gives attachment to the sphenomandibu-
lar ligament. Coming obliquely downward from the base of the fora-
men beneath the lingula is a decided groove, the mylohyoid groove. 
Behind this groove toward the angle of the mandible, a roughened 
surface for the attachment of the medial pterygoid muscle may be seen.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the anterior margin of the mandibular foramen and its surrounding structures.

text: Alveolar Process
summary: The alveolar process is the part of the jawbone that surrounds and supports the teeth.

text:
The border of the alveolar process outlines the alveoli of the 
teeth and is very thin at its anterior portion around the roots 
of the incisor teeth but thicker posteriorly where it encom-
passes the roots of the molars. The alveolar process, which com-
prises the superior border of the body of the mandible, differs 
from the same process in the maxillae in one very important
summary: The alveolar process outlines the alveoli of teeth, being thin at the anterior portion and thicker posteriorly.

text:
• Fig. 14.21  Alveoli of the first, second, and third molars. Features for spe-
cial attention include the thin and perforated surface of the retromolar 
triangular space distal to the third molar alveolus and the cancellous for-
mation in the alveoli proper and also in the interdental septa, which would 
allow a rich blood supply.
summary: Description of alveoli of the first, second, and third molars highlighting thin and perforated surface of the retromolar triangular space and cancellous formation for rich blood supply.

text: A
summary: The text block is incomplete and does not provide any information.

text: B
summary: The text block is incomplete and does not provide any information.

text:
• Fig. 14.22  Illustration of the relative thickness of bone covering lingual 
mandibular second and third molar roots. (A) Measurement of the thick-
ness of bony cover lingual to the apex of the third mandibular molar imme-
diately below the mylohyoid ridge. It measures only 0.5 mm. (B) Repetition 
of measurement in the deepest portion lingually of the second molar alveo-
lus. It measures fully 2 mm.
summary: Illustration of the relative thickness of bone covering lingual mandibular second and third molar roots.

text:
• Fig. 14.23  Comparison of the size and shape of mandibles at various 
ages. Top, Mandible of a 5-year-old. Notice the smoother, rounded bow-
like form. Notice also the amount of space between the second deciduous 
molar and the ramus. Middle, Mandible of an approximately 70-year-old 
adult. Notice the wear of the occlusal surfaces of the teeth and peri-
odontal bone loss. Bottom, Well-developed mandible of an individual 
approximately 50 years of age. The bone is regular in outline. The lingual 
constriction has lessened and has retreated to the third molar area.
summary: Comparison of mandible size and shape at different ages, showing changes in morphology and wear patterns.

text:
227
CHAPTER 14  Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
particular: it is not as cancellous, and instead of the facial 
plate’s being relatively thin, it is equally as heavy as the lingual 
plate. Although the bone over the anterior teeth, including the 
canine, is very thin and may be entirely missing over the cervi-
cal portion of the root, the bone that does cover the root is the 
compact type.
summary: The bone over the anterior teeth, including the canine, is very thin and may be entirely missing over the cervical portion of the root, but the bone that does cover the root is the compact type.

text:
The inferior border of the mandible is strong and rounded and 
gives to the bone the greatest portion of its strength (see Fig. 14.15).
summary: The inferior border of the mandible provides the bone with its greatest strength.

text:
When one looks down on the mandible from a point above 
the alveoli of the first molars (see Fig. 14.18), it can be noticed 
that although the alveolar border may be thinner anteriorly 
than posteriorly, the body of the bone is uniform throughout. 
The lines of direction of the posterior alveoli are inclined lin-
gually to conform to the lingual inclination of the teeth when 
they are in position. The anterior teeth, of course, have their 
alveoli tipped labially; therefore when one looks down on the 
mandible from above the alveolar process, more of the bone 
may be seen lingual to the anterior teeth than lingual to the 
posterior teeth. In contrast, posteriorly, more of the bone may 
be seen buccal to the teeth than lingual. Therefore the outline of 
the arch of the teeth does not correspond to the outline of the arch 
of the bone. The dental arch is narrower posteriorly than the 
mandibular arch.
summary: The anatomy of the mandible shows differences in thickness and direction of alveoli, affecting the alignment of teeth.

text:
The lingual walls of the alveoli of the second and third molars 
are relatively thin near the bottoms of the sockets, although the 
bone near the periphery is somewhat thicker and very compact. If 
a specimen of the mandible from which the third molar has been 
removed is held up to the light, the bone at the bottom of the 
socket is so thin that light will penetrate it. This thinness of bone
summary: Description of the thinness of the lingual walls of alveoli in the second and third molars.

text:
is consistent with the submandibular fossa below the mylohyoid 
ridge (Fig. 14.24; see also Figs. 14.15 and 14.22A and B).
summary: Description of the submandibular fossa below the mylohyoid ridge.

text:
The bone buccal to the last two molars is very heavy and thick, 
being reinforced by the external oblique ridge. Posterior to the 
third molar, a triangular shallow fossa is outlined; it is called the 
retromolar triangle (see Fig. 14.17). The cortical plate over this 
fossa is not as heavy as the bone surrounding it, and it is more 
cancellous under the thin cortical plate covering it.
summary: Description of the bone structure buccal to the last two molars, including the retromolar triangle with a thinner cortical plate.

text: Alveoli
summary: Alveoli are the sockets in the jawbone where teeth are anchored.

text:
The first alveolus right or left of the median line is that of the 
first, or central, incisor. The periphery of the alveolus often dips 
down lingually and labially and exposes the root for part of its 
length. This arrangement makes an interdental spine out of the 
interdental septum separating the alveolus of the mandibular cen-
tral incisors. The central incisor alveolus is flattened on its mesial 
surface and is usually somewhat concave distally to accommodate 
the developmental groove on the root (see Figs. 14.18 and 14.19).
summary: Description of the anatomy of the alveolus of the central incisor, including its shape and relationship to the interdental septum.

text:
The alveolus of the mandibular second, or lateral, incisor is 
similar to that of the central incisor. It usually has the following 
variations: the socket is larger and deeper to accommodate a larger 
and longer root; the periphery does not dip down as far on the 
lingual surface but may dip more on the labial aspect of the tooth, 
exposing more of the root of the lateral incisor. The interdental 
septum extends up just as high between the teeth as that between 
the central incisors.
summary: The alveolus of the mandibular second incisor has variations in size and shape compared to the central incisor.

text:
The canine alveolus is quite large and oval and, of course, deep 
to accommodate the root of the mandibular canine. The lingual
summary: Description of the anatomy of the canine alveolus in relation to the mandibular canine root.

text:
• Fig. 14.24  Some fine vertical sections of a skull made with radiographic problems in view. These radio-
graphs of faciolingual sections show the extent of tooth attachment, the way in which individual teeth 
compare with each other, and the variances between cortical and cancellous bone in anchorage (see Figs. 
14.25 to 14.32). The maxillary canine was impacted in this specimen. Maxillary third molars were missing. 
(From Updegrave WJ: Normal radiodontic anatomy, Dent Radiogr Photogr 31:57, 1958.)
summary: Radiographic images of skull sections showing tooth attachment, tooth comparison, and bone variances, with an impacted maxillary canine and missing third molars.

text:
228
CHAPTER 14    Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text:
plate is stronger and much heavier than that over the alveoli just 
described, although the thin labial plate may thin out at its edges 
and expose just as much of the canine root on the labial side. The 
labial outline of the alveolus is wider than the lingual outline, and 
the mesial and distal walls of the sockets are irregular to accom-
modate developmental grooves, both mesially and distally, on the 
canine root (see Figs. 14.18 and 14.20).
summary: The labial plate over the alveoli is stronger and heavier, with a wider outline than the lingual side, accommodating developmental grooves on the canine root.

text:
The alveoli of the first and second premolars are similar in 
outline. The outline is smooth and rounded, although the dimen-
sions are greater buccolingually than mesiodistally. The alveolus 
of the second premolar is usually somewhat larger than that of 
the first premolar. The buccal plate of the alveoli is relatively thin, 
but the lingual plate is heavy; the interdental septum has become 
heavier at this point compared with the interdental septa found 
between the anterior teeth. The interdental septum between the 
canine and first premolar is relatively thin, although uniform in 
outline. The septum between the first premolar and second pre-
molar is nearly twice as thick.
summary: Comparison of alveoli between first and second premolars, with differences in dimensions and thickness of buccal and lingual plates.

text:
Progressing posteriorly (see Figs. 14.18 and 14.20), the inter-
dental septum between the second premolar socket and the alveo-
lus of the mesial root of the first molar is twice as thick as that 
found between the first and second premolars. The socket of the 
first molar is divided by an interroot septum, which is strong and 
regular. The alveolus of the mesial root is kidney-shaped, much 
wider buccolingually than mesiodistally, and constricted in the 
center to accommodate developmental grooves found mesial and 
distal to the mesial root of the first molar. The alveolus of the 
distal root of the first molar is evenly oval with no constriction, 
conforming to the rounded shape of this root. The interdental 
septum between the alveoli of the mandibular first molar and the 
socket of the second molar is thick mesiodistally, although cancel-
lous in character.
summary: Description of the anatomy of the interdental septum between the second premolar socket and the alveolus of the mesial root of the first molar.

text:
The mandibular second molar alveolus may be divided into 
two alveoli, as was the case in the first molar. However, often it 
is found to be one compartment near the periphery of the alveo-
lus but divides into two compartments in the deeper portions. A 
septal spine occurs where the developmental grooves on the root 
are deep enough, or an interradicular septum will appear when 
the roots are entirely divided. The interdental septum between the 
second molar sockets and the third molar sockets is not as thick 
mesiodistally as the two interdental septa immediately anterior.
summary: The mandibular second molar alveolus can be divided into two compartments, with a septal spine or interradicular septum forming in deeper portions.

text:
The mandibular third molar alveolus is usually irregular in 
outline (see Fig. 14.21). Usually, it is much narrower toward the 
distal than toward the mesial aspect of the alveolus. It may have 
interradicular septa or septal spines to accommodate itself to the 
irregularity of the root.
summary: The mandibular third molar alveolus is irregular in outline, narrower distally, and may have interradicular septa or septal spines.

text:
Faciolingual views of the teeth and their supporting structures 
can be made clinically using computed tomography to demon-
strate the way that individual teeth relate to each other or to corti-
cal and cancellous bone; however, vertical sections of a skull were 
made to illustrate these relationships,1 as shown in Fig. 14.24. (See 
also Figs. 13.29 and 13.30.)
summary: Computed tomography can be used to create faciolingual views of teeth and their supporting structures, illustrating their relationships.

text:
Some classical illustrations of sections of the axial relations of 
the maxillary and mandibular teeth are shown in Figs. 14.25 to 
14.32. These figures demonstrate the directional lines of the axes 
of the teeth and their alveoli (see Box 16.1 and Fig. 16.20). In 
addition, the radiographs of the sections graphically illustrate the 
relative densities of the teeth and supporting structures and show 
the outline and relative thickness of the bone over the various 
teeth at the site of each section.2
summary: Classical illustrations of axial relations of maxillary and mandibular teeth demonstrate directional lines of teeth axes, alveoli, relative densities of teeth and supporting structures, and bone thickness.

text:
In Figs. 14.25 to 14.32, note the axial relations of the 
superior and inferior teeth, the relative thickness of labial
summary: Axial relations of superior and inferior teeth and relative thickness of labial

text:
and lingual alveolar plates, the characteristics of the cancel-
lous tissue, the relative densities, and the relation of the teeth 
to important structures. Compare the changes in the external 
contour and internal architecture of the adjacent sections. The 
sections in this series, with the exception of those in Fig. 14.28, 
were taken from the same cadaver and are from the left side. 
A plaster cast was made before sectioning. The sections were 
reassembled in the cast and held in exact relation while being 
radiographed.
summary: The text discusses the comparison of changes in external contour and internal architecture of dental structures in relation to important structures.

text:
Figs. 14.33I and 14.33II illustrate the appearance of some of 
the bony landmarks of the maxilla and mandible as visualized 
in intraoral periapical radiography.3 Surfaces and dento-osseous 
structures are often important to recognize in relation to diagnos-
tic and treatment aspects (Fig. 14.34).
summary: Illustration of bony landmarks of the maxilla and mandible in intraoral periapical radiography for diagnostic and treatment purposes.
Illustration showing the relation of the superior central incisor to the inferior lateral incisor.

process, J Am Dent Assoc 11:1059, 1924.)
summary: Illustration showing the position of the apex of the superior lateral incisor in the lateral incisor regions.

text:
229
CHAPTER 14  Dento-Osseous Structures, Blood Vessels, and Nerves
summary: Chapter 14 discusses the anatomy of dento-osseous structures, blood vessels, and nerves.

text: Arterial Supply to the Teeth
summary: The text discusses the arterial blood supply to the teeth.

text:
The arteries and nerve branches to the teeth are mere terminals 
of the central systems. This book must confine itself to dental 
anatomy and the parts immediately associated, and references are 
therefore made only to those terminals that supply the teeth and 
the supporting structures.
summary: The arteries and nerve branches to the teeth are terminals of the central systems, with this book focusing on dental anatomy and associated parts.

text: Internal Maxillary Artery
summary: The internal maxillary artery is an important blood vessel in the head and neck region.

text:
The arterial supply to the jaw bones and the teeth comes from the 
maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery 
(Fig. 14.35). The branches of the maxillary artery that feed the 
teeth directly are the inferior alveolar artery and the superior 
alveolar arteries (see Fig. 14.35).
summary: The maxillary artery, a branch of the external carotid artery, supplies blood to the jaw bones and teeth via branches like the inferior alveolar and superior alveolar arteries.

text: Inferior Alveolar Artery
summary: The inferior alveolar artery is an important blood vessel in the oral cavity.

text:
The inferior alveolar artery branches from the maxillary artery 
medial to the ramus of the mandible. Protected by the spheno-
mandibular ligament, it gives off the mylohyoid branch, which 
rests in the mylohyoid groove of the mandible and continues 
along on the medial side under the mylohyoid line. After giv-
ing off the mylohyoid branch, it immediately enters the man-
dibular foramen and continues downward and forward through 
the mandibular canal, giving off branches to the premolar and 
molar teeth. In the vicinity of the mental foramen, it divides 
into a mental and an incisive branch. The mental branch 
passes through the mental foramen to supply the tissues of the 
chin and to anastomose with the inferior labial and submental
summary: The inferior alveolar artery branches from the maxillary artery and supplies blood to the mandible, teeth, chin, and surrounding tissues.

text:
• Fig. 14.27  Canine regions. Note anterior extremity of maxillary antrum. 
(From MacMillan HW: The structure and function of the alveolar process, J 
Am Dent Assoc 11:1059, 1924.)
summary: Illustration of canine regions with a note on the anterior extremity of the maxillary antrum.

text:
• Fig. 14.28  First premolar regions. (From MacMillan HW: The structure 
and function of the alveolar process, J Am Dent Assoc 11:1059, 1924.)
summary: Illustration of first premolar regions from a dental textbook.

text:
• Fig. 14.29  Second premolar regions. (From MacMillan HW: The structure 
and function of the alveolar process, J Am Dent Assoc 11:1059, 1924.)
summary: Illustration of second premolar regions from a dental textbook.
